PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Harry Jenkins) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-

(1) condemns the intimidatory remarks of the Premier of New South Wales in relation to the evidence being given to the Senate Inquiry by Mr Clarrie Briese, the Chief Stipendiary Magistrate of New South Wales;

(2) notes with concern this further example of the Premier's increasingly irrational and improper conduct in relation to certain matters pertaining to the administration of justice in New South Wales, and

(3) expresses its concern at the implication for the administration of justice in New South Wales including those areas comprising federal jurisdiction of New South Wales courts arising from the Premier's conduct.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move :

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-

(1) expresses concern that a pensioner couple living on a farm worth $200,000, with a house valued at $50,000, would be ineligible for the pension under the assets test, whilst a pensioner couple living in a city with a house valued at $ 200,000 and other assets of $50,000 would be eligible for a full pension, and
(2) demands that the Prime Minister, and all members of his Government, refrain from using the words fair and equitable in relation to the pensions assets test.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) notes that the Government has-
(a) introduced an assets test;
(b) increased tax on superannuation;
(c) increased five fold the income tax of a pensioner earning $20 a week; and
(d) reduced from 60 days to 35 days the time all but the acutely ill can stay in hospital without being charged, and
(2) calls on the Government to stop ripping into Australia's elderly citizens simply to finance big spending programs while posturing as a friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move and the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) will second:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House calls upon the Prime Minister and the Leader of the House to indicate when they intend to call on for debate, notice of motion No. 1 for Monday 8 October 1984, standing in the name of the honourable Member for Denison and seconded by the honourable Member for O'Connor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-

(1) recognises that there is an implied threat by the New South Wales Attorney- General Mr Landa to the Chief Stipendiary Magistrate of New South Wales, reported on 12 September 1984 and confirms that such a threat amounts to contempt, or breach of Parliamentary privilege, against this Parliament; and
(2) condemns-
(a) the attempt to interfere with evidence about to be provided by a witness, before a committee of this Parliament, and

(b) the overt threat by the Premier of New South Wales to the Chief Stipendiary Magistrate of New South Wales, Mr Briese, regarding his future employment, as an outright attempt to interfere with a witness currently before a committee of the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Treasurer assure the House that details of applications for foreign bank licences will be kept strictly confidential whilst the Government makes a decision on them and not disclosed to any body or person outside the Government or the Reserve Bank of Australia?

—I am not sure of the point of the honourable gentleman's question because I think most of the bank groups which have an interest in Australia have already expressed such an interest. I do not think one would need to be an insider to list the institutions which have already made approaches. I am on the record as having met many of these institutions. When I was in the United States of America recently I invited any institution interested in making an application to listen to what I had to say at the Australian Embassy in Washington, and many turned up. The institutions which did appear there were reported upon. So in that sense I could not give the Deputy Leader of the Opposition an assurance that those institutions alone know that they are interested. However, I might say that the details of their applications and of the proposals they have put will be confidential to the Government and the Reserve Bank until announced.

—Has the Treasurer's attention been drawn to predictions by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that the Government will bring down a harsh mini -Budget next March or April? Is there any factual basis for such predictions or do they simply represent another attempt by the Opposition to side-track attention from the Government's successful economic management?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One is always interested to hear the Opposition state so firmly that the opposing Party will be in government after the next election and that budgetary policy will be in the hands of a Labor government. Let me make it clear that the purpose of a mini-Budget is either to change the direction of fiscal policy substantially or to change it absolutely. This Government has no need to change its fiscal policy in any way, much less in a major sense. My colleague the Minister for Finance gave an answer last week which I thought would have silenced the pathetic interventions on this matter of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. The Minister pointed out that the Prime Minister had announced just after the Budget this year that some of the expenditure data and procedures would be brought forward next year so as to undertake an expenditure review of the normal Budget processes earlier than perhaps we were able to achieve this year.

ANSWER.PARA: I repeat that the 1984-85 Budget is in tune with the economy. It was designed for the state of the economy, as the success of the 1983-84 Budget left the economy in the transition to a pick up in private investment and consumption. We have seen adequate data since the Budget has been produced, including in the market-place, on interest rates and retail sales and a range of other indicators , to show that the Budget strategy is working quite well. Of course, in that Budget we have forecast 5.25 per cent inflation, 5 per cent non-farm growth in the economy and a 5 per cent pick-up in investment. Hence there is no need from the Government's point of view to contemplate in any way a mini-Budget. What we are really seeing here are the thought processes of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, who, as Treasurer in 1978, ripped away the tax cuts which were promised by his party in 1977. He said, revealingly, in the House a couple of weeks ago that he was able to take away the tax cuts because he had not given them; he was not the Treasurer. The fact that his Party gave them, that he promised them during the election campaign and then swept them away five months later is taken care of in terms of his morality by his saying: 'I never gave them in the first place, so I could take them back'.

If Australia were to have the unfortunate experience of a Peacock-Howard-led government after the next poll, the tax cuts given by this Government would be swept away. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition made it quite plain a couple of weeks before the Budget that, given a choice between tax cuts and a lower Budget deficit, he would have no tax cuts. It is quite obvious that the tax cuts would disappear. It is also obvious that a coalition government would destroy Medicare , terminate our jobs program, introduce new taxes, attempt to finance the irresponsible parish pump expenditures promised by the Leader of the Opposition as well as destroy the prices and incomes accord. In other words, the Opposition has learned no lessons from its dismal experience. We are hearing predictions about mini-Budgets from the mini-Budget specialist, the honourable member for Bennelong, the person who presided over the worst economic performance in this country since the Great Depression, with a doubling of unemployment within a 12- month period, record interest rates and record inflation. He is now telling this Government how we ought to be implementing economic policies. The Government has no plans for a mini-Budget. There will be no mini-Budget. The fiscal policy is on track and the economy is growing very nicely, thank you. We are getting plaudits from the business community not only in Australia but also in the rest of the world and we do not need the Opposition's advice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Treasurer a further question which follows the earlier question he answered. Did the Treasurer meet on 7 June representatives of the Australian Bank Employees Union and the Commonwealth Bank Officers Association? Did the union representatives ask him for the right to scrutinise applications for foreign bank licences? Did the Treasurer indicate that there would be no particular problem, provided confidentiality was right? Did he also indicate that he did not want any cowboys coming into Australia in the form of foreign banks? Indeed, did the Treasurer at that meeting give those union representatives a cast-iron guarantee that any foreign banks allowed into Australia would have to be closed union shops?
—I did meet the bank unions, although I am not sure of the date.
—Oh!

—It was reported. Do not members of the Opposition read the newspapers? I met with them and with the Australian Council of Trade Unions for four hours. They did propose that they scrutinise the bank applications, which I found to be totally unacceptable, and I rejected that course. I indicated to them that as far as the Government was concerned we wanted competition in the banking sector, we would take on board institutions which were of undoubted financial strength and we would expect that the union practices which prevail at the moment in terms of employment in the banking system would be at least the standards which we would expect from any potential applicant.

—Is the Minister for Primary Industry aware of the difficulties currently being experienced by parts of the sugar industry, particularly in the super-wet belt? What steps is the Government taking to address these problems?

—The honourable member for Leichhardt focuses on a question to which the Government is giving considerable time and attention. I believe that the honourable member for Leichhardt and the honourable member for Herbert have paid more attention to this industry than any other two backbenchers in this House for a long, long time. Similarly, in terms of the number of Queensland Cane Growers Council meetings and mill committee meetings I have attended, it is obvious that I, as Minister for Primary Industry in this Government, have gained a better acquaintance with the industry's problems than has any other Federal Minister. The previous Government treated the industry's requests for assistance with contempt. I also went to Geneva twice with the Queensland Minister for Primary Industries to see whether, together, we could get an international sugar agreement. Last year, after looking at all the requests of the industry-I think those requests would now amount to about $400m if we added them up-the Commonwealth and Queensland governments got together to formulate a package of measures relating to rural adjustment Part B funds. Those funds were spent by about the middle of this year. When we negotiated the Commonwealth-State domestic sugar agreement it was agreed, after a lot of discussion with the industry-particularly the four major industry groups-that the industry itself would institute a wide-ranging review of the industry's production, marketing and regulatory mechanisms. Last week I met the industry leadership in Canberra and was very heartened by the progress being made by the industry itself in reviewing all its institutions. The industry leaders are engaged in a study of their own industry that will, I think, put that industry in a far better and more flexible shape to deal with problems in the future. The industry is working on legislation going back to 1915 and 1933, and the industry understands and respects the fact that times have changed and that there is a need to look at some of the fundamental institutions. The Queensland Government is approaching the Commonwealth and I hope to be talking to Mr Turner, the Minister for Primary Industries in Queensland, as soon as possible to see what views he has on the industry's own arrangements and requests for assistance in the immediate short term because we believe that the industry's problems go beyond a short term liquidity crisis. In negotiations over the last year the Commonwealth and State governments have reached a wide measure of agreement on the facts about the industry, and that has clearly indicated to us that the problem now facing about 10 per cent of the people in the industry relates to the payment of money for interest on debts, some of which flow from the high period of 1980-81 when farmers bought out other farmers or went heavily into capitalisation and machinery. We are getting a better picture of the industry's problems. As I said , I hope to be seeing Mr Turner in the near future so that the Commonwealth and State governments can work together on the industry's problems. Seeing that his Government spent some $20m on the industry with respect to rural adjustment part B funds, I would be interested to know whether he has knowledge to impart on what is the best way to go with that industry.

—My question is to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer him to Friday's ambivalent joint statement by the Prime Minister and the Premier of Western Australia. Will the Minister clarify the Government's position on the application of the five non-negotiable principles for Aboriginal land rights and , in particular, does the Federal Government still intend to enact overriding legislation in accordance with those principles to provide Aboriginal veto over mining on Aboriginal land?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised that the honourable gentleman regards the statement as ambivalent. I thought it was perfectly clear.
—Yes, it said nothing.

—I realise that the honourable gentleman believes that any problem with indigenous people can be solved with an iron bar. We do not share that view . The statement that was made followed an offer made by the Premier of Western Australia, which the Prime Minister and I were glad to endorse, whereby the Commonwealth and a senior officer of my Department on a full time basis would participate in the drafting of land rights legislation in Western Australia. I believe that that is a very significant development. It is the first occasion on which any State Premier concerned to draft land rights legislation has approached not merely the Commonwealth Government but also mining and industry groups, the pastoral industry, and even the Opposition in Western Australia, for the purpose of trying to produce legislation that will encompass the range of attitudes that have been expressed on this issue. The Commonwealth Government and I welcome that offer. We will participate fully in the development of that legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me be perfectly candid about it: As between the Commonwealth and all States there are differing approaches. I have always made it clear that we are concerned to see that those differing approaches among the States are developed as far as they can be. I am not going on the basis of the arrangements that have been reached. It would be quite improper for me to prejudge the legislation to be introduced by the Burke Government. I can understand why the Opposition is concerned about this, because the real difference between it and the Hawke Labor Government is this: As a result of the recent Fraser Government the people had bequeathed to them in Aboriginal affairs the situation at Noonkanbah where the Western Australian Government acted in a way which brought great problems to the mining industry, great deprivation to Aboriginal people, and shame on Australia in its handling of these problems. We will not go down that track.

The honourable gentleman, when he addresses these questions, should first tell the House the Opposition's position on this matter. Does it oppose land rights legislation? Does it oppose the Commonwealth participating in drawing up legislation with the Western Australian Government, whose prime concern is to grant land rights to the Aboriginal people of Western Australia, who at this stage, after years of Liberal administration, have absolutely nothing? That is the purpose of the exercise. At this stage I suggest that the honourable gentleman, before worrying about our position or that of the Western Australian Government, tell the Leader of the Opposition in Western Australia exactly how he stands in respect of his position, which is simply that Aboriginal people, so long deprived of any rights at all in Western Australia, will not get anything from the Liberal Opposition in Western Australia.

I am very confident of the outcome of this exercise. I can understand the concern of honourable gentlemen opposite, who cannot sit down with Mr Hassell because this adolescent shadow Minister says in Canberra that he supports land rights but in Western Australia says that he opposes them. That is not a position which ought to commend itself to the Leader of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to recent proposals circulated by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and next Opposition Leader supporting a flat rate of income tax. Is the Government considering the introduction of a flat rate of income tax of 30 per cent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was amused over the weekend to see the Deputy Leader of the Opposition put out a Press statement about a 'non-political' study by members of the new Right from Monash University. It was so non-political that the Deputy Leader was able to release it before the Parliamentary Library even received it. I would have thought that the expression 'non-political' in the Press statement gave his hand away anyway. The paper proposed a flat rate of tax. The Deputy Leader quite dishonestly lifted things from the paper and recommended the paper. He did not highlight one of the principal features, that is, a flat rate of tax.

ANSWER.PARA: It is part of the desperate tactics of the Opposition to refer to such papers. The paper was prepared by Michael Porter and others at Monash University, including people supporting that group such as John Hyde, Hugh Morgan, Geoffrey Blainey and others-the new Right. But these are not new policies. Basically, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is going back to the leadership of the Queensland National Party-the Joh and Flo show-on a 30 per cent flat rate tax. A flat rate tax of 30 per cent would cost revenue this year about $4 billion. There is no point in the Deputy Leader of the Opposition racing around and saying that he will introduce a broadly based consumption tax to cover the shortfall in revenue because to recover about $4 billion would mean a consumer price index effect from indirect taxes of the order of six percentage points. So we would be well and truly back up the inflationary ladder to the sorts of levels we inherited from the former Government if the Deputy Leader's policies on a consumption tax of that kind to cover the revenue shortfall from a reduction in tax of that order of magnitude were to be undertaken.

Another thing that the paper advocates is a reduction in the tax free threshold to $4,000 per annum. I would be interested in the views of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition about a reduction in the tax free threshold to $4,000 per annum. That would lift the tax for pensioners to about $238 a year or nearly $5 a week. What the paper is looking at in that respect is an increase in tax for pensioners, the unemployed and the disabled. We should bear in mind that this Government's Budget exempted them in the tax cut arrangements we introduced in August. We will have no bar of crocodile tears from the Opposition about lower income families because the paper which the Deputy Leader circulates basically says, amongst other things, that pensions and benefits are too high. It argues that they are a disincentive to work. The Deputy Leader endorses the paper strongly. He says: 'You can come and pick it up from my office'. The paper says that there is a disincentive to work and that pensions and benefits are too high . The Deputy Leader is on the same kick as the honourable member for Hume, who spent a week on his bicycle on the dole and tried to indicate that pensions and benefits were higher than they ought to be.

This Government has no intention of adopting a flat rate of tax. I indicate also the dishonesty in the treatment of this paper by the Deputy Leader. He did not draw attention to one part of it which I will quote. It specifically acknowledges that the Budget tax cuts 'reduce the tax bill faced by people at all income levels'. We did not hear that on AM this morning or see it in the Deputy Leader's Press statement. It also acknowledges that:
. . . by contributing to the maintenance of the 'Accord' the tax cuts assist in restraining wages and thereby inflation, and in restoring profitability in the private sector . . .

Despite the shortcomings of the paper it recognises the tax cuts in this Budget all round for all taxpayers. It says the Budget contributes to the maintenance of the prices and incomes accord and lower inflation. What the Deputy Leader did not indicate is that two and a quarter million Australians have a lower marginal tax rate as a result of this Budget. What he never indicated and fails to indicate when he talks about marginal tax rates is that the average rate of tax for all taxpayers is down because there is now a 25 per cent rate step between $ 4,595 and $12,500. He totally failed to mention that there is another rate step of 25 per cent between $4,595 and $12,500.

Let me sum up by saying that it was very interesting for the Deputy Leader to be embracing and handing out a paper by this group from the new right advocating a flat rate tax. We will then hear about his consumption taxes to pay for these things and their massive inflationary effects because there is no way that the unions will talk to him about any discounting. He does not believe in the accord ; he would destroy it. Also it is very instructive that this paper indicates and acknowledges that there is a tax cut for all categories of taxpayers as a result of this Budget and indicates by implication, therefore, that the average rate of tax is down. It is about time that the Deputy Leader started to indicate the facts as they are; that there is a real tax cut, that average rates of tax are down and that all taxpayers receive benefits from this Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Opposition. I would not go to the Prime Minister for a reliable answer on this matter. I ask the Leader of the Opposition a question relating to the Bill he introduced on 4 October 1984 to amend the National Crime Authority Act 1984. Can he give the House any further information regarding his proposed amendment to section 11 of the principal Act as contained in clause 5 of the Bill and his amendment to section 18 as contained in clause 8? Are these amendments directed to limiting the potential for political manipulation of the Authority's functions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very grateful once again to the honourable member for directing a question on the amendments that the Opposition has introduced to the National Crime Authority legislation. The reality is that it is particularly apt that this question should be asked today because of the bullying and blatant political remarks, and the political manipulation of the administration of justice in New South Wales by the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Wran. We have alleged for a long while that such interference-and such interference politically-into the administration of justice was occurring and there is manifest evidence out of the Premier's own words.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. I cannot hear the answer of the Leader of the Opposition.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I appreciate the comments from honourable members but it is necessary for me to hear the answer to see whether it is in order with parliamentary procedures.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. The relevance of that is, of course, that one of the major flaws of the current legislation is that it allows the National Crime Authority to be subject to political manipulation. Firstly, the Authority may only investigate using its coercive powers upon a reference being provided to it by a State or Federal Minister via the Inter-Governmental Committee. For political purposes the Authority could be refused a reference and its investigation so circumscribed. Secondly, the Federal Minister may give directions to the Authority as to how it is to conduct investigations with respect to a particular case. Therefore, my Bill, if enacted, will completely divorce the Authority from political interference in these respects and, if enacted, that Bill will give the Authority power to investigate of its own volition any Federal offence--

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I do not do so to disrupt the Leader of the Opposition's flow, because it is interesting. On several occasions we have had raised in the House this question of asking questions on Bills. There have been several interpretations. The last interpretation I recollect is that there is a requirement on questioning a person with a private member's Bill before the House that the argument should be concerned strictly with the detail of what is contained in the Bill, not an argument about its effect or a contrasting of a provision of the Bill with other prevailing practices or other legislation.
—He is hurting, isn't he, Kim? Are you Wran's man too?
—Oh, it does not worry me at all. I raise the point of order so that we can get the precedent quite clearly established for future reference.

—I thank the Minister for raising the point of order. I do not uphold the point of order. I do not agree that there are varying interpretations. The Standing Orders principally direct attention to the nature of questions. Questions may be asked of a member in charge of a Bill or a motion. One of the difficulties has always been whether the member, when asked that question, is anticipating debate. In this case we have a Bill introduced into the Parliament, a second reading speech has been made and a member has sought information about specific clauses of that legislation. The question, therefore, is in order. I call the Leader of the Opposition.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. I was saying that, if enacted, my Bill will give the Authority power to investigate of its own volition any Federal offence and abrogate the Minister's power to give directions with respect to a particular case. There are real problems and it is not sufficient to say, as the Government says, that although there is potential for political interference we would not do that, because while there is any potential for political interference there will always be cynics-perhaps today they are realists-who suggest that a particular investigation, its conduct or the failure to investigate were politically motivated. As a consequence, public confidence in the Authority and its ability to combat organised crime will be undermined. This , of course, is certainly not an abstract fear. It was this concern with political interference in the administration of justice and in the investigation of crime which led me to move the amendments in the Bill to which the honourable member refers.

ANSWER.PARA: When I say that it is not an abstract fear, I point out that only yesterday we witnessed the Premier of New South Wales, the President of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Wran, seeking to pressure a witness before a Senate inquiry because that witness--

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Speaker. The program indicates that this period of the Parliament is given to questions without notice. In view of the fact that the Leader of the Opposition quite clearly is reading from a prepared answer, are you satisfied that the question which has been asked of him by one of his own members is in fact a question without notice?

—I state in response to the honourable member for Hunter that over my 15 years in this Parliament I have watched Speakers wrestle with the difficulty of dorothy dixers and have never found one of them brave enough to state that such has occurred. I do not uphold the point of order. I call the Leader of the Opposition.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. I said that only yesterday we witnessed the Premier of New South Wales and the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Wran, seeking to pressure a witness before a Senate inquiry because that witness had the temerity to give evidence which yet again has cast doubts upon the Premier's role in the manipulation of the New South Wales criminal justice system. Using the political powers entrusted to him, Mr Wran has sought to silence Mr Briese for his own purposes. Mr Wran has said that there is now a big question mark over Mr Briese. This relates directly to the question of political interference raised by the honourable member for Mitchell.

ANSWER.PARA: I think we assume that, had Mr Briese given evidence of the type Mr Wran would have liked, there would be no question mark and his appointment as Chief Stipendiary Magistrate would certainly have been affirmed. Quite apart from any concern that the Opposition might have over a government applying a carrot and stick to a witness to manipulate his evidence, this episode renews the Opposition's fear that similar actions could be taken to circumscribe the National Crime Authority's operation. The fact is that the Senate may deal with Mr Wran's remarks-this is the real threat--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order under standing order 145, which states that answers to questions of this nature must be relevant. I point out that what the Leader of the Opposition is speaking on has no relevance to the Bill that he introduced in the House last week.

—Order! I listened carefully to the Leader of the Opposition. I was in fact about to interpose on relevance when the Leader of the Opposition did relate his remarks to that portion of the Bill he was questioned on.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. I was relating my answer to the sections which are directed to limiting the potential for political manipulation of the Authority's functions. We can see enough political manipulation in the administration of justice in New South Wales and we do not want that form of political manipulation so far as the National Crime Authority is concerned, and under the current legislation that could well occur.

ANSWER.PARA: In conclusion I want to say this: In dealing with this political manipulation the Senate may take whatever action it wishes, but it is our duty to point out that the real threat in the remarks of the President of the Australian Labor Party and Premier of New South Wales represents a political interference in the administration of justice in New South Wales and there is an enormous investment of Federal jurisdiction in State courts. It may be going on in New South Wales; this House should be seeking to ensure that it does not go on so far as the National Crime Authority is concerned. As a consequence the Government ought to support the Opposition's Bills and, more to the point, so far as the weekend remarks are concerned, ensure that that degree of Federal jurisdiction invested in the courts in New South Wales not be permitted to be manipulated in the way it is by the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party, a man with whom this Prime Minister stands shoulder to shoulder.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. I remind him of his claim during Question Time last Friday that there were significant errors in the amendments to the National Crime Authority Act moved by the Leader of the Opposition last Thursday. The Prime Minister will also recall that the Leader of the Opposition claimed that he had corrected those errors. I ask: Can the Prime Minister confirm that his assertion on Friday was in fact correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question from the honourable member for Isaacs assumes added significance in the light of the wasted 12 minutes that we have just gone through. I pointed out to the House on Friday that the Government finds it very difficult to take the Opposition seriously in any respect when it is talking about fighting organised crime. I said that this view had been reinforced by the fact that the Opposition's amendments to the National Crime Authority Act on Thursday had sought to do these things, and the House will remember: Firstly, to amend two sections of the Act which did not exist-that is not a bad effort in itself-and, secondly, to amend a further section in a way which would make it absolutely meaningless. Honourable members will recall that, after I had made that startling revelation about just how much the Opposition was across this issue, the Leader of the Opposition strongly denied it. Honourable members will recall that he said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the Prime Minister referred to amendments moved by me yesterday that did not even relate to the Act. That shows how much time the Prime Minister spends in the Parliament. That was the first draft by a staffer. I looked at the principal Act, saw that there was an error, changed it, and when I came into the House those proposed amendments were not even moved.

Even at that stage, when one's reserves of charity should have been almost absolutely exhausted by the behaviour of the Leader of the Opposition, I nevertheless accepted his denial, but I was sufficiently prudent to have the matter checked. We were already aware that the Leader of the Opposition had corrected one error when he introduced his amendments. The Bill which he presented had a hand-written alteration to clause 12(b), which purported to amend section 25 of the Act. We were also aware that there were three errors in addition to that which I had identified and which were not corrected. The Leader of the Opposition in this House falsely denied committing them.

That is not the end of the matter. Over the weekend we were able to identify yet another three errors, taking the total of errors committed by the Leader of the Opposition to six. I table a schedule of the errors made by the Leader of the Opposition-this man who is so deeply committed to the National Crimes Act that the amendments he brings in contain six errors.
Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest that the Prime Minister wait until the House comes to order.

—Obviously, Opposition members are wasting the whole of Question Time. We are aware, of course, that occasionally Bills are introduced into the House with errors in them. Minor mistakes are sometimes made. As everyone on this side of the House will appreciate, the basic point here is that the Leader of the Opposition completely denied being responsible for any errors and denied it in such a way that he appeared to be trying to suggest that the errors had been made on this side of the House. This is the kind of action by the Leader of the Opposition that clearly misleads the House-one can only come to the conclusion that he is deliberately misleading the House-and if it were undertaken by a Minister would lead to calls for his resignation from the other side.

ANSWER.PARA: We all know that the Leader of the Opposition is contemplating the last few weeks of his political career and that he is in a desperate position, but I observe finally that the events in this House last Friday demonstrate to the members of this House and the people of Australia that this Leader of the Opposition is as willing to make a false denial as he is to make a false accusation.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES: ADMINISTRATION OF JUSTICE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister, and I say in passing that he would be the expert in false denials because what he alleged was that I introduced clauses to amend sections that did not exist. He knows that is not so and his references to any drafting changes that had to be made are not what he said last week.
—Order! I ask the Leader of the Opposition to ask his question.

—Those comments are only by way of preface. Yes, I will get to my question. If that was the real reason why the Government was opposing the National Crime Authority Amendment Bill it would have some importance, but we know the real reason. I refer the Prime Minister to his support for Mr Wran's approach to the administration of justice in New South Wales-standing shoulder to shoulder with the Premier of New South Wales. Bearing in mind the political interference by Mr Wran in his threats against Mr Briese, does the Prime Minister confirm his confidence in Mr Wran's approach to the administration of justice in New South Wales, in view of the substantial investment of Federal jurisdiction in State courts.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition, in addressing this question to me, covered a range of matters, many of which obviously are concerned with the administration of matters peculiarly within the province of the New South Wales Government. He related those matters also to the well known position which I have adopted in respect of Mr Neville Wran, the Premier of New South Wales and the President of the Australian Labor Party. I have no difficulty in repeating in this House what I have had to say before regarding Mr Neville Wran; that he does have my support.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members opposite say: 'Oh'. Yes, I have no problems in repeating my general support for Mr Neville Wran, the Premier--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest that those honourable members who are indulging in this particular display reflect on the seriousness of the parliamentary institution, not of their personal amusement.

—As distinct from those opposite, I will not engage, as they so unsuccessfully have over many weeks now, in the processes of smear, innuendo and guilt by association. One would have thought that by now the results of that tactic on their part would have penetrated even their slow learning minds, because the people of Australia will have no bar of this tactic.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —One would have thought that even those with slow learning minds would have come to the conclusion that the people of Australia will have no bar of this tactic of smear, innuendo and guilt by association.
—I raise a point of order. As I recollect the question, the Prime Minister was asked whether he supported the Premier of New South Wales--
—Order! The honourable member should come to his point of order.
—I am coming to that now. The Prime Minister is now talking about smear. I can only assume that when one mentions the Premier one talks in terms of smear.
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. I call the Prime Minister.

—I will not have any bar of that and, more importantly, of course, neither will the overwhelming majority of the people of Australia. In respect of the matter that has been raised-that is, the observations purported to have been made by Mr Wran-I have only seen those media reports, but I am quite sure that in any statements that he may have made Mr Wran would not have been intending any interference with the processes of the Senate. I repeat that: I do not believe that he would have intended any interference with the processes of the Senate. This matter is ultimately within the province of the Senate for its decision. Having said that, I repeat the more general point that in regard to Mr Wran, as far as I am concerned, I will not stand idly by while honourable members opposite try to drag him down by those processes of smear. There is not one piece of evidence that tackles the integrity of Mr Wran in respect of his administration of the state of New South Wales. There is not one piece of evidence and, while there is no evidence that goes to the integrity of Mr Wran, he will continue to have my support.

—My question is directed to the Special Minister of State and concerns the new legislation dealing with the disclosure of funds for Federal election campaigns. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the proposed debate in Wagga Wagga, for which television rights will be sold, involving the Leader of the Opposition, supporting the honourable member for Farrer, and the Leader of the National Party of Australia, supporting the honourable member for Hume, each comparing his and his protege's sincerity and honesty with that of the other coalition partner? Will the income from this television special have to be reported? Will the Minister also ensure that his colleague the Minister for Communications will look into this debate from the point of view of portraying current politics as soap opera, which is currently prohibited?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —In replying to the honourable member for Prospect let me say that this proposed debate between the honourable member for Farrer and the honourable member for Hume would hardly attract the audience that the Mondale-Reagan debate will probably get tonight. Nonetheless, now that the redistribution has been finished by the independent Australian Electoral Commission, much to the satisfaction of all members of the Parliament, including the honourable member for Denison and the honourable member for Forrest, who was very pleased with the outcome--
—I was not.

—And the honourable member for Casey. What the Australian people can be pleased about is that any political party or coalition of parties which now gets 50 per cent plus one per of the votes will become the government of Australia, and we will not have the unsavoury circumstances that existed over the past 20 years when the Liberal-Country Party managed to govern with a minority of votes. That will not happen again. Now that the redistribution has been concluded--
—Why do you not come out to Maranoa and find out what it is like there?

—The Cunnamulla kid! The honourable member did quite well out of the redistribution. We cannot do much out there, can we? There are a number of people in the Opposition with whom this Government does not want--
—There is a loyalty.
—How is David Combe feeling?
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting.

—It is an interesting day to talk about the loyalty of one person to another. How about the loyalty of the honourable member for Bennelong to the honourable member for Kooyong? There is a loyalty gap for you! If honourable members want to know why the honourable member for Bennelong put out a paper yesterday on flat rate tax, it was just to help Andrew in the election! Andrew will have to run around saying : 'We will not put a 30 per cent tax on'. The old submarine, the honourable member for Bennelong, is just trying to help his Leader along!
—Order! I remind the Leader of the House that one issue goes to answers at Question Time and that is the matter of relevance. I think the question is on election proceedings and not on the Budget.

—I can tell honourable members that if people are taking up a collection at this Wagga debate and the Leader of the National Party is there, they had better be careful about whom they pass the cheque to, because I know who will win that one. The election laws now provide that anybody making a donation of over $200 to a candidate or over $1,000 to a political party will have his name put on a register, and that name will be available for everybody in Australia to see and to understand the relationship between the donor and the political party. It is something that should have been adopted in Australia a long time ago, as it has been adopted in most Western democracies.

ANSWER.PARA: If people in Wagga Wagga make a donation of that size to a debate between the honourable member for Hume and the honourable member for Farrer-I very much doubt that they will; I could not see anyone paying 200 bucks for that-they will have to put their names in the register to comply with the laws now set out in the Commonwealth Electoral Act.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the Deputy Leader of the Opposition from moving forthwith the following motion:
That this House-

(1) condemns the intimidatory remarks of the Premier of New South Wales in relation to the evidence being given to the Senate Inquiry by Mr Clarrie Briese, the Chief Stipendiary Magistrate of New South Wales;

(2) notes with concern this further example of the Premier's increasingly irrational and improper conduct in relation to certain matters pertaining to the administration of justice in New South Wales, and

(3) expresses its concern at the implication for the administration of justice in New South Wales including those areas comprising federal jurisdiction of New South Wales courts federal from the Premier's conduct.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion in writing?
—The motion is in writing and is seconded by the honourable member for North Sydney.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Young) put:
That the honourable member be not further heard.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Mr Speaker. Last weekend the Premier of New South Wales directly, publicly--

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Young) put:
That the honourable member be not further heard.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The nature of this debate--

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Young) put:
That the question be now put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question put:
That the motion (Mr Howard's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to section 41 (4) of the Export Market Development Grants Act 1974 and section 20 (4) of the Export Expansion Grants Act 1978, I present the annual report of the Export Development Grants Board for 1983-84.

—For the information of honourable members, I present the report of the Trade Development Council Panel 75 on invisibles trade, together with the text of a statement relating to the report. Limited copies of the report are available and further copies will be made available to all honourable members when they become printed.
—Pursuant to section 21 of the Papua New Guinea (Staffing Assistance) Act 1973, I present the Papua New Guinea Superannuation Scheme annual report for 1983-84.
—For the information of the House, I present a report by the Commonwealth Schools Commission entitled ' Recommendations for 1985'.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCHOOLS COMMISSION COMMONWEALTH TERTIARY EDUCATION COMMISSION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of the House, I present a report by the Commonwealth Schools Commission for 1985-'Response to Government Guidelines'-and the report of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission for 1985-86 triennium Volume 2 Part 1-'Recommendations on Grants'-and Part 2-'Advice of Council'-together with the text of a statement by the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) relating to the reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Young) proposed:
That the House take note of the papers.
Debate (on motion by Mr Sinclair) adjourned.
Petitions
Petitions
Petitions
Petitions
Petitions
Petitions
Petitions
Petitions

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present the Commonwealth Fire Board annual report 1983-84.
—Pursuant to section 107 of the Repatriation Act 1920, I present the Repatriation Review Tribunal annual report 1983-84.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member seek to make a personal explanation on the ground that he has been personally misrepresented?
—Yes, Mr Speaker. I will be very brief.
—The honourable member may proceed.
—The Australian of 5 October stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Dr . . . Klugman . . . said truth and fairness in politics could be determined only by politicians.
I am afraid that I have not such a high and mighty view, not even of my colleagues. I draw honourable members' attention to page 1591 of Hansard of 4 October. I said:
Basically, we are recommending the repeal of the section, thus leaving the decision as to whether political advertising is true or false to the electors and to the law of defamation.
The article that appeared in the Australian may have appeared also in other newspapers in Australia because I understand it involved a mistake by Australian Associated Press.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I seek the leave of the House to table a document which purports to be the minutes of a meeting on 7 June 1984 between the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and representatives of the Australian Bank Employees Union and the Commonwealth Bank Officers Association.
—I am not in a position to approve the tabling at the moment. If the Deputy Leader of the Opposition shows them to the Treasurer, he will decide whether they can be tabled.
—I would be delighted with that.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
National Flag
To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. We are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia , namely:
The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses-represents the nation 's historical origin, and the source of its language and law.
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. We know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. We recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. We are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable house will: Propose and pass a motion that ''the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change.''
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt,Mr Drummond and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that:

We hail as a victory for the not-so-silent majority, the decision of the Hawke Federal Government to now conduct an inquiry into the effects of hard core pornography and violence upon people and especially children.
We view with deep concern, and deplore the decision of the Government, to allow the sale of this objectionable material to continue and become even more widespread during the period of the inquiry.
We request the Federal Government to immediately re-enact the previous laws which banned the entry into Australia and the sale of hard-core pornography and violence in video and publication form.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Donald Cameron,Mr Hunt and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federal Ship Painters and Dockers Union
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we are greatly concerned with the extent to which serious crime including murder, major drug financing and massive tax frauds have penetrated into the highest levels of Australian society as shown by the investigations of various Royal Commissioners and in particular by Mr Frank Costigan Q.C.

That we are concerned that the National Crime Authority has too many restrictions and possible lines of veto placed upon it for it to be an effective successor to the Costigan Enquiry and that this will allow major criminals to avoid prosecution.

And your petitioners humbly pray that the Federal Government negotiate urgently with the Victorian Government on the reactivation of the Costigan Commission and to extend its term to at least 31 March, 1985 and also to provide the Costigan Commission with whatever resources it may need to successfully conclude its investigations into organised crime in Australia. Further we believe that the issue of organised crime in Australia is so important that the Parliament should not be dissolved until at least the interim Costigan Report has been received and fully debated in both Houses of the Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Donald Cameron,Mr Ruddock and Mr Tuckey.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4 They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ''the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Fisher,Mr Hawker and Mr Macphee.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and its future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography and Entitlements of De Facto Spouses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives should disallow the new Customs and Objectionable Publications Ordinance, and reject the Remuneration Tribunal's travel entitlement to de facto wives of Parliamentarians and the ABC's Commissioners decision to allow the de facto and homosexual partners of ABC staff to travel at public expense, and that the Government should introduce laws to:
(1) Prevent the importation and sale of hard core pornography and grossly obscene publications,
(2) Register imported pornographic video tapes for non-commercial use with the Film Censorship Board and require the Censor to more appropriately reflect responsible community attitudes,

(3) Protect Australians and those who enter into de jure (legal) marriages, and their families, from exploitation and the encroachment of immoral regulations and Acts into the traditional and Christian forms of life.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Braithwaite and Mr Fisher.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should disallow the new Customs and Objectionable Publications Ordinance and that:
The Attorney-General enforce laws to prevent the importation and sale of hard- core pornography (e.g. X-rated videos) and publications which consistently incite the use of hard drugs;
The importation and sale of grossly obscene publications, including those associated with blasphemy be prevented;
Imported video tapes/discos for non-commercial use to be registered by the Films Censorship Board;
Censors more appropriately reflect responsible attitudes;
Further measures be taken in association with States to protect Australians, particularly women and children, from exploitation; and
That, because of the importance of this issue to society, a conscience vote be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Regulations and an Ordinance now before the Parliament amend the Customs ( Prohibited Imports) Regulations and the Customs (Cinematographic Films) Regulations and supersede the A.C.T. Objectionable Publications Ordinance in such a manner as to be harmful to society by removing from existing Commonwealth law:
The power to prevent the importation and sale of hard-core pornography (e.g. X- rated videos) and publications which consistently incite the use of hard drugs;
The power to prevent the importation and sale of grossly obscene publications, including those associated with blasphemy;
The power to require imported video tapes/discos for non-commercial use to be registered by the Films Censorship Board.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should disallow the new Regulations and Ordinance and ensure:
that the Attorney-General enforce existing laws;
that censors more appropriately reflect responsible community attitudes;
that further measures be taken in association with the States to protect Australians, particularly women and children, from exploitation; and
that, because of the importance of this issue to society, a conscience vote be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives should disallow the new Customs and Objectionable Publications Ordinance and that the Attorney-General should introduce laws to:
1. Prevent the importation and sale of hard-core pornography
2. Prevent the importation and sale of grossly obscene publications
3. Register imported pornographic video tapes for non-commercial use with the Film Censorship Board
4. Require the Censor to more appropriately reflect responsible community attitudes
5. Protect Australians, particularly women and children from exploitation; and
Your petitioners also request that, because of the importance of this issue to society, a conscience vote be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We assert that TAFE, with over 1 million students, requires greatly improved resources if it is to continue to train Australia's skilled workforce effectively.

2. We call upon the Commonwealth Government to provide greatly increased funds to ensure that TAFE is accessible to all Australians, unlike the present time when thousands of people are turned away from TAFE colleges each year.

3. We urge the Commonwealth Government to equip TAFE workshops with the advanced technology used in modern Australian industries, and to expand TAFE's capital works program so that sufficient quality accommodation is available for TAFE teachers and students.
4. We ask that the Commonwealth Government greatly increase TAFE's recurrent expenditure, so that TAFE can respond quickly and flexibly to industry, Government and community demands.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. The Federal Labor Government's retirement income policies are piecemeal, inconsistent and make no provision to encourage people to save towards their retirements; and
2. the Government's proposed assets test legislation is iniquitous and, if enacted, its effects would be discriminatory.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
1. Scrap its proposed assets test legislation;
2. either institute a broad enquiry into Australia's retirement income and taxation systems or await the outcome of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare's work on this matter; and,
3. following the report of such a wide enquiry institute a retirement income policy which is fair and equitable, that encourages self-provision and which will be non-discriminatory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth-
that the Australian flag reflects Australia's membership of the Commonwealth of Nations, her position in the southern hemisphere, and her federation of original colonies,
recognizes that the flag as a symbol of pride for most Australians, such that several organisations, including the ALP, incorporated the flag in their motifs.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government will resist moves to change the Australian flag, or if changes is contemplated that the question be put to the Australian people by referendum to seek their views.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Broadcasting and Television Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That because television and radio
(a) affect our social and moral environment,
(b) are family media watched and heard by many children by many children at all times, and
(c) present too much explicit violence and sex,
they therefore need stronger control than other media and the existing standards need stricter enforcement in both national A.B.C. and commercial sectors.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government will amend the Broadcasting and Television Act, in relation to both national and commercial broadcasters, to legislate
(a) for adequate and comprehensive programs in the best interests of the general public,
(b) for a ''Dual System of Regulation'' enforced by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal by internal regulation and external control,
(c) for an independent consumer body to represent the best interests of the general public, and
(d) for immediate and effective penalties to be imposed for breaches of program and advertising standards.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully shows:

That we, electors of the Commonwealth of Australia, view with extreme concern and express forthwith our complete abhorrence of the relaxation of the former Federal laws concerning censorship classifications to allow publication and importation of hardcore pornography. Therefore we, the undersigned, do fervently request the Federal Government to repeal the ''A.C.T. Classification of Publications Ordinances'' as they effect publications and videos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully requests the Government to introduce laws to:
(1) Prevent the importation and sale of hard core pornography and grossly obscene publications,
(2) Register imported pornographic video tapes for non-commercial use with the Film Censorship Board and require the Censor to more appropriately reflect responsible community attitudes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Army: Taree Open Cadet Unit
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, and in particular the citizens of the Manning Valley, respectfully showeth:

That we, the loyal citizens of Australia and in particular the citizens of the Manning Valley, firmly express our strong opposition to the classification of the Taree Open Cadet Unit as a unit to receive limited support only under the restructured Army Cadet Scheme.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that; The Minister for Defence direct the Australian Army to re-classify the Taree Open Cadet Unit as an open, community-based, regional cadet unit (R.C.U.).
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Brisbane Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully show:

That the potential noise hazard to residents of Sandgate, Shorncliffe, Brighton and Nudgee Beach (including 4,000 aged people), will become intolerable when the new Brisbane Airport is operative in 1987, if protective action is not taken.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Federal Government will, when the redeveloped Brisbane Airport becomes operative, make sure that; A curfew is retained on both runways when the new airport is commissioned in 1984.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Senate Committee on the Effects of Pornography on children
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled.

We the undersigned, plead that the Houses of Representatives will vote in favour of the Senate resolution calling for the appointment of a Select Joint Committee to examine the effects upon children of viewing pornography, violent and obscene video material, because not all parents are supervising all children all of the time, and not all video outlets are impoverishing themselves by compliance with the law. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest consideration, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Dr Rex Hood
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: This Petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
That the penalties of a fine and three years suspension from Medicare imposed on Dr Rex Hood of Pingelly are out of all proportion to his offences;
That neither Medicare nor Dr Hood's patients were put to increased expense by his unlawful acts;
That the court action, administrative action and Medical Board inquiry in respect of the same acts constitute a form of triple jeopardy repugnant to the traditions of our legal system; and
That the interests of the people of Pingelly were not considered.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Minister for Health rescind the suspension of Dr Hood;
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: This Petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
That the legislation and regulations associated with Medicare are repugnant to natural justice and humane medical practice, and more appropriate to a police state than to Australia;
That the said legislation and regulations are being administered so as to oppress and demoralise the medical profession, and without regard to the interests of the sick;
That altogether disproportionate penalities are being imposed, through administrative action, on medical practitioners for minor infringements of the Medicare rules; and
That, unless reforms are instituted, the quality of Australia's health care system will decline.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government legislate to make possible in Australia a health care system in which efficiency and innovation are not repressed, and humane medical practice is again possible without harassment.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Self-Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: that in November 1978 more than sixty two per cent of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory in a Referendum rejected the introduction of Territorial Government of Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory. That until the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission Inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances have been made public and there has been a Referendum of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory as to their attitude to Territorial or Local Government.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that that Government take no further action nor legislate in respect of Territorial or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:

1. They call on the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to reject the recommendations of the Commonwealth Schools Commission contained in 'Funding Policies for Australian Schools', concerning proposed increases in State aid to private schools and the proposed community standard for education funding.

2. They call on the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to declare a three year moratorium (1985-1987) on increases in State aid to private schools and on grants for new private schools and for increased private school enrolments.

3. They call on the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to re-affirm their primary obligation to government schools and to implement all 1983 ALP election promises for increased funding to government schools.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Import and Sale of X-Rated Video Films
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain members of the Parish of St. Francis Xavier, West Mackay, Queensland, electors of the Division of Dawson, shows that legislation is to be introduced allowing the import and sale of X-rated video films.
Your petitioners therefore pray that such legislation be withdrawn.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of certain elected representatives and officers of Local Authorities in Australia shows considerable concern that the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program levy, at 2 cents per litre on petrol and diesel, was indexed in the 1984 budget, but that funds raised from indexation of the levy will go into consolidated revenue, and not specifically into expenditure on road funds.
It has been estimated that indexation of the levy will raise $491 million over the next six years to 1988/89, of which Local Government could have expected to receive $58 million.
This is a further denial of funds to Local Government, following $13 million lost this year from Personal Income Tax Sharing entitlements.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will amend the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Act, such that funds raised through indexation of the levy will be placed in the Trust Fund, and used for much needed road construction work.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of certain citizens of Queensland, Australia, respectfully showeth that we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: JUDICIAL AND STATUTORY OFFICERS (REMUNERATION AND ALLOWANCES) BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the Senate returning the Judicial and Statutory Officers (Remuneration and Allowances) Bill and acquainting the House that the Senate has agreed to the Bill as amended by the House of Representatives at the request of the Senate.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to act in accordance with the national interest to ensure the future of the U.S. Alliance and particularly ANZUS.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, the Opposition's matter of public importance reflects the growing public concern and disquiet over the drift of our foreign policy away from the United States of America as a result of the continuing factionalism within the Government. Let me remind the Government that the conduct of foreign policy determines the nation's long term destiny. That is why it is important for a government to pursue a coherent foreign policy with clearly defined objectives. Nothing is more harmful to Australia's security than to be lurching from one piecemeal policy to another -policies which owe their genesis more to internal party considerations, in the case of the Australian Labor Party, than to a rational assessment of Australia's national interest. It is this irresponsible approach to foreign policy and the United States relationship which has characterised this Government's foreign policy.

SPEECH.PARA: What is particularly disturbing is the Government's attitude towards ANZUS. In this area it has oscillated between policies of benign neglect on the part of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and active malevolence towards the United States on the part of many in the Labor Caucus and indeed in the Ministry. It is increasingly clear that the Prime Minister's rhetoric on ANZUS and the United States relationship is not supported by the Government in its actions. Both the Prime Minister and indeed the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) have refused to intervene in New Zealand's dispute with the United States Government over New Zealand's refusal to grant access to United States ships to New Zealand ports. Furthermore, this Government has shown no sign of registering Australian concerns about New Zealand's refusal to take part in joint exercises where nuclear powered or armed units are involved.

These incidents strike at the very heart of ANZUS. The governmental inertia is typified by the Foreign Minister's latest comments that he would 'not be an errand boy for the United States'. No one would want or expect Australia's Foreign Minister to be anyone's errand boy, although incidentally, that is what he trumpeted when he went to Moscow recently. However, we would expect him to address a matter of such vital importance as this and act to ensure Australia's national interest.

The United States Secretary of State has pointed out that if New Zealand wishes to share in the benefits of ANZUS, which Mr Lange says he does, then that country must assume its obligations.
