It has been made abundantly clear that, if the ships of one alliance partner are effectively prohibited from the ports of another, then that alliance will be reduced to a hollow shell. This goes to the heart of Australia's security. Yet, when the United States requests Australia to use its influence on the fraternal Labour Government in New Zealand on this issue, something which we should have been doing assiduously anyway, the Foreign Minister gratuitously insults the United States.

What of the Prime Minister? Does he show any signs of recognising the seriousness of the problem? No, he does not. He acts as if the problem either will go away or does not exist. He is either out of touch with the realities of the situation, the seriousness of which has now been made crystal clear by both the New Zealand and American governments, or he feels constrained by the internal divisions within his own Party from acting to shore up the ANZUS alliance; nor is there any indication that the Australian Government is preparing the groundwork for bilateral discussions with the United States over ways of preserving the ANZUS framework. Such matters require careful and painstaking consideration. They cannot simply be dropped into place. Yet the Government gives every appearance of doing nothing, either because it is too difficult factionally, or because it might upset New Zealand. The benign neglect , which typifies the response of the Prime Minister and the Government towards ANZUS, is deserving of condemnation on its own. However, on top of this is a consistent pattern of Labor Government actions which have resulted in a weakening of our defence relationship with the United States and its ability to project itself into our region at a time of significant increases in Soviet deployment.

Let me detail briefly some of these actions. We have the Prime Minister's own commitment to a concept of a South Pacific nuclear free zone. Rather than showing leadership at the South Pacific Forum and emphasising the importance of the United States presence in our region, the Prime Minister opted for a shoddy compromise which, whilst it might appease the left wing of his Party, only adds uncertainty about the future role of the United States in our region. Whatever the Government may say about ensuring that the nuclear free zone will not exclude the transit of nuclear powered or nuclear armed vessels, there is no doubt that this proposal is the thin end of the wedge. It is perceived as such, of course, by Mr Lange, who regards it as a satisfactory first step. This concept, which is about the only centrepiece of the Prime Minister's foreign policy, will be very difficult to keep the lid on. The Government is promoting an initiative in the region which has the potential to place serious obstacles in the way of ANZUS and the United States security effort.

This Government is not content to compromise our security interests solely in the Pacific. It is also actively encouraging regional disarmament initiatives in the Indian Ocean. The Indian Ocean is, of course, an increasingly vital part of the world. The Soviet Union has a strategic advantage over the United States in this region through its geographic proximity to the area. Furthermore, new bases in Afghanistan and the southern parts of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics , coupled with ready access to airfields in Ethiopia and South Yemen, have considerably increased this advantage. The difficulties the United States has just in supporting a peacetime deterrent makes this a hazardous enough task on its own. Even with the continued use of the bases in the Philippines and the absence of a threat to the Straits of Malacca choke point, the Western Australian home port facilities are crucial. Yet we have the Government's involvement in the Indian Ocean zone of peace concept.

Even more disturbing was the acceptance of the Thomas amendment at the last Australian Labor Party Federal conference. This amendment called for restrictions on the pattern and frequency of United States naval visits. It also called for all development work on naval installations in Western Australia to be related solely to the needs of the Royal Australian Navy and not to the requirements of any other navy. Ipso facto, we are to take no notice of commonsense requirements for compatibility of our naval facilities with those of our major allies because only the RAN is to use the facilities and all development work on those naval installations is to be related solely to the RAN and not to our major allies. To make matters worse, the Hawke Government has established a working party of the left wing controlled Western Australian ALP to recommend how the new ALP policy on United States naval visits will be applied.

The Government's actions are not confined to the oceans and coastlines of Australia. On 6 June the Prime Minister made a typically sanctimonious speech on the United States joint facilities in which he reiterated the Government's commitment to the joint facilities and the Western alliance. Shortly after this speech, the Foreign Minister took a contrary view. On 7 August in Geneva and earlier on 29 July in Brisbane, in a little reported but important speech which exposed his thinking on this matter, the contrary view was there. The Foreign Minister spelt out very clearly two things about his conduct of the Australian- United States relationship: First, that, should the joint facilities develop a role in first strike capability, they should be closed; second, that, if Australia felt that the United States did not have a genuine commitment to the disarmament process, then Australia would have to re-assess its policies and attitudes to the United States bases. We believe that the Foreign Minister's views are patent nonsense. What does he mean by a first strike capacity? What does he mean by a genuine commitment to the disarmament process in the face of Soviet intransigence? The Foreign Minister has not yet explained his benchmarks for a decision that the United States must get out of Australia. Equally extraordinarily, the Prime Minister has not repudiated the contradictory statements of his Foreign Minister. He merely described the remarks as hypothetical. There is nothing hypothetical about the Foreign Minister's remarks , and they constitute a very real threat to our relationship with the United States. Moreover, the Foreign Minister's pursuit of disarmament matters will continue to collide with the legitimate security concerns of the United States in the face of the massive Soviet weapons build-up.

Whilst the coalition disagrees with the distorted prism through which the Foreign Minister views the nuclear debate, it acknowledges that his statements are calculated and well thought out. That is somewhat different from those of the Prime Minister who, in the field of foreign policy particularly, has no consistency of view. While he pays lip service to ANZUS now, neither the coalition nor the Australian people will forget his signing in 1976 of a call for 'an independent and non-aligned Australia'.

TALK.START.PARA: —And several of his colleagues.

—Yes, and several of his colleagues. What are our allies to make of this foreign affairs zig and zag show? What faith can they place in a government that has two spokesmen on foreign affairs issuing conflicting statements on strategic matters-matters which go to the heart of our security, to the root of our relationship with the United States?

SPEECH.PARA: There should be no need to remind the House of the importance of ANZUS to Australia. I dare say that, if one asked any number of people passing this building today or in any centre or small town of Australia, the overwhelming majority would reaffirm their commitment to the ANZUS Treaty. We have had this commitment in Australia since 1951, and from our side of politics it is a commitment which has been unequivocal. In three important respects it is the cornerstone of our strategic security. First, it offers the ultimate guarantee to our security should a direct threat to Australia eventuate.

Second, it is a necessary instrument for maintaining the global strategic balance and in this respect ensures a measure of stability in international affairs. Third, it is a force for stability within the Asian-Pacific region and has assisted, by underpinning the framework of stability, the dynamic economic growth of the region. Moreover, it is our only direct and formal link to the network of alliances which collectively form the Western alliance.

The coalition's attitude is marked by its clarity. This is in sharp contrast with that of the present Government. The coalition's acceptance of the Western alliance and ANZUS is based on a realistic calculation of the benefits and, of course, the risks. There are always both in an alliance of this nature. There are, in fact, few alliances like the ANZUS alliance in the world. Why it even has to be called into question when the benefits, so far as Australia is concerned, far outweigh the risks and when the benefits flow to Australia in far greater proportion than they do to the United States can be answered only by the Government.

The calling into question and the refusal to take the New Zealand Government on on a matter that strikes at the heart of our security arrangements renders this Government open to the strongest criticism and condemnation. Of course, the ANZUS Treaty does not guarantee in absolute terms that any party will do anything other than consult. What happens in any situation will depend on a range of factors. Included in this will be the status of the defence and strategic relationships between us. That is why Australia has worked hard at consolidating the American relationship over the years. Any American attitude will be dependent on the standing of the Australia-America relationship in economic, political and defence terms. It is this structure, represented by ANZUS, which has been placed in jeopardy by the actions, indeed inactions as well, of this Government. It is in danger of being reduced to a hollow shell. This Government, by placing its own factional interests ahead of the national interest, is contributing to the destruction of a relationship which has been nurtured carefully over three decades.

We cannot accept that the Government is constrained by its own factions from trying to influence the New Zealand Government. We cannot accept that the Government is constrained by its own factions from laying the groundwork for negotiation of a bilateral treaty because, by spelling out the treaty relationship with the United States, it will open a real hornet's nest in its own Party. We cannot accept that this Government's inertia towards the United States alliance and its active pursuit of policies which threaten that alliance could be anything other than contrary to Australia's national interest.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) was fascinating for what it failed to say after promising so much. What he accused the Government of failing to do was, using his words, 'take the New Zealand Government on'. I am not quite clear what he had in mind when he said 'take the New Zealand Government on'. I do not know whether he proposes some sort of political bovver boy tactic of steel cap boots being used to kick people's shins, whether some sort of fierce public denunciation should take place or whatever. One tends to divine that his inclination is that it has to be passionate, tough and very aggressive, but he did not outline what he had in mind. He did not explain to the House and the public what he believed the alternative course of conduct should be. Therefore, I find his whole purpose something of a mystery. What exactly is it that we have been doing, as distinct from the things he has synthetically presented here and claims we have not been doing, that is not satisfactory and in what way should it be altered?

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing I have to point out to him is that what we have done-our approach to this rather difficult situation obviously causes us preoccupation and some concern-has been to address ourselves to this issue as subtly as we can with the hope that there will be some positive output at the end. If the Leader of the Opposition has reservations about that let me remind him that the tactic we are adopting in this is exactly that which has been adopted by the United States. In both cases we have adopted this common approach to the situation because we believe, in all of the circumstances, that if anything is to prove productive in the difficulties which have now arisen this is the most likely course of conduct to bring about that sort of result.

The week before last in New York I spoke with the Secretary of State for the United States, Mr George Shultz, and the day before, on the Wednesday, I spoke with the Prime Minister of New Zealand, Mr Lange, on this matter. All agree that the approach which we are adopting, which all of us very largely are adopting, is the most appropriate tactic to develop in these circumstances. Therefore, I say to the Leader of the Opposition: What exactly is it that he finds wrong, and not just with our approach? What is it that he criticises in the approach of the United States? What is it in the tactic which is being adopted by the Secretary of State, Mr Shultz, that he objects to and wishes to condemn? The honourable member presented a display of professed fealty to the alliance and particular affection towards the United States. I seek to score off none of those points. I merely say that he sought to portray those qualities in what we had to say. Yet if he takes logically the implications of the criticisms he has put forward, he is rather vigorously attacking, criticising, the United States Administration and the way in which the Secretary of State for the United States, Mr George Shultz, is conducting the US Administration's response to this situation.

There are a number, not just one or two but several, misstatements-I will be kind enough to restrict my description of them to that-in what the Leader of the Opposition has said. He said that, when the United States requests the Australian Labor Government to use its influence on its fraternal Labour Party colleague and Government in New Zealand, it refuses to do so. He said that we have repudiated the United States when it has requested us to use our influence on our fraternal colleagues in New Zealand. The fact is that the United States has not sought that. It has not asked it, implied it or made such an approach in any way. In all of our discussions we have agreed that the sort of approach being adopted consistently since the Labour Government came into power in New Zealand, the approach common to the United States Administration and common to us, is the best one to adopt.

I remind the Leader of the Opposition of what the Secretary of State said at the conclusion of the thirty-third ANZUS Council Meeting in Wellington, New Zealand, on 17 July 1984. At the Press conference in which the New Zealand representative, Mr Cooper, the retiring Foreign Minister of that country, and I also participated, the question was asked of Mr Shultz:
Mr Shultz, if the Labour Party does carry out its policy in banning visits of nuclear ships here, will it be the end of ANZUS?
Mr Shultz replied:

Well, we will have to see what happens and I think it's better to stay away from 'iffy' questions, to state our positions clearly and to work with the new Government and see if we can't resolve the problems satisfactorily.

That line is a line which has been pursued consistently by the United States Administration. That approach is the approach that we have undeviatingly followed ourselves. I agree with what George Shultz said:
. . . I think it's better to stay away from 'iffy' questions . . .
It is better to state our position clearly and positively, and to try to work for a satisfactory outcome of this problem.

That is what we have been doing. That is what the United States has been doing. That is not what the Opposition has been doing or is doing on this occasion. What the Opposition is doing is seeking to inflame this particularly difficult situation. If the Opposition had a genuine concern for the alliance, the ANZUS Treaty, and if it were even partly, fractionally, as committed to it as it claims to be, it would not be trying to aggravate this situation at present.

The Leader of the Opposition, from his distinguished service to this country of nearly half a decade as Foreign Minister of Australia, should recall that there are certain situations in foreign relations in which it is best to take a more subtle and low key approach when difficulties arise, and this is one such occasion. That is why there has been no deviation by either the United States or Australia on this issue.

The Prime Minister of New Zealand has been fairly consistent in statements he has made in which he quite explicitly has declared that New Zealand wishes to remain in ANZUS. New Zealand has a dispute on one aspect of the relationship. That is a dispute to which the United States, Australia and New Zealand have been addressing themselves in a succession of discussions which have been taking place, and no doubt there will be more. Mr Lange has repeatedly said that New Zealand wishes to stay in the alliance. As recently as the 25th of last month, at the General Assembly of the United Nations, he said:

That membership is formally expressed in a security treaty with the United States and Australia which, for 33 years, has been a central feature of the foreign and defence policies of successive New Zealand Governments, including my own.

He has repeatedly declared the keenness of the New Zealand Labour Government to remain within ANZUS. There is a problem; there is no disputing that. It has been addressed with a great deal of care, caution and, of course, some concern by the respective parties. That difficulty is not helped in any way at all by the flagrant way in which the Opposition is seeking to open up fissures and to make the processes more difficult not just for the Government of this country but also for the Administration of the United States as well as for the responsible people in the Government in New Zealand. This is a completely unhelpful approach on the part of the Leader of the Opposition. An editorial in the Australian of 31 August stated:
However, individual countries themselves will determine whether nuclear-powered and nuclear-armed ships and planes may visit their ports, and what transit rights they will enjoy.
This means that the operation of the ANZUS treaty is not adversely affected at all by the nuclear-free zone.

The nuclear free zone is another matter which the Leader of the Opposition raised and to which I want to address myself now. I have a minute which contains an extract of a statement of 28 August from the United States State Department. It was provided by my Department and I am happy to show it to the Leader of the Opposition and his foreign affairs spokesman. It states:
The Australians, who originated the proposal-
that is, the proposal for the nuclear free zone in the South Pacific-
have taken particular care to assure it would not affect the ANZUS (Australia, New Zealand, United States Treaty) relationship, the Department pointed out.

There must be something wrong when the Opposition is constantly telling us how the Labor Government of Australia is impairing in one way or another the important ANZUS relationship and the Americans are constantly saying that that is not so. We think the relationship is in as strong a condition as it has ever been if not in a healthier condition than it has ever been at any time in the past.

So the South Pacific nuclear free zone proposal put forward by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at the recent South Pacific Forum Conference is not, as the Leader of the Opposition described it, 'a shoddy proposal'. That is the term he used. It is a proposal which is understood by our friends and allies and at the same time is a concrete demonstration of our concern to put in place things which show beyond any doubt the genuineness of our credentials in regard to the issues of nuclear arms control and disarmament. I repeat that it is something which has widespread support in the South Pacific.

Let me move on from that serious misstatement. The Leader of the Opposition has said that New Zealand has refused to take part in exercises involving nuclear powered and nuclear armed ships. That is not my understanding of the situation. My recollection, which may be a little hazy at the edges, is that at least one spokesman for the New Zealand Government is on record as saying that the restrictions in respect of the use of port facilities will not be an impediment to participation in exercises. However, I have had a check carried out and have had a note sent in to me since the Leader of the Opposition made that statement, and the note states:
N.Z. Government has not said it will not participate in exercises involving nuclear powered and nuclear armed ships of U.S.

So we find that the case put forward by the Leader of the Opposition is not just designed to apply more undesirable tension, pressure and divisiveness in this rather delicate area but is based on a succession of misstatements from a man who, I repeat, in my view was a distinguished representative of this country as its Foreign Minister for half a decade and therefore should know better. He should be able to check his facts. The staff he has available to him is highly qualified, able and dedicated. These things should have been checked before they were said.

The next matter he attacked us on concerned the Indian Ocean zone of peace. The Leader of the Opposition, in a statement entitled 'An Australian Dilemma: Defence and Diplomacy in the Indian Ocean' to a conference held by the Australian Institute of International Affairs and the United Services Institute at the Joint Services Staff College in Canberra in 1976, referred to the Indian Ocean zone of peace as a noble ideal. He said:
We have said that it-
the Indian Ocean zone of peace-

represents a 'noble ideal'. In saying this we are conscious, however, that it is a concept which can influence the conduct of the Super Powers. It would in practice complement the objectives which we believe can be achieved through balance.

He refers to the concept as a noble ideal, and so do we. We also acknowledge the very large difficulties involved in getting it into place, but we are trying. This Government is a member of the same ad hoc committee in which we are trying to do that as was the honourable member's Government in the past. So that is another nonsense. One wonders what the motivation was for bringing this sort of matter forward.

The Leader of the Opposition referred to the issue of arms control and the joint facilities. That has been responded to before. I have made it clear, as has the Prime Minister, that my comments were hypothetical comments which would apply perhaps in certain circumstances. After all, reference to such a subject is hypothetical but scarcely relevant to the case he has been trying to make.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has raised this matter of public importance simply because it and the Australian community are becoming very restive about the developing crisis over ANZUS. We all know that the Government has a credibility problem which has been raised by off-the-cuff statements, particularly by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden).

SPEECH.PARA: I refer in particular to his recent comment in the United States of America when he said:
Australia is not 'an errand boy' for the United States.

One can understand what he has in mind when he said this. But his capacity for the unhappy phrase does not allow people to give credit to his concern that Australia should not exacerbate the sensitivity of the issue, and we acknowledge the sensitivity of the issue. Equally unfortunate is the policy of threatening to expel the joint facilities in central Australia if there were not better progress on disarmament. These remarks have not encouraged people to believe he will do his best to save ANZUS. The fact is that the Government, on the issue of international security, has lost a great deal of credibility, because of the unhappy knack the Foreign Minister has of making or seeming to make the United States a scapegoat. This is clearly implied in his recent statement on behalf of the Australian Government to the United Nations. When he refers to joint facilities in the United Nations in a context which suggests Australian patience with the United States is becoming exhausted-I am using his own words-he is defeating his own purposes. He is sending a signal, whether deliberately or unintentionally, to the Soviet Union, that all it has to do to get the United States out of Australia is to maintain an attitude of intransigence towards the verification problems which bedevil progress on arms control.

It may be the view of this Australian Government to tell the assembled nations that Australia will expel the United States if there is not progress on disarmament. But it certainly is not the view of the people of Australia and it certainly is not the view of the Opposition.

We know too that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has a credibility problem within his Party on such issues because he simply does not have the numbers in Caucus. He knows, and the Press Gallery knows, that the presence of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) in Cabinet creates a situation which puts the Prime Minister on the defensive. So the Prime Minister is practically silent on ANZUS. Today the Minister for Foreign Affairs has made the charge again that the Opposition is seeking to inflame the situation. The Opposition is certainly not seeking to inflame the situation. The fact is that we have a duty to ourselves to say what we think this alliance is all about.

We have a duty to Australia to prevent what someone has described as the New Zealandisation of Australia. We do not have to be afraid of becoming an errand boy for the United States in order to remind Australians of the significance of ANZUS against the assault on Australian public opinion mounted from New Zealand, in concert with the Australian Democrats. We have been visited by the keepers of the New Zealand conscience, including the New Zealand Labor Party strong man Mr Anderton. They have not been keeping their counsel on this matter, and have been very deliberately concerting an attack on Australian public opinion. So the time has come to tell New Zealand that this assault on our interests simply has to stop. Even the Pacific Trade Union Forum was hauled into action by the New Zealand Federation of Labour. Jim Knox announced at the conference that New Zealand is to scrap ANZUS. He said:
We want to see the Pact destroyed.

That is the view of the New Zealand Federation of Labour. In this House, the acting Foreign Minister spoke in some ambiguous defence of this idiocy. The acting Foreign Minister took a benevolent view of the developments at the Forum his interest in ANZUS was obviously not very compelling. Mr Lange is upon us, he seemed to say, because New Zealand has a public opinion which has been influenced by the peace movement.

Let us look at some of the brainwashing coming from across the Tasman. It is said that ANZUS was signed to reassure us against the Japanese and that, in view of the fact that the Japanese are upgrading their self defence program because of American interest, ANZUS is invalidated. This somewhat tortuous concept was enunciated by the new New Zealand Ambassador to the United States. I have news for this gentleman. The ANZUS treaty was put in place after Communist North Korea invaded South Korea, thereby producing a direct threat to Japan. Sir Richard Casey wrote in 1954:
Well before the ANZUS Treaty was drafted, the spokesman of the Australian Government identified the immediate menace in the Pacific not as Japan but as communist imperialism.

The critics who want to knock ANZUS then say it is a treaty to consult. This is simply not true. It is a treaty which obliges partners to consult if they consider that there is a threat developing. This is a sensible clause and it is in the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation provisions. But the crucial clause obliges ANZUS partners to act to meet the common danger of armed attack according to the respective constitutional processes. The New Zealand debate hardly ever mentions this clause. It is not in the peace movement's manual either. So New Zealand public opinion has been led by the nose by those who discount the contemporary relevance and power of ANZUS.

The Foreign Minister asks what the Government should do and what has it been doing wrong. I will tell the Foreign Minister what the Government should do. The Government should be much more vocal in contradicting this nonsense threatening ANZUS as it gets repeated time and again by those badgers of the Australian media-the talk-back, talk-fast and think-slick talk-back radio commentators. The Government has the resources to bring about an understanding of the part played constructively and sensibly by the interlocking system of Western security of which the United States is central and ANZUS is a part. As a distinguished Australian serviceman said recently:
'Our national task is to prevent war'.

This is done by developing a system of security which is adequate to deter war. We have, in the Pacific region, been sorely tried. The Korean War of 1950 threatened to deliver the Korean people entirely into communist hands, and this would have put Japan under enormous pressure. Today South Korea and Japan are great economic pace-setters and our economic future lies in the complementary industrial might and commercial strength of these great economies. Where would they be without the security support of the United States?

We hear a lot about the negative factors in the Vietnam War. But during the time the issues were being contested there, the remaining nations-the members of the Association of South East Asian Nations-developed their nationalism, rejected communism and drew themselves together into a most viable international community-ASEAN. Their governments, too, have an acute concept of the need for stabilising measures that proceeds only from a system of collective security.

Thailand, a key state in the region, is linked through the Manila Treaty with the United States. The Philippines has a treaty relationship. Australia, Britain and New Zealand have a defence arrangement with Malaysia and Singapore. The ASEAN region is of great economic importance to Australia. Its stability is fundamental. Its stability has been greatly enhanced by the knowledge that Australia and New Zealand in the past have worked closely with the United States to maintain the Pacific as a stable force in world affairs. Now this manic obsession in New Zealand with the nuclear question is attempting to derail the benefits which come to the region. It needs no futurologist to tell any one of us that the security of New Zealand or Australia is not under immediate threat. It is an important factor in our mutual benefits from ANZUS. But there is no immediate contingency of threat.

But we are nothing if the United States fails in the magnificent task of continuing to ensure the stability of the Pacific which rests on the interlocking system of alliances sponsored by the United States. We live in the fastest growing economic region of the world. But that situation will not remain , and our prosperity and New Zealand's will not remain if the system of security which lies behind it is up-ended. The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is, as we know, enhancing its capacity to be more militarily dominant in the region. At this time we find New Zealand policy disabling the United States and discounting the great contribution that that nation and its people make to human betterment.

I believe that the whole argument for collective security has two sides. In one dimension, by preventing war, by deterring any temptation to resort to military conflict, we strengthen peace, we strengthen stability and we strengthen economic progress. But we also have the opportunity, through our association with our ally, the United States, to be involved in the East-West dialogue, which holds a major key to our ultimate destiny.

We ought to realise, understand and state publicly and clearly to the Australian people the benefits which flow to this country from a continuation and a strengthening of the relationship between our two countries which underpins that security and that economic progress which we always look forward to.

In the final analysis, if the New Zealand attitude forces New Zealand into a position which invalidates its membership of ANZUS, and the reputation of that alliance, Australia should make its own bilateral arrangements with the United States. This is too important a matter to allow public opinion to drift, to allow a wedge to be forced between the Foreign Minister and the Prime Minister. It is a matter which is basic to the very security and future prosperity of this nation. All of the people must be told of the benefits and modern relevance of the ANZUS Treaty. We must not allow the argument to go by default; the Government is allowing just that course.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suspect that there can be no surer sign of an approaching election than this tired old tactic of the Opposition of trotting out a debate on ANZUS. Those of us who have been around for some time know that one can lay 6 to 4 on that, about three or four weeks before an election date, out will come ANZUS. That very practice is an effort to demean the relationship between Australia and the United States of America. It is not a relationship, as the Opposition seeks to imply, between the Liberal Party of Australia and the United States. But in desperation this time the Opposition has sought to blame the Hawke Government for what the Opposition sees as the shortcomings, not of the Australian Government-although we are debating this matter in the Australian Parliament-but of the New Zealand Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us be very clear on one matter-the Hawke Government's position on ANZUS. About this time last year, or just a little earlier-on 15 September 1983-the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) brought down a review of ANZUS. I quote what the Minister, on behalf of the Hawke Government, said about ANZUS:

The Government has completed its review of the ANZUS Treaty, first as a national act and then in association with Australia's alliance partners. The review has led us to a firm and unequivocal reaffirmation of the alliance as fundamental to Australia's national security and foreign and defence policies.
A little further on the Minister said:

. . . although the Treaty was drawn up a generation ago, and in very different circumstances, we have reached the conclusion that the commitments and obligations that were accepted then remain as valid and appropriate today. The Treaty has the full support of this Government . . .

I make those points very clear because in the argumentation that has flowed from the speeches of both the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) and the shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs, the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) , there is an effort to contest those propositions that have been unequivocally stated by the Government. That speech on the review of ANZUS was in response to a paper presented by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence dealing with ANZUS. Because this report was agreed to by Liberal Party members, I want to quote a section from it which is very pertinent to the considerations we are facing today on a matter of difference between alliance partners. On page 88, the report says:

The Committee has stressed several times in this report that there is inevitably an asymmetry of interests and needs between Australia and New Zealand , the 'junior partners' in the ANZUS Alliance, and the United States, the ' senior partner'. Australia (as does New Zealand) frequently has quite different foreign policy preoccupations from those of its ally. So far, although Australia and the United States have had reasons to be annoyed with one another, the relationship has endured such 'family quarrels'.
A little further on, on page 91, it says:
The Committee believes that differences between Australia and the United States -
we can put New Zealand in there-

will continue to exist and will be appropriate on some issues. On the basis of past example, however, the management of these differences is likely to be conducted in an atmosphere which, on balance, favours accommodation.

The Opposition, as shown by the statements made today and in a Press release from the Leader of the Opposition yesterday, is not prepared to allow quiet and diplomatic discussions to arrive at that sort of accommodation referred to in the Joint Committee's report. In fact, the argumentation produced today encourages the collapse of ANZUS by excluding New Zealand. The Opposition spokesman for foreign affairs said we should make it on our own and have bilateral arrangements with the United States. So members of the Opposition want not to go through the process of accommodation, taking into account different points of view, but propose that we dismantle ANZUS by excluding New Zealand. That is the very simple proposition that they have put forward. They seek, by the proposition they have put forward today and by the statement made last night by the Leader of the Opposition, to undermine ANZUS, to exclude New Zealand, and are not prepared to adopt the practice that the United States is adopting, of quiet diplomacy to accommodate differences of opinion within ANZUS. So they are seeking to abandon New Zealand; they are seeking to dismantle the ANZUS alliance . That is the proposition they have put forward today.

The Leader of the Opposition, in his speech today and in last night's Press release, talks about pandering to left wing initiatives. Some of the observations-I am glad to hear such observations from the Opposition-refer to the Indian Ocean. I read a quotation from a statement made in September 1980:

. . . great power military presence in the Indian Ocean has increased and that there has been a deterioration of peace and security in the Indian Ocean area. They further noted with regret that recent events in the region, together with the worsening international situation, have caused a further build-up of great power military presence. While regretting the suspension of the bilateral talks on arms limitation in the Indian Ocean between the Soviet Union and the United States and reaffirming their commitment to the ultimate establishment of a zone of peace in the Indian Ocean in accordance with the 1971 UN declaration, they called upon the great powers to take active and effective steps to remove existing sources of tension in the area.

That is not a statement by a left wing organisation; it is a statement made by the Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting in New Delhi in September 1980 signed by Prime Minister Fraser. So here we have a proposition that members of the Opposition now attack, saying a zone of peace in the Indian Ocean is a left wing idea. That concept has been basic to Australia. Since 1972 successive Australian governments have consistently voted in the United Nations for resolutions on the Indian Ocean zone of peace. Incorporated in that voting pattern are statements by the present Opposition when it was in government from 1976 onwards.

There is also a reference in the statements made by the Leader of the Opposition to the notion of self-reliance and defence. It is an important and basic part of our approach to the ANZUS alliance that Australia will undertake responsibilities in its own area and ensure that our forces are adequate to carry out those responsibilities. Regrettably, last night the Leader of the Opposition stated that there had been a serious rundown of our defence forces.

Once again I want to sheet home the guilt and responsibility for the rundown of the defence forces. Mr Deputy Speaker, I know you have heard this before but it seems people on your side have very short memories. I refer to the statement made by the Liberal Party's Minister for Defence on 29 April 1982. I repeat some of the statements from that announcement that he made. He said that the Government-the Liberal Party-would not at that stage proceed with the acquisition of an additional five Fremantle class patrol boats or the second underway replenishment ship. He said that the Government would cut back on the follow-on destroyers and would delay lower priority facilities and infrastructure development. He said there would be a reduction in program costs for expenditure, and planned fuel and other stockholding levels would also be reduced.

The men guilty for any rundown of the Australian defence forces sit opposite. The program of the present Government is to ensure that we can adequately fulfil our role under ANZUS by undertaking responsibilities for which Australia alone should be responsible. That is the contribution we are making to ANZUS. We have stated our affinity with ANZUS and we believe that is the proposal supported by the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, shortly after Question Time I sought the leave of the House to table a document which purported to be the minutes of a meeting between the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and representatives of two unions held on 7 June. The Leader of the House (Mr Young) indicated at the time that, subject to my discussing it with the Treasurer and his giving approval, I could table those minutes. I did have a discussion with the Treasurer and he indicated that he would agree to my tabling the document. He has now come into the chamber ; he can confirm that he did agree, subject to my letting him know, which I did. I am glad the honourable gentleman has arrived. I simply want to say at this stage that the document which has come into my possession purports to be the minutes of a meeting with representatives of the Australian Bank Employees Union and the Commonwealth Bank Officers Association of Australia, held in Canberra on 7 June 1984. I have, of course, furnished the Treasurer with a copy of the minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: On the face of it, there is a conflict between the answer the honourable gentleman gave and that document. I simply make the point, so that there should be no misunderstanding about it, that I do not at this stage claim other than that this document purports to be a record of the discussion between the Treasurer and the unions on that particular date. I seek leave to table the document.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), said today in a question to me in relation to this matter that the document tabled represented the minutes of a meeting. The fact is that it does not contain the minutes of a meeting because the minutes would require some approval of their contents by me and there were no minutes kept as such. The document is obviously someone's note, if that. I make the point that it has no official status and, indeed, is not even an accurate record. I indicated at Question Time that I expressly told the unions that they would be vetting nothing in respect of the applicants. Indeed, my own Caucus committee sought also to involve itself in the approval of foreign exchange licences. I disagreed with that; I said that it was not entitled to do that. I would not allow it to do that and it did not. In the same vein, I told that to the bank employees unions. I do not know whether this document is even a note of a bank employees union-it has no signature to it-but it certainly is not a minute of the meeting and it is definitely an inaccurate record of what took place.

—by leave-I simply want to add that in a strict technical sense the document does not constitute an agreed minute between the two parties present at the meeting. I should make it perfectly plain to the House that I understand the document to have been a record of that conversation prepared on the union side. It has come to me on that basis. I am not surprised that the honourable gentleman should take exception to some of the things contained in the document because they are plainly at odds in one particular respect with the answer given today by the honourable gentleman. It is also interesting to note the very strident guarantees claimed in the record of conversation to have been given by the Treasurer regarding the union nature of any foreign banks that are granted licences. I think that the document will make some interesting reading for those people.
—I seek leave to respond to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition on the same subject.

—The Treasurer seeks leave to reply on the same matter. This is not a particularly formal way to handle this matter. Ideally, there should have been a motion to take note of the paper, but the House seems to be indulgent on this matter. On the premise that the matter will be brought to a quick conclusion, the Treasurer is given leave.

—First, I said that I had no knowledge of this document or its authenticity. It is obviously a record by somebody at the meeting, or appears to be. It is not accurate in respect of this question of vetting. It would be unthinkable for a union to be sitting beside the Government vetting foreign bank applicants for licences. I made that quite clear to the unions. I am sure that any inquiry to the bank officers' unions will substantiate that fact.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Road Safety, I present a report of the Committee on Road Safety generally.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report I have just tabled resulted from a road safety survey conducted by the Committee, which distributed a questionnaire Australia- wide through the offices of Federal members of parliament. The media also played a key role in drawing the questionnaire to the attention of the public. The questionnaire sought to identify people's perceptions of the major contributing factors to road crashes. Four major areas stood out, and these formed the basis for this report, namely: drink-driving; driver attitude and behaviour; speed as a factor in road crashes; and disregard of road law as a factor in crashes.

SPEECH.PARA: Alcohol was recognised as still being the greatest single cause of trauma on our roads. Random breath testing has had a definite impact on our road fatality figures, as is evidenced in Victoria, where the proportion of fatal crashes that have involved a positive blood alcohol level has gone down over the last five years from about 55 per cent to 40 per cent. The Committee believes that random breath testing should be fully implemented in all States and territories. The Committee noted that drugs, including medication, are also contributing to road crashes. Although a large volume of work would be involved, the Committee believes that further research is needed in this area. The Committee recognises the important initiatives of the Federal Office of Road Safety in commissioning studies on the effect of cannabis and alcohol on driving and on drug screening of drivers and pedestrians killed in road crashes. Applicants for driving licences should be made aware of the dangers of alcohol and drugs in relation to driving. The community as a whole should be more aware of the effects on driving of medication, other drugs and their interaction with alcohol.

Driver attitude and behaviour has long been recognised as one of the most important factors in road crashes but one of the most difficult to tackle. It is a difficult area to approach and, in the past, road safety authorities have tended to concentrate more on the road environment and vehicle safety. The behaviour of the road user is nearly always the final link in the chain of circumstances which lead to a road accident. On the positive side, driver behaviour can very often sever that final link. Researchers have estimated that the driver provides somewhere between 65 and 95 per cent of the prime causes of crashes, with the vehicle and the road providing the remainder. Driver behaviour is seen as dependent on the driver's ability and motivation or attitude. Of these two factors, research has consistently found that motivation is the most important influence on behaviour and well outweighs a driver's ability in determining the safety of road behaviour. It is also clear that the degree of difficulty of driving depends on what the driver chooses to do rather than the inherent difficulty of the driving task. A driver chooses to take sharp corners at high speed, to overtake in heavy traffic, or simply to drive recklessly. Safe behaviour can be motivated by a co-operative attitude, a desire to avoid crashes or simply to avoid penalties for breaking the law.

Education and campaigns to change community and individual driver attitudes are more productive than external enforcement measures as they are capable of providing a high level of compliance through self-enforcement. However, the Committee believes that selective enforcement can affect driver attitudes, with random breath testing being a good example. While recognising the difficulties of changing driver attitudes and behaviour to improve road safety, there are positive signs emerging. Research and education campaigns have identified some aspects that are more amenable to change. Recent anti-drink driving campaigns and random breath testing have seen marked reductions in road fatalities associated with alcohol, and the Committee is most heartened by this. The Committee has recommended that priority be given to road safety research aimed at investigating and improving driver attitude and behaviour.

Speed was ranked third in the survey of the most important factors contributing to road crashes. It seems that rather than the speed at which a car is driven, it is the inability of the driver to control the car at that speed and to react quickly enough to hazards or the actions of other drivers that leads to crashes. It seems to be the variability of speeds within a traffic stream that is a significant determinant of the likelihood of a collision. Evidence suggest that speed reductions will be most effective if the driving public can be convinced that the new limits are reasonable and the limits are rigorously enforced. The Committee believes that State and territory traffic authorities should be encouraged to use speed zoning depending on road and traffic conditions when setting speed limits.

Disregard of road rules was the fourth most important contributing factor in road crashes. Traffic enforcement accounts for the largest single proportion of all police duties. A considerable body of research relating to the effectiveness of enforcement in modifying road user behaviour and in reducing accidents currently exists. However, most studies are methodologically inadequate and few firm conclusions can be drawn from them. The Committee believes that the effectiveness of various enforcement procedures, including penalties, is in need of review. The difficulties and dangers of driving in remote areas of Australia are well known and the Committee was struck by the poor road conditions in many areas. If alcohol is added to this picture we have the dangerous mix of high speed, unrealistic driver perceptions and unsafe roads.

The Committee looked at particular road safety problems affecting Aboriginals. The Committee believes that some road safety publicity campaigns need to be designed specifically for Aboriginal and other outback communities. In such an important area as that of road safety, the Committee believes that national co- ordination is needed to develop short and long term road safety objectives. The Committee believes that a set of standardised statistics should be devised and collected throughout Australia to provide a more substantial road safety data base for Australia. Road safety research priorities should be developed at a national level by a Commonwealth-State co-operative body. Based on adequately researched road safety priorities, a program of short and long term measures should be developed at a national level by a Commonwealth-State co-operative body. This body should plan, co-ordinate and in some cases develop road safety programs at the national level. On the basis of national priorities, Commonwealth grants could be made for specific research, program development or education campaigns.

The Commonwealth needs to initiate and promote uniformity in Australian road safety statistics and the adoption of best practice in road safety measures. The Committee believes that greater co-ordination initiated at the national level is essential to make the maximum use of the expertise and financial resources available, whilst acknowledging that in many instances the State governments hold authority on specific road safety rules. The Committee believes that through co-ordination, better use can be made of limited resources with better road safety programs as the end product. This inquiry has shown that Australian people are concerned about road safety and consider this national tragedy worth comment, thought and action on a national scale. I take this opportunity to thank the members of the Standing Committee on Road Safety, many of whom are in the chamber today to listen to my speech on the presentation of this report. This Committee has kept its early promise of being a-political in its concern about road safety generally in Australia. I thank Committee members for their hard work and assistance during this Parliament, namely the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter), the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Gorman), the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), the honourable member for Franklin ( Mr Goodluck), the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Wells), the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), and the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth). I thank the staff, Mr Allan Kelly, Mrs Denise Denahy, Mr Simon De Vere and Miss Marie Ferris. I also thank the past staff of the Committee in this Parliament, Mrs Lyn Simons, Mr Paul McMahon, Ms Jennifer Goodger and Mrs Judy Terrel.

Finally, on behalf of Committee members I also thank the Federal Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris), and his staff, and Mr Bill Upton and officers of the Federal Office of Road Safety for their assistance in our common concern of achieving safer roads.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I congratulate the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling), the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Road Safety, for the way that she embarked on a very rigorous and determined effort as chairman of a bipartisan committee. Sometimes I thought she was overenthusiastic but I take it all back now. She has done her job in good heart and worked hard to try to develop a committee that has been at most times very interested in the goal of trying to cut down road deaths in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Sometimes I think that the Committee is not as fashionable as others; so we do not get the publicity that we should. Some other committees, by getting on to trendy issues, get a heck of a lot of publicity. We see grotesque photographs in most of the newspapers in Australia each day. We see pictures of cars smashed up and read that four or five children have been killed. When I see those pictures the realisation comes to me that the Committee is worthwhile. Sometimes its work is repetitive and we go over the same things day after day but it is worthwhile. At the end of the tunnel at least we contribute. It is better than the slush we see in the gutter in this place. Just think about the blood in the gutter day after day which we read about in the newspapers.

I found the Committee very interesting. I speak also on behalf of the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker). He has done a very good job. I am talking at the moment about members from my side. I cannot think of the names of all the honourable members on the other side who were members of the Committee but they are all good fellows. The honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) is away at the moment. He participated. On the other side, the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Wells) and the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Gorman) did a very good job in a constructive way, day after day and week after week, trying to cut down the road toll in Australia. The members of the Committee and the Committee staff are dedicated. They realise that together we are trying to make an impact on the road toll in Australia. There are 365 road deaths every year. Of those, 10 per cent are young cyclists, invariably under the age of 21.We have a job to do and a responsibility. If the number of people who die on the roads each year died in a war there would be a hell of a hue and cry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nearly 3,000 die.

—That is right. The number is not 365; it is nearly 3,000, almost 10 people each day. Many people are injured. Ninety thousand road cyclists are injured each year. It is a big problem. We all have to face up to it. I think the report is excellent. We will be criticised for it. The States, with their petty jealousies, will say: 'Why are you trying to tell us what to do?' We are trying to help. I hope that we can be constructive. I hope that the States will pick up the Committee's recommendations to make our roads a safer place for young people to drive. I hope those people will realise that they will have to moderate some of the things they do if they are to stay alive and contribute to this wonderful nation.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.
Ordered that the second reading be made an order of the day for a later hour this day.
[COGNATE BILL:
FISHING LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1984]
Debate resumed from 13 September, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill and the Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering the two measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian fishing industry has assumed both national and international significance only in the last 15 to 20 years. Prior to that time it catered primarily to local communities and major cities. However, the creation of an expanded market for Australian seafoods provided the stimulus for the growth of the Australian commercial industry. If Australia is to expand its fishing industry and develop new fisheries, particularly for import replacement purposes, it will be necessary for fishermen to exploit the resources further off-shore. It is not the Government's role to inhibit this potential expansion of the industry, yet exactly this is occurring with the lack of an off-shore constitutional settlement program in operation.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of the off-shore constitutional settlement makes interesting reading, particularly its more recent history; that is, since its referral by this all promises, no action Government to the desk of the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans). The history appears to be no more. The proclamation has never been issued. What has happened to the now illusive settlement, collecting dust in the Attorney-General's rooms? The implications of having no working, effective off-shore constitutional settlement is a cause of great concern and justifiably so-to not only the fishing community but also myself and my Opposition colleagues. I intend to move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1984 indicating our support for the measures raised by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) and also our concern at the lack of finalisation of this piece of legislation. Without the settlement in place to formalise Commonwealth-State administration arrangements for each fishery, there is no clear determination of which fisheries the Commonwealth has sole, or even a major, responsibility for managing.

Jurisdiction over minerals and fisheries are merely two elements concerning the off-shore constitutional settlement. However, the fishing concerns have been completely ignored by the Government. It was not until the mid-1970s that constitutional interpretation gave jurisdiction to the Commonwealth over fisheries beyond three miles from low water mark and the States jurisdiction over fisheries within three nautical miles. Nevertheless 1975, the year made famous for the return of a responsible, productive people's government-a soon to be repeated event-saw the High Court decision issuing Commonwealth jurisdiction from the low water mark to the three nautical miles mark. Rationalisation of the Commonwealth-State role has to be settled. States controlled up to three nautical miles, and the Commonwealth three to 200 miles. Fishing which crossed State borders and Commonwealth waters gave the impetus to the development of joint authorities, and thus off-shore constitutional settlement was finalised by Commonwealth and complementary State government legislation in 1982. Unfortunately, for the fishing industry, after the disastrous change of government it was to be re-examined and revised. It is now sitting somewhere in the Attorney-General's office.

Instead, there are many fisheries which presently involve some Commonwealth input but which would, if the off-shore constitutional settlement were operational, become solely a State responsibility. Many fisheries already subject to State levies, in recognition of either, firstly, their management costs or, secondly, a perceived benefit arising out of the exclusive access status, may become subject to additional Commonwealth levies, due to present Commonwealth expenditure in administering complementary legislation outside the three nautical miles State water limitations. Such complementary legislation is merely an administrative aberration and could not be considered to be true fisheries management. There is no agreement that the Commonwealth is incurring costs as a part of managing those fisheries and as such could legitimately seek to recover those costs.

The extent to which costs are recovered, according to the Minister in his second reading speech, 'will be determined in the light of costs and benefits that flow from management'. The Minister could not have been any clearer or have issued a more blatant statement of this socialist Government's true intention of revenue raising. This is nothing more than a resource rent tax. What would happen, I wonder, if it were to take that matter to the public. It is a crippling reward for entrepreneurial skills and initiatives, qualities foreign to my Australian Labor Party colleagues, but qualities nonetheless to which our great nation's success and future are attributed. There can be nothing more destructive than a tax of this kind and this is exactly what the Government is proposing. If the Government decides that the benefits-perhaps they are more appropriately described as profits flowing from a fishery subject to the Commonwealth levy-are excessive, the levy would then be varied to reflect the magnitude of these 'benefits'. Thus, in essence, the higher the profits, the greater the levy, causing a gradual destruction of all private enterprise initiatives in this country.

The logical conclusion of cost recovery, as envisaged by the legislation, is that the entire Fisheries Division of the Department of Primary Industry could be funded by levies on the basis that administration of the Fisheries Act is of benefit to all who are subject to it. The fishing industry certainly maintains, and with reason, that many of the Department's management actions are of no benefit whatsoever to the industry. If the industry has to pay, it has a right to know exactly where and how the funds are to be spent. Does it go into the general public coffers and not just to revenue? There must be some system of equity. There is no reluctance on the fisheries' behalf to invest their money into research contributing to exploratory fishing or pre-seasonal prawn sampling , as they are currently in the practice of doing with a degree of help from the Commonwealth Government. But there is concern over the possible funding in unrealistic circumstances of the public services.

Previous experience with cost recovery in the export inspection services has left the industry wary of exactly what costs are involved. There is no undertaking about which departmental costs will be included in the cost recovery calculations. There is no justification that conditions not available to private enterprise should be met by the levy. The costs of overservicing, the provision of excess staff, long service leave, superannuation, 17 per cent leave loading, as well as study leave, are discretionary costs accepted by the Commonwealth but not acceptable to the private employer. There is no justification that a competitive fishing industry should pay for Public Service conditions which are not available to the wider public.

So much lip service has been paid by the Minister to the user pays principles. He has attributed much of this legislation's conclusion to its logic. Yet it has come to my attention, and I feel obliged to acquaint the Minister with the fact, that inherent in this principle is the 'user says' principle, which has been conveniently disregarded or forgotten. If the user is to pay, the user has the right to some say as to how the funds from the levies will be utilised. It comes as no shock to realise that the Government appears to have once again, in a pseudo-dictatorial fashion, completely and utterly denied industry any rights in the implementation of legislation. Consultation with or notification of the industry about this legislation prior to its introduction has been non-existent. One prominent member of the industry described to me the Government's consultation with the industry over the past year as appalling. The Government cries 'consensus' continually. Consensus with whom, I ask. It was certainly not in this case with the industry. It is the Opposition's policy to have lengthy negotiations with industry sources as they often have insights into the complexities of industry often missed by government and departmental advisers. The Minister to us appears more concerned with setting up legislation through which means he can raise more funds at will, the amount of which is unknown to the industry and to myself and is obviously lurking in the dim dark recesses of the Minister's mind.

It was the special case of the northern prawn fisheries labouring under an excess of boats which initiated the concept of paying back the Government via the use of a levy on operating boats for the next five years, when it is hoped the total number of boats should have declined. Unfortunately, it appears to us that the Government has become overexcited and has used this opportunity to develop legislation covering all fisheries in general as a means of raising revenue, whereas the original intention was to overcome the problem in one particular part of the industry-the northern prawn fisheries.

The northern prawn fisheries deserve commendation for their efforts of self- regulation and determination to preserve the fisheries for future generations. It needs to be stressed that the Government is not providing the loan. That loan of $5m has to be arranged on commercial terms and with commercial repayments. It is a responsible approach and I hope that those boat owners who will be leaving the industry will have the opportunity of resettlement in some other pursuit or some other opportunity for retraining so that they can continue to operate in private enterprise. It is hoped, too, that efforts of the industry in self- regulation will result in the prawn fishery not being overexploited and that those who remain in the industry will at least have a reasonable return for the efforts and risks undertaken. In regard to the Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), I foreshadow that I shall move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the legislation should not have been introduced until completion of an off-shore constitutional settlement between the Commonwealth and the States formalising areas of fisheries administration'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we should pause for a moment to consider why the Fisheries Licences Levy Bill 1984 and the Fishing Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1984 are necessary. If one looks at the course the fishing industry in Australia has taken over the last 20 years, one can see that it is in the state it is in through the neglect of the previous Government. The previous Government was simply never prepared to take the hard decisions that were necessary to ensure that we had a viable fishing industry in this country. I think that fact has to be recognised. Although some of the initiatives that we are taking are obviously unpopular with the industry, we have consulted with it. The industry realises that, unpalatable as those initiatives are, they are long overdue. We will get support from the industry for that reason. When we talk about Australia's fish resource, we are talking about a resource that belongs to all the people of Australia. It would be unconscionable if, in giving limited entry to these fisheries and thereby bestowing a very large economic rent value on the people fortunate enough to be in a limited entry fishery, some return to the public was not forthcoming. This legislation seeks to impose on the industry a small charge to make sure that money is available for the development of specific fisheries. The Government has spelt out quite clearly that the money will be made available to the industry for use in specific fisheries. The Government has no intention at all, and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has given an assurance in this respect, of imposing levies in respect of fisheries that are struggling or are not in a position to pay. There is also no doubt that the fisheries in Australia that have done best and survived the best are those fisheries which are controlled. I refer to limited entry fisheries. In this regard I think that Western Australia has by far the best record.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the most stable of the limited entry fisheries. I hope that, when we have managed to put all of the fisheries in Australia on this basis and we have a strong, stable industry, the efforts of the Minister will be recognised by the industry. I think his efforts have been absolutely tremendous. He is the first Minister who has spent so much time and effort looking after the interests of the fishing industry. It is nonsense for the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh) to suggest that there has been no consultation. There has been an enormous amount of consultation with people in the industry. It is ongoing consultation. Until the electoral redistribution I represented the biggest fishing electorate in Australia and I know the extent of this consultation. I know that there are many people in the industry who now say that for the first time there is the ability to talk to government and government will listen to the problem that they have. The fisheries in Australia are in need of a lot more research. I personally believe that one of the things we need to do is to utilise the private sector by encouraging it to engage in much more fishery research. I think this is an initiative that this Government is looking at and can make a very big contribution to. It would seem to me to be far more efficient for the Government to give assistance to people who are interested in developing a new fishery. The private sector itself could undertake research and it would be very happy to have on board fishing inspectors and qualified people to aid them in that research. However, the main cost of carrying out this research would be borne by the private sector. If that fishery proved viable, it would be rewarded by being among the first into it.

One area that is causing me considerable concern is that of the southern bluefin tuna. It is quite obvious that this industry has to be rationalised. This rationalisation will, in the long run, mean a drift of catch from Western Australia to other States, most likely to South Australia. I certainly would not agree with such a development in the long run. In the short term, it presents enormous problems. Some mechanism has to be worked out to ensure that the employment prospects in places like Albany and Esperance, which already have very high unemployment levels, are considered. I think a mechanism can be worked out. Such a mechanism would require a phasing in of any new arrangements over a two-year period. This would, of course, be contingent upon the necessary research being carried out to ensure that other fish were made available to supply the fish processing works in these areas. I am sure that the fish are there; I am sure that the potential is there. However, research will be needed and this research will only be carried out through proper management of the fishing industry.

Another area that is concerning me is the development of the rock lobster industry in the north of Western Australia where the predominant species is the painted crayfish which does not readily pot. This fish does not pot in existing pots. But I believe there is every chance that, with the necessary research, we can develop pots that will ensure that this species can be trapped commercially. There is no doubt that there is a world-wide demand for crayfish. This is one area in which considerable extra benefit can be derived for Australia. At the same time a lot of employment and stability can be given to country towns that are now leading a very tenuous existence. I know from experience that a lot of this research can be carried out by the private sector with government co- operation. I am hopeful that we can ensure that assistance is given to the industry.
Debate (on motion by Mr Drummond) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to advise the House that today I called upon His Excellency the Governor-General and recommended to him that the House of Representatives be dissolved and that a general election for the members of the House of Representatives be held on Saturday, 1 December 1984. His Excellency has accepted my recommendation. Mr Speaker, may I depart from my prepared text and say this to you, sir, and to the House: While His Excellency has authorised me to indicate his acceptance of my recommendation, he will put that in writing and I expect to receive that tomorrow. When I receive his reply in writing I will table the exchange of correspondence between His Excellency and me.

SPEECH.PARA: I have also asked the Governor-General to take the necessary action to enable an election to be held for half the Senate conjointly with the election for the House of Representatives. His Excellency has agreed to take this action. The details of the election timetables are: Issue of writs 26 October 1984; close of electoral rolls 2 November 1984; close of nominations 6 November 1984; polling day 1 December 1984; return of writs 24 January 1985. Referendums on the Constitution Alteration (Terms of Senators) Bill 1984 and the Constitution Alteration (Interchange of Powers) Bill 1984 will also be held on 1 December.

The Parliament still has significant and essential Government legislation before it. The Government wishes this legislation to pass the House by 11 October to enable it to rise then. The Senate will clearly need to sit at least an extra week to deal with the essential legislation before it. I then propose to advise the Governor-General to dissolve the House of Representatives, probably on 26 October.

Mr Speaker, when my predecessor as Prime Minister advised the double dissolution of the Parliament on the ever memorable 3 February 1983, he set in train a certain inevitability of events. The chief of those was, of course, the election of my Government on March 1983. But his decision to advise a double dissolution also significantly affected the electoral timetable of this, the Parliament of the Commonwealth. As a result of that decision, the timetable for simultaneous elections for the House of Representatives and half the Senate- which had been temporarily restored by the premature election of 1977-was once again disrupted. The consequence is that under the Constitution there must be an election for half the Senate in time to enable the newly elected senators to take their places in July 1985. In practical terms-involving considerations of the time required by the Australian Electoral Commission to complete the counting of votes-this means that the half Senate election could be held no later than April next year.

It has, however, been the pattern over many years for elections for half the Senate to be held in the latter months of the preceding calendar year. Since 1949-leaving aside the three double dissolution elections-eight out of 10 such elections have been held in November or December and one other was held in October. The three separate half Senate elections, of 1964, 1967 and 1970, were all held in November or December. It is therefore absolutely clear that the decision to hold the election for half the Senate on 1 December conforms entirely with well-established custom, proper procedure and clear precedents.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I can understand, of course, why those on the other side desperately want to avoid an election. We can understand that. Virtually from the outset of my prime ministership I have made it very clear to the Parliament and public that I intended, if possible, and if consistent with the higher national interest, to realign the elections for the two Houses.
—You can't even keep a straight face.

—The reason I cannot keep a straight face is that I am looking at the joy all over the face of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard).
