However, the inspection services have become a bureaucracy and are controlling the industry. This situation has arisen particularly in the meat industry. The background in the meat industry is that we have 100,000 people employed, 30,000 of whom are employed in the export works. The meat industry produces $2,300m worth of export income and 50 to 60 per cent of our meat is exported.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the past five years 40 works have closed and cattle numbers have declined from a peak of 33 million in 1976-77 to the low figure of 22 million in 1983-84. The Industries Assistance Commission report in 1983 indicated that the meat industry was seriously depressed and likely to remain so for some time. During this time of change in the industry the numbers of meat inspectors employed by the meat inspection service make an interesting comparison. In the peak years of 1976-77, 1,616 meat inspectors were employed. In the peak years of 1978-79 there were 1,794 meat inspectors. Although cattle numbers had declined in 1982-83 we still had 1,632 meat inspectors employed.

The problems of the meat industry are varied and well known to the members of this House. Producers encounter problems in selling on the overseas market and processors have problems with the availability of livestock. In addition, there has been the impact of the 1967-68 drought and the more recent drought in 1982- 83. The problems of processors in making their plants efficient and in achieving a constant throughput occur each year. Not only does the meat industry face these difficulties, but it has problems with regulations for export, regulations for the home market, and the inspection services the costs of which we are discussing tonight. This is a very labour intensive industry and it is prone to industrial disputes. The year 1980 was a peak year for industrial disputes and the meat industry was significantly disturbed.

Turning to the Budget Papers and the figures we are now discussing, it is interesting to observe that the expenditure set out for export meat inspection services is $77.7m and the estimated revenue will be $61.7m. I wonder whether the Minister can assure the House that the $21m included in the revenue figure will be recouped from last year's unpaid charges. I hope that the Minister will give an assurance that that money will be forthcoming. We now see that the net cost to government will be about $37.7m.

There is doubt about the efficiency of the Commonwealth meat inspection service as it now operates. I wish to quote from the Woodward report of the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry. The report states:

. . . I believe administrative arrangements and procedures for supervision of the handling of meat for export have been far from adequate to ensure that such meat has met the requirements prescribed by law.
The important sentence stated:
I believe that they are now adequate, but could be made more cost-effective and more certain.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those are key words.

—As the honourable member for Wannon says, that is a key point. There is a comparison between the inspection services at a Federal level and those offered at a State level in Victoria. Industry sources estimate that the cost of the service in Victoria runs at $8.4m. The service inspects something like 85 to 90 per cent of the meat processed in that State. Industry sources estimate that it costs about $13m to render the same Federal inspection service which covers about 10 to 15 per cent of the remaining export products. The Country Abbatoirs and Wholesalers Association of Victoria reports that because of this cost differential the State meat inspectors could inspect and brand the present export kill in the Victorian export works for a cost of $4m. So one can see that on a contractual basis the Victorian inspectors could save the producers and processors $9m. Those are the figures and the observations which are made on the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Meat Exporters Federal Council has drawn up a table which I believe demonstrates the problem in broad terms. Let us look at the cost of inspection charges for the number of animals processed. In 1979-80, 8.8 million cattle and 30.5 million sheep and lambs were slaughtered. The inspection charge in that year was $31m. In 1983-84 7 million cattle were slaughtered. This was a reduction of 20 per cent. The figure for sheep and lambs went down to 24 million representing a reduction of 21 per cent. However, the interesting point is that inspection charges rose to $79m, an increase of 150 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —They went up.

—The charges went up. Yet the number being inspected was less. Regarding the charges which are before the House, the Minister has put forward a suggestion that there has been a reduction from $5.40 to $4.35, a reduction of 20 per cent. I draw the attention of the House to the true position. In September 1983 a charge of $1.80 applied. In October 1983 the charge was increased to $5.40.
—A 300 per cent increase.

—There was a hike of 200 per cent in charges on that occasion. We now propose a charge of $4.35 which represents a 142 per cent increase on the September 1983 figure. The situation in Queensland is that the proposed export fee of 2.4c a kilogram will add a cost of about $8 to $10 per head. This export levy will be very important in Queensland because that is from where most of the cattle are exported and that is where the increase in charges will be most painful. The increase in Queensland and throughout Australia will be $1.80, up to $10, representing an increase of 500 per cent.
—How much?

—Five hundred per cent. The Meat Exporters Federal Council estimates that the increased inspection fees will add $30m to industry costs in a full financial year. The interesting comparison to be drawn is that meat inspection in America, New Zealand and Canada is publicly funded which means that our competitors on the international market will not have to bear this quite excessive charge. It means that they will be able to export their meat into world markets competitively and at much better prices than we can in Australia.
—So the Government pays for the total cost over that.

—That is correct. That is our policy and that is the way we would do it in government. We would give our primary producers a chance to compete on the export market. It is interesting that just this very day the inspectors in Victoria have gone on strike. They could be worried about their jobs. The important thing in Victoria is that although there is a strike the domestic consumers have been able to receive their meat because the Victorian inspectors have continued to work on.
—You mean only the Federal inspectors are on strike?

—Only the Federal inspectors in Victoria have gone on strike. I gather there will be further strikes around the nation in the next few days. Can the Minister assure the Australian meat producers, the taxpayers and the processors whether any inspectors are working at processing plants which are no longer operative or inspectors who are surplus to requirements? Hopefully the Minister can assure the House that there are no inspectors who are surplus to requirements and are not working in plants that are not in operation. It is a sad situation for the meat industry that, in a 6-week period from 9 August, five works have closed throughout Australia. Five thousand workers have been put off. Industry people suggest that the increase in inspection charges has been a contributing factor in the closure of these works. The interim Inspection Policy Council, which was appointed by the Government to look into these matters, has made two strong recommendations to the Government. Apparently the Government has seen fit to not take up these recommendations. The Council, in its report in April 1984 recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in the short term there is a compelling case for assistance to be given to the industry through a reduction in the export inspection charge.
In fact, the Government has increased the charge to the industry. The Council recommended further, in line with the difficulties the industry is facing and the closure of abbatoirs, that:

. . . a moratorium be declared on the export component for 2 years because of the State of the industry, the need for trade incentives and the fact that efficiency measures and charges must be phased in.

I conclude by asking: Are we propping up yesterday's men in yesterday's practices or are we putting in place the most cost effective meat inspection service for both domestic and export consumption that will take us into tomorrow 's world?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Meat Export Charge Bill and the Meat Export Charge Collection Bill this evening and after listening to the honourable member for Corangamite, Mr McArthur, the first point that needs to be made in this debate is that we are talking about a measure designed to collect 50 per cent of export charge expenses, a policy which was introduced by the previous Government, the so-called friend of the graziers. Back in 1978 the Fraser Government decided that all rural industries should pay 50 per cent of the cost of export charges. This policy was further enforced by the famous razor gang, headed by Peter Nixon, the Minister at the time, who set out quite clearly to this House that export charges should be set at the rate of at least 50 per cent for those who are benefiting from the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight members of the Opposition, who were members of the Government at the time this policy was introduced, appear to be trying to tell us that the policy of collecting 50 per cent of export charges was a fallacy. It is a policy that they introduced and one from which they now seem to be wanting to back away. There is no reason why there should not be some charge on export inspection for any industry. To try to blame export charges for the calamity that is occurring in the meat export industry is a complete fallacy. We know that the fortunes of the meat export industry go up and down. Over many years export meatworks have closed and reopened. In fact, this country was governed for 30-odd years by a government which oversaw this type of operation.

It was very strange that honourable members from the Western District of Victoria, the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) and the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), whose predecessor, as Prime Minister of this country, oversaw the policy of introducing 50 per cent export charges, should stand up tonight and try to tell us that there is something wrong with that very policy. This policy has to be implemented. Circumstances in the meat industry at present are such that there will be closures of meatworks simply because of the world market situation. It is wrong to try to blame such closures on export charges. They are a small sector of the cost structure of that industry. They are not the total sector. If export charges were at a minimum we would still have a complete closure of many meatworks simply because the stock is not available and the market is not available. So honourable members opposite ought to be honest in relation to that matter.

I wish to direct my remarks tonight not so much to the meat industry, as has been the case until now, but to the dairy industry and to the egg industry, which are also vital industries to Australia. The dairy industry in my electorate of McMillan is a vital industry for my electorate and for the people who work in that industry. I refer not just to the farming sector but to the factories in every town in my electorate. Hundreds of workers are reliant on the dairy industry. A situation has developed in Australia wherein, once again because we have overproduction and an export market which does not pay, we have to ask ourselves what do we do with that industry. Do we allow the free enterprise market structure to operate? If we followed the philosophy of free enterprise of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia , we would do absolutely nothing. If their philosophy were allowed to operate we would have a massive collapse right across the board in the industry until things got back to a market supply and demand situation. We clearly know that, while that is an alternative, it is not the priority alternative for any industry. We have to take into consideration that it will affect the jobs of people in factories and on farms. We have to consider the economy of the towns in the dairy areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. Madam Deputy Speaker, I, of course, am always very broad-minded but I draw your attention to the fact that these Bills are about the collection of inspection fees. They have nothing to do with philosophy. I ask you, Madam Deputy Speaker, to keep a very close look out to make sure that the honourable member talks to the Bills.
— Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member is relating it back to the economic conditions in his area.

—In any industry involved in export charges one must look at the complete industry. As the debate has gone on tonight members of the Opposition have tried to tell us that the cost of exports has a definite input in the actual industry. So what I am saying is definitely related to what we are talking about, and I am talking about the dairy industry and export charges. While they are a very minor point in regard to the total economics of the dairy industry, tonight I would like to look at the industry as a whole and at some of its problems.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that my colleague the honourable member for Macarthur, who will be following me in this debate, also has a very deep interest in the dairy industry . I put to you, Madam Deputy Speaker, that the dairy industry employs thousands of people. The first thing every member of every family in Australia sees in the morning after he has cleaned his teeth properly is the milk in his bowl of Wheeties. It is an industry which affects everybody in Australia.

Here we have an industry which has developed in Australia on an export basis for many years. We used to export thousands of tonnes of dairy products to the United Kingdom before it joined the European Economic Community. Since 1970, thanks to the lack of support by members of the former Country Party, we have had the situation where, just across the Tasman Sea, New Zealand is still exporting to the EEC and Australia is on the outer. So we had to try to find markets which were not as lucrative. Because of that we have had to cut back the industry in Australia. It has been cut back to the point now where Victoria and Tasmania are major producers of exports and New South Wales-my colleague from New South Wales, the honourable member for Macarthur, will speak later in this debate-is vitally interested in what will happen.

We have two industries in one. One sector of the industry produces milk for the morning breakfast table under contract with the State governments. Another sector of the industry produces the same product which is converted to our butter and cheese and sold on the world market. Because the world market has collapsed, we have to ask ourselves what we should do at present when those who cannot get a decent price for their products see a market opportunity in sending milk from Victoria to Sydney and want to do something about it.

It is quite clear that in this case the Government has responsibilities and must take a serious look at this problem. I noticed in the speech of the shadow Minister for Primary Industry, the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh), that he did not even mention this most vital subject. This is a most vital subject for those in thousands of jobs, for thousands of producers and for the consumers of Australia. The shadow Minister skipped over it in about two minutes and did not even bother to give its importance a look in.

Right now we have a clash between an industry which is producing for exports and one which is producing for the local market. The Government has to face up to the responsibility of deciding what will happen to the whole industry should it cut itself back to the point--

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. In all fairness the matter of quotas for an industry has nothing whatsoever to do with an inspection service. I ask that the honourable member contain his remarks to the Bills, as my colleagues have done.
—Order! The honourable member for McMillan will be relevant to the Bills for the remainder of his remarks.
—I seek your indulgence, Madam Deputy Speaker. There have been other Bills in this--

—I recognise that other speakers have been roaming far and wide. I have given the honourable member for McMillan a fair amount of latitude. I suggest that for the few minutes remaining to him he make his remarks relevant to the Bills. We have seven Bills before us. With the indulgence of the Chair, previous speakers have moved outside the relevance of each of the seven Bills and so has the honourable member for McMillan. I suggest that he now get back to the Bills. Future speakers might also like to look at the fact that they may have a little indulgence but they may not roam forever.

—It has become quite obvious from the debate tonight that there is no member on the Opposition side who understands the dairy industry at the moment. After the next election there will be no Opposition member here who understands the dairy industry at all, because the Opposition does not want to hear what is possibly one of the most important debates to have taken place on primary industry. It is important for thousands of people who have jobs in that industry and for thousands of consumers.

SPEECH.PARA: In view of the objections we are receiving from the Opposition, I move on by saying that at present negotiations relating to the dairy industry are in a very delicate stage. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) is negotiating with State Ministers to try to agree on a proposition which will create the climate in which thousands of people can maintain their jobs. People will be able to stay on the farms and will be able once again to pay that export charge which this legislation seeks to cover. If we do not come up with a policy which is for the benefit of the whole industry, we will finish up without an export industry in dairy products. This will adversely affect the Australian economy. We need exports. We can maintain those exports but it will not be done by the Opposition 's laissez-faire, private enterprise, free enterprise, supply and demand type policies. It will be done simply by negotiation between the Federal Minister and the State Ministers. I believe that this Minister at the table knows more about the dairy industry than anybody sitting on the Opposition side.

I move on to the Eggs (Export Inspection Charge) Amendment Bill, the Eggs ( Export Inspection Charge) Collection Amendment Bill and the Egg Export Legislation Repeal Bill. A number of decisions of far-reaching effect to the Australian egg industry have been made by the Government. These were announced in a media release in Townsville on 2 August by the Minister at the table. They were that the Australian Egg Board, which was involved in export marketing, was to be abolished and that the Commonwealth hen levy, which was used to equalise losses, was to be phased out on 1 July 1987. Also, sections of the Trade Practices Act which provide exemptions for arrangements between egg marketing authorities on pricing for interstate trade and for restrictive interstate trade are to be repealed.

Over the period since August it has been suggested in various quarters that all the decisions announced by the Government came as a complete surprise to the industry. However, this was not the case as a number of these decisions followed recommendations made to the Minister for Primary Industry by the Australian Egg Marketing Council. Since that time, in addition to the decisions announced, the Australian Egg Marketing Council has been invited by the Department of Primary Industry to meet the Department to discuss research, the phasing out of the Commonwealth levy and other matters affecting the industry.

I am sure that under this Government and under this Minister we can look forward to rational policies and communication between State and Federal Ministers. It will take a little time but we have to turn around many years of neglect, many years of past governments taking the decision that spending a few bob here and a few bob there would keep the cockies happy. Those days are gone. We are in the real business world now. We are competing in world markets and we have to be fair dinkum. I am sure that these sorts of Bills that have been brought forward by the Minister, and the ones that will continue to be presented by this Government, will be in the long term for the betterment of rural Australia and of jobs in rural Australia. That is a very important point that we never hear a word about from the Opposition benches. We always hear about the farmers but we never hear a thing about the factory jobs involved--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the abattoir workers?

—The honourable member for Maranoa interjects: 'What about the abattoir jobs?' I point to the number of years when honourable members on that side of the House had charge of the export industries. They allowed them to get to a situation where now it would take an absolute genius to overcome those problems in 18 months. The people of Australia will re-elect this Government on 1 December and over the next four years we will be able to reinstate those jobs which have been lost because of the policies over the seven years prior to our taking government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been interesting to listen to the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) and to realise that, of course, the prime part of the honourable member's constituency is in fact the dairy industry. He sided with a Government which has completely abrogated its responsibilities to these industries and particularly that part of the dairy industry which is still involved in the meat industry. We all know that we cannot run a dairy industry without also being involved in the meat industry. We know very well what a disastrous blow has been struck against the meat industry by this Government's recent move with these meat inspection charges.

SPEECH.PARA: It was interesting to hear the honourable member. He even bothered to tell us that we are in the real business world. But what else did he tell us? He told us of some fancy deal whereby he will encourage his constituents, who happen to be the most efficient milk producers in Australia, not to go into the New South Wales market where they could make a quid-where they could make money. He will talk them out of that, with the aid of this Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) who thought he could also talk the wheat industry out of what was its right, and deny the Australian economy $3,000m. He did not even understand what his Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was on about. The Prime Minister needed that $3, 000m so he could go to the electorate and claim that his Treasurer (Mr Keating) is one of the best Treasurers. Of course, this Treasurer has gained his reputation by rain and bountiful seasons.

But let us look at some of the other things that the honourable member for McMillan bothered to tell us. He said that Victoria might survive if it could still be an exporter. It can export to other States--

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course it can.

—But the Government will not let it. The Government will have a fancy deal whereby there are switches of money and slings. The poor old taxpayer will have to pay up while the honourable member's constituents, the people he represents here, are denied the opportunity of competing in the market.
—I will send you down in the election campaign against him. You will clean him up.

—It would be a good idea to let those people know how their man represents them in this place. The first responsibility of any member of parliament is to the people who place their trust in him. No trust should be given to this person.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some of the problems confronting the meat industry, particularly the export charges that have been put upon them. It is not long ago that the honourable member for McMillan, in his opening remarks, told us that 50 per cent of shared costs was an idea of our Government when we were in power under Malcolm Fraser.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not our policy.

—I say to our shadow Minister for Primary Industry, the honourable member for Darling Downs, that it was basically a policy that 50 per cent of the costs be borne. But it was not 50 per cent of $77m. That is the difference. This Government has let this thing run wild. It has been unable to administer it. It has taken control of the Government. The other day this Minister went out to slap the meat inspectors on the wrists and tell them that maybe they should reduce their numbers a bit. Of course, he rushed into New South Wales and picked up an extra 300 staff when he did not need any of them. He went out there to rationalise the situation. He told the poor old consumer in New South Wales: 'We will give you a single charge'. Instead he picked up an extra 300 meat inspectors and put them on higher wages and better conditions than they had had before. Who will pay for that? The honourable member for McMillan says that we have to consider the consumers. He represents consumers and producers but does not seem interested in either of them.

SPEECH.PARA: But $77.7m is what this Government will spend on inspecting meat. It is disgraceful. The Government has been unable to come to grips with the main problem. As I said, it set out to slap the meat inspectors on the wrists. But what is being tolerated this week? There are lightning strikes in every State. Today it is Melbourne. A major exporter told me: 'We are behind on our market deliveries because of the seasonal conditions and now we cannot load meat today. We cannot sell it on behalf of Australia'. What did the honourable member for McMillan tell us? He told us that we are in the real business world. What a stupid statement.

The facts of life are that the Export Inspection Service is destroying the Australian meat industry because this Government has ignored the recommendations of the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry. It has looked at the whole situation and has failed to come to grips with any part of it. What is more, I can tell honourable members that security is not very good. The situation is that in many meat works where dual export and local meat are produced, they lock up the export meat but fail to lock up the local meat. If someone can sneak a bit of extra meat into the local freezers during the night, out it comes in the morning. If it happens to get accidentally mixed up in the export meat, that will be a profit for someone. Of course, if the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) were here at the moment he would well remember his dealings on behalf of the Richmond City Council and the Protean meat company. He would know how things work and how they are done. He is an expert. But there are problems associated with the meat industry. The huge burden--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. There was an insinuation against the honourable member for Melbourne Ports. There was absolutely no ground for what the honourable member for O'Connor said.
—Order! The Chair did not perceive it as a reflection. There is no point of order. I call the honourable member for O' Connor.

—At times the sensitivity of the Government is remarkable. Of course, the honourable member for McMillan was a member of this Parliament in the days when his Party was in opposition, and it is amazing how the sensitivity of honourable members opposite can rise. I just wish that on occasions he had called for the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) to relax a little and not try to annihilate people like John Reid with unfounded accusations.

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: The matter involving the honourable member for Fremantle and Mr Reid has nothing to do with this debate and I think that the honourable member should clearly get back to somewhere close to what he is supposed to be debating.
—The honourable member has made his point of order. I ask the honourable member for O'Connor to maintain relevance to the Bill.

—I agree entirely with your ruling, Mr Deputy Speaker; it was only in response to the interjection and those references that I digressed in that manner. There are huge problems for the meat industry. I was advised just recently, again by exporting people, that the European Economic Community in the last few weeks has made further inroads into our Pacific and Indian Ocean markets and, to quote the exporter with whom I was discussing this matter, into areas that we considered absolutely the preserve of Australia. Those markets are being reduced. In his words, the reason is that we are no longer able to compete . We are well aware, as the Minister will tell us, of the European Economic Community's subsidy practices. The Community is prepared to subsidise and, although I do not stand here as a supporter of that action either within Australia or anywhere else, I do say that government has a responsibility, even if it chooses to levy some charge against the producers of this country for the provision of the export service, to see that it is as inexpensive as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has heard me on this before, but each time I come into this place to speak on this subject I am obliged to bring up the Northam Shire Council. The Northam Shire Council, in my electorate, services the Lindley Valley abattoir and the Tip Top meatworks. They are not small works; in fact, when the Northam Shire Council was supporting only the Tip Top meatworks, it employed eight meat inspectors. So it was a reasonably large works. Under State Government legislation it is obliged to recoup not 50 per cent of the cost of meat inspection services but 100 per cent of the cost. Today, when we are debating this new and iniquitous legislation, the charge is $3.60 per bullock.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—An amount of $3.60, all sizes in. I admit that that is being done for local inspection and other demands are placed on the export system. If that charge were doubled-it would not be; it might go up by 50 per cent to roughly $5 -for 100 per cent recovery, there would have to be some questions about the capabilities of this wonderful Federal Government operation! The Minister has assured us that there will be a charge, aimed at recovering 50 per cent, of $4. 35. What a myth that $4.35 is. That is all right for a bobby calf or something like that. The method behind this new system, which has never been used before, is that the bigger the bullock, the more one pays. The rate of charge in the legislation is 4.8c per kilogram, while only 2.4c per kilogram is applied at present. When these meat inspectors have finished their little round of lightning strikes, it will probably be encumbent on the Minister to come in here to tell us that he has granted them something that Cliff Dolan told him to. Just as he told the Government how to fix up the Budget this year, he will tell it how to do this. The Minister will then tell the producers the amount has to be that 4.8c.

SPEECH.PARA: In the north-west of Western Australia and areas of Queensland which are the great exporting areas-the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen) has told us that we are not big exporters in the corn-fed beef sector; our prime export area has always been large aged beef going out for the hamburger trade and the like-we are not talking about bobby calves and baby beef of 180 kilograms; we are talking about the steer of 500 kilograms as he walks into the slaughter yard. If the abattoir is efficient and takes out its 65 per cent of meat on which this 2.4c per kilogram will be paid, the abattoir will have 325 kilograms of meat and at that 2.4c per kilogram the amount works out to be $7.80. If I read the Minister's legislation properly, he still adds what I would term the fixed charge of $2.55 to that. He can correct me if I have misread his legislation but that is the way it works out to me. The producer sending that bullock into the market is not paying the Minister's so-called $4. 35 which the Minister says is the same as it used to be; he is paying $10.35.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the Minister going to say to that?

—What will he say to that? If that still represents 50 per cent, it means that the cost of running this wonderful export inspection service is something like $20.70 per bullock! I am not sure that that is correct; all I know is that it will cost $77.4m this year, of which the Australian producer has to pick up the tab for $40.7m and the poor old Australian taxpayer has to pick up the rest, when the reality is that this Government does not need to carry that burden at all. The fact is that Mr Justice Woodward, in his particularly interesting report of the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry, went to some length in paragraph 9.5 to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . managements should be encouraged to take over responsibilities for work on the chain now performed by meat inspectors. The numbers of meat inspectors should be correspondingly reduced but, on average, their work should become more responsible and call for greater experience and higher personal qualities.

That is a direct result of the evidence I gave to the Commissioner. The fact is that I said, and the Commissioner agreed, that the Commonwealth should employ very limited numbers of meat inspectors, and those meat inspectors should be highly paid supervisors. They should be there to ensure fair play on behalf of the importing countries. The supervisor could see that the job was done properly . The Government could well and truly afford that small cost and in fact make the service freely available to the industry. The industry would then definitely be stuck with employing some meat inspectors but of course it would employ them as seasonal and cyclical workers. The Government could do that, and that could reduce almost totally the burden on the taxpayer and the efficiency of the balance of the inspection could be left to the works. They could do it properly.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about milk and eggs for five minutes?

—The honourable member has so deserted the dairy farmers of his area that I am astounded that he even wants to raise the word 'dairy' in this place. He has sold them out. It is time the electors of McMillan had that drawn to their attention. I know how the Department of Primary Industry has worked on this issue for years. I argued with a Minister of the Fraser Government that the importing countries did not demand that we employ the actual chain-type meat inspection service and that the responsibility of our Government, under our agreements, is supervision. I had to ask a question in the Parliament to get even our Minister to agree to that. Ministers get brainwashed; that is the problem. I eventually asked the Minister on 25 March 1981:

SPEECH.PARA: Is there any evidence that the countries importing meat from Australia demand that the Federal Government must pay the wages of meat inspectors?

The Minister was absent from the Parliament that day so the question was fielded by the Prime Minister. The Minister eventually replied on 3 April, and the answer to the question was no. I put it to the House that this Minister could not answer honestly in any other fashion. It is not the best when we have to agree that our Minister did not do it, but this is the Government of the brave new world. We heard the Prime Minister carry on this afternoon. The most interesting thing he said today was that the Government would be against tax avoidance and organised crime. I guess that means no more Dawkins and no more Wran. These are the things that this Government could address if it chose to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The honourable member referred to a Minister as Dawkins and to the Premier of New South Wales as Wran. I think he should refer to them by their correct titles.
—The honourable member has a point. I ask the honourable member for O'Connor to be more cautious in his address.
—I will certainly be more specific. I will say no more Minister for Finance and no more Premier of New South Wales. I thank the honourable member for McMillan for the opportunity to repeat it.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor again offends. There is an implicit reflection in his amended remarks. I ask him to proceed with the Bill and reframe his remarks.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, if you request me to withdraw, I certainly do so. The Australian industry and the Australian people are confronted with no Government determination to address the cause of the problem. The cause of the problem is that the inspection services are too costly. They are costly for many reasons. Quite clearly, the Government will not do anything about that. It tolerates strikes which are a further blow to the industry and which quite fly in the face of the efforts of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis). He has recently come back from Japan, where he told the Japanese that if they bought meat or any other product from Australia his union mates would guarantee delivery. They are not delivering meat today. In fact, they are imposing an intolerable burden on the industry in so many ways.

SPEECH.PARA: On previous occasions I have drawn to the attention of the House the huge costs of travel for meat inspectors. I made this comparison: Eight meat inspectors working for the Northam Shire could commute from the metropolitan area to provincial areas at a cost of $7,000 a year; when the Feds moved in the price jumped to $45,000 a year. This absolute waste is one reason why it is so wrong to have a government department employing meat inspectors. I have said before that the industry is seasonal and cyclical. While that situation exists, it is incumbent on the Government to go to the core of the problem and not just shelve its burdens on to the producers, who are presently suffering from the market situation and suffering even more because these burdens are pushing them out of the competitive area.

I condemn the Government for introducing the legislation at this time. It says that there is never a good time to impose additional taxes, but this happens to be one of the worst times. The Minister is not even keeping up his reputation of Mr Nice Guy. After all, we know it is he who goes out to do the public relations . It is the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), Senator Walsh and a few of the others who put in the hatchet. Country people and the producing industry are very much opposed to these moves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak in this cognate debate and will confine my remarks to the Dairy Products (Export Inspection Charge) Amendment Bill and the Dairy Products (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Amendment Bill. The dairy industry in my electorate is looking forward to 1 December, as indeed I am. I challenge the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) to repeat in my electorate his remarks about interstate milk. No one wants a milk war, least of all the farmers, because it will benefit no one. The one group of people who will lose out in a milk war are those in the dairy industry, regardless of the State. I will have great delight in circulating the speech the honourable member for O'Connor gave this evening to all the dairy producers, not only in my electorate but also in my new electorate, which will be Throsby, and in the electorates of Eden-Monaro and Gilmore. If the Opposition ever had any thought of getting a seat there it can forget it because it will not get any votes there when the dairy farmers see that the honourable member for O'Connor has been advocating an open milk war. We have captured the dairy vote in Macarthur; because of the speech of the honourable member for O'Connor we will also capture the dairy vote in the electorates of Gilmore and Eden- Monaro.

SPEECH.PARA: My electorate of Macarthur-soon to be Throsby-includes the dairying areas of Illawarra, Shoalhaven and the southern tablelands of New South Wales. While not considered a totally rural electorate, rural industry and dairying in particular provide much direct employment and support many communities within it. Figures for 1983-84 show that income to dairymen from sales of milk and milk products produced by dairymen in Macarthur totalled $33m. The industry in my electorate employs some 900 persons on farms, approximately 180 dairy factory operatives, and 90 vendors, most of whom have committed their lives to the industry.

The purpose of the dairy products Bills is to streamline the system. The establishments and goods prescribed under export orders will be categorised on the basis of product out-turn and inspection intensity, varied accordingly. The new inspection procedures will replace on line inspection during manufacture with a monitoring system involving sampling of the final product. One effect of these new inspection practices will be that a large quantity of the relevant prescribed goods will be exported without physical examination by the Export Inspection Service being necessary. In particular, this will apply to goods produced at registered establishments with a record of good quality control performance. The maintenance of good quality control by the registered establishments will be ensured through spot checks at will. It does not mean that a product will never be inspected or cannot be inspected. I think this is very important to ensure the good name of our export dairy products.

Another effect of the new practices will be that the inspection effort should decrease as the new system is progressively developed. It is expected that this will be reflected in reduced costs for the inspection service. In summary, it is proposed to introduce substantial changes to export inspection that are designed to make better use of resources more closely attuned to industry needs. These new procedures have been developed in close association with the industries concerned. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), who is at the table, always moves in close consultation with the industry. He does not often go off at a tangent. Anything he does in his portfolio is always done in close consultation with the industry. That is why he has such a high degree of respect in the industry and from the people on the land throughout Australia.

It is important to note that the Bills do not change the levels of charges. The Government is not introducing a new charge, or increasing charges. In fact, in the long term it will reduce charges. It will permit reliable producers to reap the benefits of the new inspection practices, which recognise that a lower level of inspection is appropriate to these places. These Bills will not affect producers in my electorate, as the dairy export industry is based mainly in Victoria, but I am most concerned that Australia have a rational dairy industry. More particularly, I have this concern because I was brought up on a dairy farm.

The alternative to this rational industry is a milk war which can have only disastrous consequences for the industry in the short and long term and for consumers in the long term. It is confidently predicted that if a milk war is allowed to develop, 40 per cent of dairymen will go out of business, regardless of which State they come from. If a milk war develops we will see milk producers going out of business in all States. Who will make up this 40 per cent? Those farmers most heavily into borrowing with fixed repayment commitments will feel the pinch. The reduction process will have no respect for State borders. The biggest worry is that those dairymen falling by the wayside will largely be in the younger age group, those on whom the future of the industry depends. I do not believe that we as a Parliament can allow this to happen. I reiterate that it is important, I believe, to note that the Bills do not change the level of charges, in case the Opposition thinks that they do. The Government is not introducing a new charge or increasing charges. As I said before, in the long term it will reduce charges. It will permit reliable producers to reap the benefits of the new inspection practices which recognise that a lower level of inspection is appropriate to those approved places. I commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure tonight to support the Opposition's amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Meat Export Charge Bill. Unfortunately, it is a second best option because we do not want these new taxes to be introduced at all. This amendment asks for their deferral for at least two years. Of course, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has never picked up the fact that this is what the industry wanted. He set up an inquiry to look into this problem and it recommended that the new charges be deferred for two years. When he received the report, like all good Ministers he put it in a pigeon hole and forgot about it. The industry was told that it had to cop the increased charges. So there has not been any deferral.

SPEECH.PARA: We ask that the Minister again look at this problem. The beef industry in Australia faces a tremendous problem now, particularly in regard to the number of unemployed in that industry. The Hawke Government is keen on boasting about the number of new jobs it has created. If General Motors-Holden's Ltd or the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd were in the same position as the beef industry and the abattoirs industry in Australia, the Government would be running cap in hand to help them. A total of 30,000 people are employed in the industry. Ten thousand of those workers are out of work. There are abattoirs in my electorate, such as Wallangarra, where a whole works has been closed down. Up to 30 works have been closed down.

TALK.START.PARA: —When did that close?
—Two or three years ago.
—Who was in government then?

—We may have been. We will be in government after 1 December, too . Government members can bet that they will not be in government then. We will be prepared to fix up the industry at that time. There is no way in the world that the present Government will be returned to office. I would also like to pick up some of the comments made by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Hollis). I cannot understand how he can allow the beef industry to operate under the free--
—I did not mention the beef industry.

—I thought that a milking cow had a bit of meat on it. I happen to be a cow cocky. I have pulled a few teats in my time. I thought that a dairy cow had a bit of meat on it. After it has been lovingly milked for 10 years, it is fattened up and sent to the works. But Government members think that the milk producers of this country ought to have some sort of crazy government setup whereby quotas are introduced. Yet the beef industry is one of the few industries that still operate under the private enterprise open system. There are no quotas or setups for beef. Beef can be traded interstate throughout Australia. The Victorian Government has tried in the last few days to set up easy trade between the States. The Wran Government, the Bjelke-Petersen Government and the Victorian Government are all to blame because they all have ridiculous State taxes and quotas whereby we cannot even trade among ourselves these days. That is how stupid it is. Only last week in regard to the grain industry the Minister reintroduced permits so that we can trade a bit of feed wheat. We were in the position where we could not even trade any wheat from our farms. We could not sell a grain of wheat from our farms unless we got permission from some government agency. I tell the Government that farmers in Australia are sick to death of it.

SPEECH.PARA: Many dairy farmers also will not support the introduction of the milk quotas. I do not agree with it, although some of my colleagues get a bit upset about it. I think that we have seen enough government interference in industry. This is what the inspection charge is all about. The Commonwealth bureaucrats now employed in the inspection service cost the beef industry $90m a year. It is costing $20m a year just to run the division. It is costing twice the amount of the Department of Primary Industry. Members on this side of the House have pointed out very adequately the amount of money involved as far as the beef producers are concerned.

As we know, the Minister offered a charge of $5.40 and that figure was reduced. The industry would not accept that charge, so he came back with a new charge, a flat rate of $4.35 on all cattle slaughtered, plus 2.5c on every beast that was hung for export. As the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) pointed out, that can amount to a lot of money. Some of the bullocks that come out of Maranoa weigh 1,000 lb dressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are big bullocks.

—They are big bullocks. Maranoa provides good fattening paddocks. Some of the Channel Country bullocks weigh at least 1,000 lbs dressed. The Minister has set a price that will cost about $14 just for the export fee plus $ 4.35, so he is looking at $18 to $20 a head. A decent Channel Country, Maranoa bullock will cost $20 a head to inspect. I think that that is an absolute disgrace.

SPEECH.PARA: All of these charges are passed back to the producer. In the long run the producer pays. Half of the amount is not paid by government. It is passed back to the producer and he must pay. The honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh) is a damn good shadow Minister. He has announced our policy-that is, that we will pay for all the charges. I believe that that is the way it should be. It should be paid out of Consolidated Revenue. How can we compete against these other countries? How can we compete against the United States of America, Canada and New Zealand? Why should not inspection charges, such as health inspection charges, be paid out of the public purse? Why should the beef producer pay it? It is no longer his product. The beast is sold at auction, yet this charge is passed back to him through a reduction in the price that the industry offers to him. Why should he bear that cost? Of course, the Minister has absolutely no support on this issue. A High Court action has been brought against him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who, the Minister?

—Yes. The Australian Meat Exporters Federal Council, the Australian Meatworks Federal Council, the Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia, the Cattle Council of Australia, the Cattlemen's Union, the Council of Australian Public Abattoir Authorities, and the Sheepmeat Council of Australia are opposed.
—He has the people on side.

—He does not have the people on side. That is nonsense. We will find out on 1 December just how many people he has on side. I tell Government members that there will not be a farmer in the country who will vote for Bob Hawke; no way. I do not believe that there should be an inspection service, but unfortunately this bureaucracy has been set up since we started selling beef to America. I believe it is high time that the Department and the Minister went to the American importers and asked them why we have to have this very expensive inspection service. It is a damn sight better than anything that is operating in the countries to which we are selling meat.
—They will sell kangaroos and goats as well.
—With regard to kangaroos, where is the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen)?
—He has gone out; he is not interested.

—I thought he was in charge of the House. The meat industry employs over 100,000 people. There are 30,000 people directly employed in the abattoirs in this country. The Australian Labor Party could not give a damn about them. Workers have been shifting out of abattoirs by the hundreds every week. The inspection service, of course, employs 180 people. The Minister knows that there are 180 meat inspectors sitting around Australia on full pay. That is costing the taxpayers of this country $6m a year.
—You appointed them.

—Maybe we did, but what is wrong with the Government? Why cannot it get rid of some of them? Why can it not rationalise the industry? Our exports have decreased. We have heard that cattle numbers have dropped from 34 million to 22 million. Numbers in the cattle industry have dropped by half. Why can it not rationalise a bit?
—Shooting or poisoning?

—Shoot them. Do anything to get rid of them. They must be thinned out a bit. What is wrong with that? The beef producer has to do that. How does he cope with this problem? He has to cut down on his staff. He has to cut down on his capital expenditure. What about the dairy farmer and the fellow who produces eggs? He has to cut down on his chooks. He cannot keep hundreds of employees hanging around. Of course, Mr Kevin Bartell, the Chairman of the Australian Meat Exporters Federal Council, stated publicly that the Government has been bad in all of the negotiations that he had with the industry. Of course , none of the producers is on the Minister's side in this regard. I only hope that the Australian Democrats, the National Party of Australia and the Liberal Party will block these Bills when they get to the Senate. I hope that they will throw them out.

SPEECH.PARA: We should go to an election showing how tough the Government is on this industry. No responsible person in the meat industry today is not opposed to what the Labor Government intends to do in this legislation. Inspection fees will cost the industry an extra $30m. Inspection fees are up from $31m in 1979- 80 to $90m. If we add up the amount of money spent on salaries and the administration of this service we will find that it now costs the industry overall $90m. The taxpayer is paying for half and the industry is paying the rest. The taxpayer is paying indirectly as it is coming from Consolidated Revenue. Overall the total cost is $90m.

I mentioned previously that 40 works are down. The Wallangarra works has closed . I would just like to put in a plug for one meat works which has actually opened in the last few months in Roma in my electorate. That works was able to be opened because of the contribution of the meat workers, such as the knifers. They put in some money to buy shares in the works and have got this works going. I congratulate the management, the unions and the people who work in this works at Roma. Let us hope that they keep the works going. I only hope that they can get enough cattle to do so. One of the biggest problems at the moment is that cattle numbers are down. Works are finding it very difficult to keep throughput up, costs down and make a profit. Of course, many big properties in the Maranoa electorate supply beef. As I mentioned, the Channel Country produces 800lb to 1, 000lb bullocks. The big properties there, such as Tanbar, Nappa Merry, Cameron Downs and Nockatunga, are the backbone of this country and supply thousands of head of export cattle. Queensland is the biggest export State, supplying over 50 per cent of the total exports of this nation. Of course, it is not easy for exporters to survive.

I might just mention to the Minister the enormous costs of the tuberculosis and brucellosis eradication program. This program is now being undertaken by the bigger cattle stations and they are having tremendous problems in getting rid of these diseases. I believe that governments ought to be looking again at the help they can give these people to try finally to clean up these diseases. Wild cattle have been shot out at great expense in the western part of my electorate. Work is now being undertaken at great expense to clean up the problem in the Gulf country. Private owners up there are having great difficulty in surviving.

I recently undertook a trip into Asia. I would like to mention the fact that the Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen) is very lax in signing the new meat agreement with Japan. I believe it is high time that the Labor Government signed the agreement. I just wonder how much longer it wants to negotiate and procrastinate. I was told two months ago in Japan that the agreement was just about to be signed. We still have not signed it. We still do not know where we stand with the Japanese. I think it is a disgrace that this has gone on for so long.

As I have said previously in the House, I believe we need to be looking at new markets in Asia. We have great competition there from the South American countries as they can now export meat to these places. Previously the Asian countries did not take meat from foot and mouth disease countries. Their governments have now allowed them to do this. We just cannot compete with the price that is being offered by them because of the fact that the inspection charge is being paid by those countries and because the workers in most of these countries are paid a lower wage than is paid in Australia. It is impossible for us to compete with many of these countries in the Asian market. I also believe that a very good market is opening up in China. I think that we ought to be doing more in this respect. I have spoken about this with Dick Austin, the new Chairman of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation. I hope the Minister follows up the fact that New Zealand and America are selling meat to Peking and we are doing nothing. Australian beef is not being delivered to these places and I think it is high time it was.

In closing, I would like to mention that I am sorry that the Minister responsible for the environment and all things beautiful has left the chamber. I wanted to mention to him that the kangaroos and wallabies in the Maranoa electorate are getting thicker than ever. There has been a strong call for more tags to be issued for kangaroos. Kangaroos eat out a tremendous amount of the beef and dairy pasture in my electorate. It is unfortunate that the Minister is not in the chamber at the moment as I was hoping that he would look at this problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about milk and eggs?

—I have a number of large hatcheries in my electorate and their owners are being asked to pay an increased inspection charge. It seems to me that these days one can do nothing without some bureaucrat being involved and some inspection charge being imposed. It does not matter where one goes or what one does, there is someone there to check, double check and check again. It does not matter where one's product is going. Eggs, dairy products and beef all have to be handled in this manner. I support the amendment, which states that this Government be called upon to delay the introduction of these excessive charges for at least two years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I wish to direct my remarks specifically to two pieces of legislation in this cognate debate, namely, the Dairy Products (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Amendment Bill 1984 and the Dairy Products (Export Inspection Charge) Amendment Bill 1984. In doing so, however, I note that the other pieces of legislation in this cognate debate relate to export charge increases in relation to the meat and egg industries. I express the same concern as the distinguished honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) as well as my other colleagues in the Opposition have expressed about the ever increasing spiral of export inspection charges as they apply to our agricultural exports.

SPEECH.PARA: We express this concern because it is becoming increasingly obvious that our agricultural products are being marketed in an international trade environment in which products from other nations are heavily subsidised and receive all sorts of export incentives, yet, we expect our primary producers, whom I and I am sure the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) regard as the most efficient and economical in the world, to deal on an unfair basis. I stress that Australian farmers are prepared to sell their products on the international market any time of the day so to speak so long as it is on a fair basis. For that reason, I oppose the legislation before the House, believing that it adds to the already heavy cost burden on the primary producers of Australia. It is certainly the Opposition's policy that all export inspection charges be done away with and the Commonwealth, by necessity, has to pick up the tab for that. This would certainly be a very wise investment by the Commonwealth in the future of our agricultural exports. Who in this chamber and outside this chamber can deny the importance of agricultural exports to the Australian economy? I do not for a moment, despite my heavy criticism of the Minister for introducing this legislation, believe that he would adhere to the view that Australia's agricultural exports are not an integral and very important component of Australia's economy.

Dairy products in particular have to compete with the unfair subsidies of other nations, particularly those of the European Economic Community and, in many instances, New Zealand. For that reason, to add increased export inspection charges to dairy products or to alter export inspection charges that could very well lead to an increase in the cost of dairy products further hinders the Australian dairy industry. We know that the Australian industry is suffering from ever increasing cheese imports from the EEC, not to mention imports of other dairy products from New Zealand, such as skim milk powder and ice cream. I might say, in passing, that the increase in the tonnage of sheep meat imported into Australia from New Zealand is of obvious concern to the Opposition. As with the imports of EEC cheese and New Zealand dairy products, we do not believe that the Minister has acted vigorously or quickly enough to stem the tide.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be aware, as all honourable members of this House would be aware, that the former Minister for Primary Industry, the Hon. Peter Nixon, set up a very efficient countervailing duty system that the Minister at the table, if he had the will, the energy or the interest, could certainly have used to prevent the dumping of EEC and New Zealand dairy products in Australia. Quite simply, it is my belief, and the belief of Gippsland dairy farmers, that the European Economic Community put it over the Government, not to put too fine a point on it, in negotiations last year, and it is necessary for the Minister at the table to renegotiate the arrangement he had last year with the European Economic Community.

There are many problems facing the Victorian dairy industry, particularly the Gippsland dairy industry, and none more so than cheap subsidised imports from the EEC and New Zealand as well as the importation of New Zealand heifers. As the Minister would be aware, I and other honourable members have made representations to him; yet we are reassured by the Minister that the importation level is not particularly high and, moreover, that the New Zealand heifers are of a high breeding quality. I find that logic very difficult to comprehend given the depressed state of the Gippsland dairy industry. There is no point whatsoever in importing cheap New Zealand heifers of very doubtful breeding quality. It makes sense that New Zealand will not send its best breeding heifers to Australia and the increase in the number of heifers can only lead to an increase in production, and that is a concern to all of us.

I believe that the Australian dairy industry also suffers from a failure of the Minister and the Government to promote our products vigorously in the Third World where I believe lies our greatest opportunity for expanding our export markets. This is particularly necessary given the recent devaluation in New Zealand which will make its exports somewhat cheaper and allow it to move into Third World markets. Again I call on the Minister more obviously or more vigorously to represent the interests of dairy farmers.

It goes without saying that the Victorian dairy industry is in a depressed state and that a number of dairy farmers in Gippsland and in other parts of Victoria face the prospect of bankruptcy if government assistance and government restructuring in the industry is not forthcoming. The Minister dragged his heels over the last 12 months when it was first pointed out to him that we were reaching a crisis stage. He has failed to take the necessary action to institute a restructuring that will benefit Gippsland dairy farmers. Concern for the dairy industry is shared by townsfolk in many Gippsland towns such as Yarram, Foster, Toora, Leongatha, Korumburra and Thorpdale and a number of areas such as Poowong North, because these areas depend on the dairy industry for their livelihood. Their future well-being is intertwined with that of dairy farmers. Of course, if there is a downturn in the income of dairy farmers these towns will suffer.

I notice that the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) has a grin on his face as if these are not matters of tremendous concern to a great many Gippslanders. Let me remind the honourable member for McMillan that unless assistance is forthcoming from the Government in the very near future-if it is not already too late-a number of small businessmen and people involved in the service industries in these towns in my electorate of Gippsland, as I am sure is the case in his electorate of McMillan, will be severely disadvantaged. Gippsland dairy farmers do not wish for a breakdown in the domestic dairy price structure. It is high time that the dairy industry in Australia was regarded a national dairy industry, as are all other agricultural industries. The Gippsland dairy farmers are a part of the largest and most efficient dairy industry-the Victorian industry-which wants to maintain a domestic price structure. After all , all farmers will suffer if there is a breakdown in this domestic price structure, but farmers in other areas of Australia are not as efficient as the Gippsland dairy farmers due to climatic and geographical differences.
Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Government members are delving into the realms of the ridiculous if they think there are any more efficient dairy farmers than Gippslanders. They are surrendering the interests of their own constituents, not to mention the interests of Gippsland dairy farmers, if they pretend otherwise. Mr Deputy Speaker, despite the fact that Gippsland dairy farmers are the most efficient in Australia, they receive only approximately half the incomes received by dairy farmers in New South Wales and Queensland. This is a system which discriminates actively against Victorian dairy farmers. There must be a recognition by dairy farmers in New South Wales, Queensland and South Australia that there is a problem in Victoria because the Victorians mostly export their milk products and there must further be a recognition of the need for a national dairy industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I see no logic at all in a government which stands idly by and witnesses the Victorian dairy industry suffering tremendous economic losses. I realise that the Minister has a number of constitutional, and perhaps even political, problems associated with the necessary introduction of a national dairy industry . Nonetheless, he is the Minister responsible. We have looked to him for several months-firstly, for a protection of the industry against cheap subsidised imports; and, secondly, for a recognition that there must be a national dairy industry. I am sure from my conversations with the Minister and his staff he acknowledges the latter. But I do not for a moment give him credit for moving firmly and quickly enough to ensure that Victorian-and Gippsland-dairy farmers do not continue to be severely disadvantaged under the present industry arrangements. I call upon the Minister to act swiftly, and with some compassion I hope, to alleviate these problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Notice Paper refers to some seven Bills which are the responsibility of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). They are the Meat Export Charge Bill, the Meat Export Charge Collection Bill, the Dairy Products (Export Inspection Charge) Amendment Bill and other associated Bills. I believe that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) should be present in the House tonight because this is not a matter relating to the Minister for Primary Industry; this is a matter relating to the Hawke Labor Government's tax policy, because in fact these export inspection charges are export taxes which are adversely affecting the international competitiveness of Australia's major export industries, namely , the rural industries.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe, as do all my colleagues in the National Party, that meat inspection charges should not be met by the industry. Meat inspection is a public health issue and its charges should be met out of Consolidated Revenue. It is an inspection which is provided for the general benefit of consumers, whether they be domestic consumers or export consumers. On that basis there is a justification for Consolidated Revenue meeting the cost of inspection for domestic consumption of beef and other meat and there is no justification for imposing what amounts to an export tax on the export of Australian meat.

In recent years there has been a notable conflict developing between members of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union and members of the Meat Inspectors Union. In recent years we have seen declining employment for members of the AMIEU in the meat industry but we have not seen a comparable decline in employment for meat inspectors throughout Australia. In fact, other speakers here tonight have mentioned that there are some 180 meat inspectors on the payroll in Australia at present who are not actively employed. I wonder how the retrenched members of the AMIEU feel about this job protection and guaranteed income policy which is implemented and perpetuated by this Federal Government because it does not have the courage to reduce staff numbers as the industry goes into a decline. What about the large number of retrenched slaughtermen in the beef industry? What about the sheep slaughtermen who have been laid off in recent years despite the efforts of former governments to keep them in employment? This Government is perpetuating the payment to meat inspectors to sit around and, I presume, do nothing because the Minister has not provided any explanation as to what they are employed in.

This raises the question of the cost efficiency of meat inspection. The Australian Meat Exporters Federal Council called a crisis meeting some months ago to discuss the impact of the Government's proposed inspection charges on the industry. In the paper that was presented by the Australian Meat Exporters Federal Council there is a section which addresses the cost efficiency of meat inspection in Australia. Basically this section highlights the fall in slaughter numbers and the escalating charge for meat inspection. In 1979-80 some 8.8 million cattle and calves and some 30.5 million sheep and lambs were killed. The total cost of meat inspection was $31m. In 1983-84 the cattle and calf kill had dropped to 7 million, a decline of some 20 per cent, and the sheep and lamb kill had dropped to 24 million, a decline of 21 per cent. But what happened to the cost of meat inspection? It is now $79m. I ask honourable members to remember that the cost in 1979-80 was $31m. For the benefit of the three Government members sitting on that side of the House--

TALK.START.PARA: —How many?

—There are three Government members and the Minister at the table. That increase in meat inspection charges is 150 per cent. The slaughter figures have declined by 20 per cent and 21 per cent respectively for cattle and sheep, but the cost of meat inspection has gone up 150 per cent. How can the Government possibly come to the House and introduce legislation which will increase the cost of meat inspection even further? Is it not aware of the plight of the Australian meat export industry? Is it not aware of the competitive pressures on us? Is it not aware that the New Zealand Government recently devalued the dollar ? Is it not aware that the Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen) has failed in his responsibilities on behalf of Australian meat exporters to negotiate successfully with Japan to ensure that our share of the Japanese market continues?

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that this Government is trying to convert the Australian meat industry into a domestic industry where there is gross over-supply so that the price of beef and other meat can be depressed artificially because we are no longer competitive on the international market. Then this Government can go to the people in the election and say: 'We have reduced the price of beef'. But in the process it will also reduce the Australian meat producer to poverty. In the past few years some 10,000 jobs have been lost in the meat industry. The size of the Australian cattle herd has declined from some 30 million to just over 20 million and 40 meat works have closed. What has happened to rationalise the meat inspection service in Australia to take account of this decline in the size of the industry both in absolute and relative terms? How can this Government seriously introduce legislation which will increase the cost of meat inspection and reduce our ability to export? I believe that this action by the Government is ill advised and will have a long term detrimental effect on the future of our industry. I have pleasure in supporting the amendment moved by the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My name does not appear on the agenda to speak to the Bills concerned, but I would appreciate the opportunity to speak briefly on a few of the matters that have been raised. I strongly support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh). We are so dependent in Australia today on the success of the primary industries and we are striking problems throughout the world, particularly with marketing, the costs at home and the effect of the European Economic Community, which has been mentioned by a lot of honourable members tonight. But we have to appreciate these facts and anything we can do as a parliament to assist the man upon the land should be done now. That is why the honourable member for Darling Downs has moved the amendment to the Meat Export Charge Bill, simply to ask that this levy be kept over for a certain time. I do not think that the primary industries of Australia are opposed to paying some of their share of the cost of inspection for export, but this must be determined on a basis that reflects the prosperity of those industries at this time. The man on the land today has no say whatsoever on the rising costs in the country and these are a paramount factor which concerns him. Naturally he is very concerned, particularly with exports.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) mentioned, we all have a great responsibility to promote our product at home. The beef and dairy industries have been doing their best to achieve this over the years. But surely there must be market opportunities throughout the world of which we can take advantage if we look a little further. That is why the Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen) has been somewhat condemned, because we have not taken advantage of a long term meat agreement with the Japanese. Our farmers, including the graziers, are happy if they know that the Government is doing something to get long term agreements wherever it can at a satisfactory price. The important factor is that no matter how the Australian economy is-if we have a recession or anything else-it has been proved over the last 12 months that the only way the economy can return is through prosperity in the primary industries.

A certain amount has been said tonight about the dairy industry. I did not intend to speak because I believe the debate has gone a little further than the Dairy Products (Export Inspection Charge) Amendment Bill, but I think some honourable members do not realise the situation in the dairy industry in Australia. The industry to date has been a State industry. It is only concerned from a national point of view with underwriting for export markets. Dairy farmers were numerous in years gone by, but their numbers have been cut drastically. They have been forced to reduce their numbers themselves, simply because of the profitability within the industry. The whole structure of dairy farming within Australia today has been based upon Acts brought into being by the State parliaments. I do not blame the farmers of Victoria or Tasmania for being envious of the market milk sales that farmers can make, particularly in New South Wales, Queensland, Western Australia and perhaps South Australia. To understand the industry one has to appreciate that farmers have invested their capital in stock, plant and land. As the honourable member for Gippsland pointed out, the dairy industry in Australia is as efficient, in dealing with our climatic conditions, as any other country in the world. We have kept our costs to reasonable levels. When the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) starts to talk about a national dairy industry-and I think he appreciates this because he and I have talked about it-any changes must be based on the structures that are there now.

It is natural that I should rise in the chamber to say that the dairymen in New South Wales, who number 3,000 or more, must receive some protection in a market they have pioneered at great cost over a long period. In any changes that are made the Minister must consider this. It disturbs me at times when we talk of a national dairy industry. I think I am correct in saying that the other States have co-operated with the Minister for Primary Industry over recent times to try to devise a system that will be acceptable to all the farmers throughout Australia. I supported the Dairy Farmers Association in New South Wales when it agreed that a levy of 1.4c to 2c a litre would be paid on all milk produced on the farm as long as entitlements were fixed within a scheme.

I was sorry to hear that, when the Australian Agricultural Council met the other day, the Minister for Primary Industry was not able to get general agreement between the States. I point out that it was the Minister of Agriculture in Victoria who would not agree to the scheme. I believe the farmers in the other States were most generous when they offered to contribute as long as certain safeguards were provided. They were prepared to assist a farmer suffering a low return because of the markets around the world. They actually agreed to assist him under certain conditions. All they asked for was a recognition that the markets are supplied for 365 days of the year and an assurance that the income of those dairymen would not be reduced accordingly.
