The contribution to the levy about which I have spoken, under a national farming scheme, means a payment of between $4,000 and $10,000 a farm in New South Wales. I wanted to make those points quite clear. When we talk about the dairy industry we have to understand how it has grown over the years, the way it has developed, and the investment and the work of the farmer. It must not be affected by any overnight move.

I conclude by saying that there are indications that the world markets for dairy products will improve over a period. At last the European Economic Community has taken some positive action to reduce its production. I believe it has been reduced by about 6.9 per cent over a six-month period. That is a sign that the EEC recognises that it is affecting the markets of the world, as it is with the beef industry, the sugar industry and all the other primary industries. Any plans that are being made now from a national point of view I hope will keep in mind and analyse properly the world situation. Perhaps then we will not have to do the things that are being talked about now-pulling down one farmer and building up another. We hope to reach a situation in which all the farmers will be built up, not only because of the domestic market within Australia but also because of the world scene.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The Government has allowed a rather wide ranging debate on these cognate Bills. They cover three industries and it is understandable that honourable members should want to focus on those industries rather than on the matters that are technically contained in the Bills. I start off by saying that it has been a night where Opposition members have slammed into the Government and the Export Inspection Service. It is fair enough for them to slam into the Government because it is the Government, of course, that has taken the decision with respect to the 50 per cent export inspection charge recoupment. However, as Minister for Primary Industry I will not tolerate all these cowardly attacks against the officials and the people in the Export Inspection Service. The Opposition has never really sought a briefing, during my term as Minister, of the Export Inspection Service and what is going on, the activity that has been carried out in my Department, and the negotiations with industry, the States and with the union.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Meynick, the Chairman of the interim Inspection Policy Council I set up, came to me at the end of the first study I gave him and said that he had the highest regard for the Export Inspection Service. The Opposition has also had a tonne of opportunity to put before the House its reaction to the corporate plan published by the Export Inspection Service which sets out a blueprint for its approach to the industries. The Export Inspection Service is not pinned in time. It is not a religion. It is an organisation that interacts with industries and has a relationship with the industries it is seeking to serve. I took the opportunity not so long ago to make a full statement to the House about this, and again the Opposition was concerned only to score cheap political points rather than put forward constructive views on how it thought the Export Inspection Service could better serve the industries. It is a service organisation and it is doing a very good job.

A lot of misinformation was given tonight by members of the Opposition. I was told that the service was costing $90m to the meat industry. It is costing about $75.6m and the industry will pay about $32m this year. With respect to the Export Inspection Service overall, there is a subsidy by the Government, by the taxpayers, of some $44m. It is all very well, when one is not taking any interest in the service itself and what it is doing, simply to promise that one will not charge the industry any more for the export inspection services carried out. Of course, that is the two-card trick again. The National Party of Australia will say that the industry can spend whatever money it wants to and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), will criticise the size of the deficit. So there is always this business of having things both ways.

I am not going to open up too much on the politics of it all. The previous Government really did nothing for the beef industry or the abattoir industry. Mr Fraser felt an early election coming on in 1977, when the beef industry was at its lowest. The Government brought in a beef incentive payment scheme, which had to be investigated by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. That was a slap-a- cow-on-the-buttocks scheme. During the life of the previous Government, 32 abattoirs were shut down. Under the present Government, some 89 have shut down. Nothing was done about it then. The Meat Council of Australia used to come to me and say that it was begging the Government to do something and eventually it got an Industries Assistance Commission inquiry. The IAC inquiry was pretty precise in looking at a commercial operation, and it was also looking at the overinvestment in the abattoir industry through the late 1960s and early 1970s. The Government took a decision shortly after it came to office. We did not go along with the move by the big operators in the industry to impose a levy because it would have had an adverse effect on the smaller abattoirs. The whole problem is lack of cattle. That, and very little else, is what is shutting down abattoirs.

If there was no export charge, would this stop rationalisation? Would it stop rationalisation if Elders bought out F. J. Walker Ltd and decided to close a plant or two? Would that stop because there is no export inspection charge? If we asked the industry whether if there was no export inspection charge, they would gain more markets, their eyes simply glaze and they say: 'We cannot predict that'. Of course they cannot predict it. They are dealing in a commercial environment. They are dealing in the real world. There is no sense in the Opposition bringing up the business of the recovery of 50 per cent as if it is magic or a creation of the Labor Government, which it continually parrots is anti-rural. At the time we came into office, the previous Government had had the 50 per cent charge policy in place for three commodities. It had indulged in all its anti-rural policies. If that is the criteria we intend to use to define what is anti-rural, the previous Government had in place export inspection charge recoupment for three commodities. The rest of its plan was proceeding as the Department and the Export Inspection Service gained an accurate costing of the service itself and were liaising with the States because the States carry out some services.

When we brought in the policy-I would have thought that the previous Government would have introduced it if it had continued in office- many allegations were being made by the industry which displayed a lot of ignorance of what was intended and what was being done. So I set up the interim Inspection Policy Council mainly to give the industry a window on the levels of cost, the systems of inspection, the procedures, and where we were heading with the service. So the industry itself had some idea of what it was all about. Of course this helped greatly in hosing down some of the industry's suspicion and the allegations that it was making.

This whole question has caused a lot of trouble. We have actually moved to save the industry quite a bit more money. Before I move away from the 50 per cent principle I would like to say that it is not just a public health measure; it is also a trade facilitation measure. The interim Inspection Policy Council said that the 50 per cent level of charging was fair. So let us not bandy all this nonsense around because it is a popular issue on which to run.

As a result of the 1983-84 Budget the Government put in place a charge relating to cattle of $5.40 a head. What it did after the Inspection Policy Council brought down its deliberations was put in place by regulation a charge of $4.35. In terms of this Bill we are asking for a split charge as recommended by the interim Inspection Policy Council. That will give a cost per head of cattle of $ 2.55 and a 2.4c a kilogram export component that is the split charge. This measure recoups the 50 per cent. There is no difference in the level of collection. It is simply a different system. The advantage of a split charge is that it stops diversion. In other words, it helps export works because it stops cattle and stock from being diverted from export works to domestic works. That was one of the most important things that we were thinking of.

If we look at the cost of getting a beast chopped up into mincemeat, steak, or whatever and on to the table, it costs about $160. For people seriously to suggest that some $3.60 or some $2.55 will be the defining amount of money that dictates whether or not an export abattoir or any other abattoir is financial, they are really having themselves on. If we look at the impact of devaluation over recent months, that has had far greater benefit than the additional impost of the charge. All I am saying is that it is not that it is not a real cost but that some of the allegations being made about its impact are really trying to put the blame for a very basic problem somewhere else. We do not really know where the charge falls, whether it be on producers, consumers or processors, or whether it falls on all three. It just depends on whether the market is rising or falling. What we are doing here tonight is saving the industry $6m.

A lot of nonsense has been spoken about the number of meat inspectors who are not working and are being paid. This Bill makes sure that the industry does not pay for people who are not being utilised in the Export Inspection Service. The allegation has been made that I did not put all the recommendations of the interim Inspection Policy Council to the Cabinet. I did not put them in terms of recommendations but all the recommendations in the report were discussed by the Cabinet. The interim Inspection Policy Council has no more status than the Industries Assistance Commission, a Senate committee of inquiry or any other committee which makes a report to the Government. In other words, it is not the Government itself.

The reasons why we did not go for a two-year moratorium or retrospectivity are related to the Budget. That is not to say that the interim Inspection Policy Council report was not fully discussed. At the time we discussed it some 84 per cent of the abattoirs were not paying. They were threatening to take me to the High Court of Australia and they wanted a $14m concession. But it was not those arguments that weighed on our minds; it was simply the budgetary considerations plus the fact that the Government had taken the decision that the 50 per cent recoupment was fair, and the interim Inspection Policy Council itself had said that. So this issue was fully considered by Cabinet and it was considered again the other night by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) when a delegation came to see him.

Honourable members opposite have been saying that this proposal could not have come at a worse time. At present we have a rising market and the herd is rebuilding. So what they are saying is that a better time to put on a charge like this is when there is a falling market and the herd is diminishing. That is the corollary to the argument being put by honourable gentlemen opposite.

I will comment on the question of overseas countries' practices. The United States of America does recover the costs incurred in providing an export inspection service when those services exceed the basic services provided for mandatory inspection for domestic consumption because the United States exports something less than 20 per cent of its meat. There are charges in Argentina, Ireland, the United Kingdom, West Germany, France, Denmark, the Netherlands, Sweden and Japan. There are some minor charges in New Zealand and I will not go into that. New Zealand is a competitor. It is heavily dependent on exports of rural products for foreign exchange and the New Zealand Government takes a decision in that regard. We do not know how long that will continue. It is up to the other Government. In regard to the whole question of meat inspectors being on full pay, I have said here and I have said many times that they are public servants and they are on full pay.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sack them. Rationalise.

—It might be all right for the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh) to say we should sack them, rationalise, shoot them or whatever. The fact is that it takes up to 12 months to train these people and the meat industry has no hesitation in making a demand on the Government as it did in earlier years, that we instantly provide meat inspectors. When people with a high degree of skill and dedication are being posted out of seasonal works and are required to go to remote locations, it is not as if one can turn such a work force off as if its members are day labourers. They are skilled people. We are arranging transfers where we can. We are giving additional training to people who are not currently engaged in inspections and putting them through various programs. We are trying to get retirements from age 55 onwards and we are being more flexible in our procedures for hiring and trying to negotiate that issue through.

SPEECH.PARA: One honourable member commented about my statements to the New South Wales Rural Press Club about savings of $12m. I was referring there to practices and procedures which are in train, some of which were touched on in the corporate plan-no one has commented on that tonight-and which we think shall take place over the next two years and will give us those savings. That is what we are working on.

The honourable member for Darling Downs really stunned me by talking first of all about the Export Inspection Service. As far as the meat industry was concerned he said it was all right simply to sack people but when it came to the dairy industry he said we could not sack them straight away; we were moving too fast. It really seems to me that it depends on who talks to him last and asks for his advice. That is why the policy of the Opposition is really a wish list. He is saying it is all right to sack meat inspectors but not dairy inspectors.

What we are about is trying to maintain food standards and to cater for customer requirements. We are trying to get a system of services and better uniformity. At some stages the Opposition is saying that it does not want inspectors. Sometimes it is saying it does not want monitoring and at other times it is saying we should ignore the requirements. We really have to look at each case industry by industry, but there has to be some principle.

The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) was basically critical because he is opposed to moves to get a national meat inspection service. Other honourable members do not seem to acknowledge the fact that inherently there is cross-subsidisation in all of those matters and if one moves from one level of cross-subsidisation to another, from big works to little works, from seasonal works to full time works, there will be a need to negotiate with industry and the work force itself. In the past when there was not as much of a recoupment, works would make a request for inspection. They were not conscious of savings that were available and still are available in some works. At least the advantage of the 50 per cent recoupment is that the industry itself is involved in the practices.

With respect to dairying and eggs, some substantive points were made by some people. I point out that the quality control systems are being trialled and will not be finalised for about three months. However, in tandem with this, we are also looking at how we can work better with the States and give more responsibility to industry for quality grading, of which the honourable member for Darling Downs was critical. But if we do not proceed with the legislation now, it will mean that new inspection procedures will be delayed until the next sitting. That is not just a threat; that is simply information. Dairy inspection will reduce and charges will align with the new inspection practices.

The honourable member for O'Connor made substantial allegations in his usual fashion. He said that we did not do much about the recommendations in the report of the Woodward Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry. In fact 48 of the 55 recommendations are in hand or have been acted upon completely. All sorts of sizes of beasts were mentioned in the House tonight. The average beast that goes through export abattoirs is about 130 kilograms boned out. The biggest beast for Queensland and the northern export works-some of these Maranoa bulls--

TALK.START.PARA: —Point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker. We have 1,000 lb bullocks in Maranoa.
—There is no point of order.

—They bone out at about 240 kilograms. One honourable member made the calculation of $20. That would give 750 kilograms boned out, which would mean about 1,120 kilograms boned in. I suggest to him that that is a bigger beast than a Maranoa beast. It would be more like a McMillan beast-one of those big rangy Friesians. The honourable member for O'Connor also wanted another system. He does not really understand the real world. If he believes that meat works will do it properly, he has another think coming. He mentioned something about Northam. The Western Australian domestic system is really four systems and is basically carried out by the Department of Health.

SPEECH.PARA: An allegation was made tonight that costs have blown out. The money cost of inspection has been contained since April 1983. The requirement for export inspectors has reduced from about 1,690 to 1,430. At present we have a surplus of 110, if the Opposition wants the figures. But they are not paid for by the industry. The honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) made a comment that it was up by 150 per cent. This is due to the Woodward recommendations and the irresponsibility of the previous Government. It is due to the takeover of the New South Wales service and it is due to inflation. Some allegations were made about more substitutions. I simply point out that any allegations should go to the Australian Federal Police. There were allegations about current industrial action, which has been resolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the dairying Bills.

—I do not think I have time for that one. To touch quickly on the hen levy, this will continue until June 1987. The current collection of about $20m is primarily for equalisation. There is only about $250,000 per annum for industry contribution to research. The cost of collection is $500,000. So if it is continued for research only, the cost of collection will be double the amount to be collected. Therefore, we are moving to alternative research funding.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) made some comments about cheese imports into this country. Last November the industry made an application for countervailing duty in respect of cheese imports. After much extensive consultation the European Economic Community signed a price undertaking under which it agreed not to disturb the Australian market and to reduce export subsidies by around $800 per tonne. Due to several factors, including the EEC policy of pre-fixing export subsidies, the impact of the price undertaking has not yet shown up fully in import statistics. I will write a letter to the honourable gentleman about that.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr McVeigh's amendment) stand as part of the question.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

Original question resolved in the affirmative.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
'the House is of the opinion that the Bill should not be proceeded with until early 1985 when the proposed changes to export inspection practices for dairy products are introduced'.

DEBATE.TITLE: DRIED VINE FRUITS EQUALIZATION AMENDMENT BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILLS:
CANNED FRUITS MARKETING AMENDMENT BILL 1984
CANNED FRUITS LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1984
CANNED FRUITS LEVY COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1984 [No. 2]]
Debate resumed from 13 September, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill, the Canned Fruits Marketing Amendment Bill 1984, the Canned Fruits Levy Amendment Bill 1984 and the Canned Fruits Levy Collection Amendment Bill 1984 [ No. 2] as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate on these four measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australian fruit growers are people within our community who not only contribute much to the wealth of out nation, but who are also particularly vulnerable to effects often beyond their control, especially to the international markets. This series of Bills, concerning both the canned fruits and dried vine fruits industries, is fundamentally administrative in nature. Of course, we in the Opposition were extremely disappointed that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) in introducing the legislation did not know what he was talking about and faced the supreme ignominy of having to come into the House and admit that and introduce the correct piece of legislation. I just make that comment in passing.

SPEECH.PARA: It is wrong for a government to try to concertina legislation through this Parliament in the closing stages when we do not have the opportunity of debating matters which are of great importance to rural industry. I think it indicates a haphazard approach to government by the Minister and by the Australian Labor Party, particularly with respect to rural industry, that they cannot even bring in the correct piece of legislation. However, in indicating that the legislation is fundamentally administrative in nature, I am not advocating compliance. Much more has to be done to adequately assist these industries in their bid to help rationalise. Both these industries, although initially appearing similar, are actually very diverse in nature and more particularly in their manner, and methods advised for assistance in rationalisation within the industry.

The canned fruit industry is an industry described, according to the Australian Labor Party agricultural policy as '. . . in 1980 saddled with deep rooted, chronic problems'. Prior to the introduction-not by this present anti-rural, anti-people Government-of the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation, the industry was experiencing a dramatic increase era without statutory marketing control. The Australian Canned Fruits Corporation was developed to undertake responsibility for regulation, marketing and promotions of canned deciduous fruits both domestically and overseas. Operations for administration and, more importantly, promotions are presently financed by means of a levy on canned fruits. The industry was labouring under tremendous internal bickering, destructive competition and selling in unprofitable markets where returns often only just covered costs of production. The larger the output, the greater the loss. Rationalisation was essential for the industry's survival and, by eliminating these unnecessary additional internal pressures, progressive changes within the industry became possible.

The Corporation provided, and is still providing, the stability necessary in the industry for progressive marketing policies to be implemented by providing the foundation on which valid attempts at cutback in production are being achieved. There is little doubt that the massive declines in canned deciduous fruit production can be attributed to the successful operations of the Corporation. Since the commencement of the Corporation, the industry has contracted by more than 33 per cent. Although painful, this was very necessary. In 1979, canned deciduous fruit production output, measured in basic cartons, was 7,500. This was when the Corporation was introduced. By 1982 it was down to 4,083 and by 1983 only slightly more.

Against a background of economic recession, the maintenance of sale volumes is regarded as satisfactory and has been achieved essentially by, first, increases in promotional expenditure and, secondly, the decision by the Corporation that, notwithstanding cost increases, prices would not reflect those new costs. Vital to maintaining sales at a satisfactory volume and price are effective promotions and advertising. It is essential to note that, when other grocery products are heavily promoted in virtually every market, canned fruit must compete for its share of consumer spending.

It is pleasing to note that the Minister has seen fit to continue the operation of the Corporation for another three years until 1987. We give an undertaking that at that time we will favourably consider a request from the Corporation and the industry to extend the period for another two years. It is regrettable that the Minister has not seen fit to agree to the request of the industry for that extension. I indicate that on our return to government we will favourably consider that request to allow the appropriate readjustments to continue.

The Minister has also allowed for the expansion of the Corporation's borrowing powers, permitting it to raise finance by more contemporary financial instruments, and its ability to operate on the futures market for hedging purposes. However, great concern is felt within the industry, as I indicated previously, over the length of this extension. It feels that three years is too short and would prefer, rather, a five-year extension, ensuring that the ongoing rationalisation in the industry can be substantiated until the industry can stand on its own feet, that being in five years, not three. It is the Opposition 's policy to maintain lengthy negotiations and input with the industry, not only to consider short term implications of government action but also long term implications.

Turning now to the dried vine fruits amendment proposals, I am pleased to say it is one of the rare opportunities I am afforded as Opposition spokesman to commend this Bill to the House. The proposed amendment will allow the current equalisation scheme to operate more efficiently by minimising interest costs on at least 50 per cent of fruit subject to the levy and by cutting cash flow delays, thus effectively maximising returns to growers. In understanding the importance of equalisation to the dried vines industry, it is necessary to note the industry's unique structure; that is, the homogeneous nature of the product, small land holdings operated by a concentration of some 3,500 farmers, and the excessive dependency on volatile world markets which serves to place individual members of the industry in a very weak bargaining position. This, coupled with the soldier settlement background, promotes a close knit community in which equity of returns for like quality products is essential. Equalisation is an effective machine for bringing relativity between export and domestic markets. Noting the industry's present financial circumstances where growers have for the month of June the lowest ever unpaid equity in fruit proceeds, every effort should be made by government and industry alike to maximise cash flow and returns to growers.

The agreed amendment still allows the levy to be paid from sale proceeds. It does, however, ensure that there are no unnecessary delays in the distribution of equalisation payments, recognising that cash flows significantly faster than 105 days in the case of many sales. It is difficult to estimate the effect on cash flow from packeted fruit in changing from 105 days to 45-days packer-agent- packeter. Nevertheless, approximately 50 per cent of fruit subject to the levy is sold in bulk form with an anticipated cash flow period of 30 to 40 days. The 105-day rule was introduced with regard to the worst possible cash flow situation and the need for levy to be paid by packers from proceeds of sales without resource to further borrowing. When the present 105-day amendment was introduced, the industry enjoyed much healthier financial circumstances than it does at present.

We are all aware, and cannot deny, that there are many industries in difficult, potentially crippling circumstances, an experience not foreign to many Australian rural producers, especially those in the dried vine industry. Real and effective assistance is necessary, which will take account not only of balance sheets, but also the unquantifiable welfare cost. Although statistically non-measureable, it nevertheless carries a cost. Of particular concern is the pending Industries Assistance Commission report into the dried vine fruits industry. Community effects are difficult to assess, a fact that the industry as well as this humane Opposition are more than aware of; the compassionless Government perhaps not so.

We are concerned with people, not with rationalising their welfare. Human tragedy and misery are immeasurable. We cannot rationalise emotions and morale. What account does this Government make for people? None of these social effects can be readily quantified, yet all are a real cost, particularly to those involved. The inability of analysts to measure these effects should not be a reason for failing to recognise them. This Government has a worrying tendency to overlook any social consequences in framing its rural policies. The Government appears to be not only uninformed but also of the very misguided opinion that, because one is a farmer, one is a millionaire. Urban dwellers do not have a monopoly on poverty. It is about time the Hawke Government was not only made aware of this but also began to act on it, particularly in the case of the dried vine fruitgrowers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few comments in this debate on the canned fruit Bills. I do not claim to have a canned fruit industry in my electorate but I am particularly interested in the canned fruit industry and, for that reason, have decided I would like to take part in this debate. As the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) would know well-and I think the honourable member for Murray will be taking part in this debate-the industry has gone through a very tough period during the last few years. There has been a very dramatic restructuring of the market demand for its products. There is little doubt that the industry has gained considerably from the implementation of the Canned Fruits Marketing Act 1979. Nevertheless, a number of problems have arisen regarding the financial and marketing arrangements of the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation. The purposes of the amendments in these pieces of legislation are to improve the viability and operations of the Corporation and, in the case of the two minor Bills, to remove anomalies that militate against the interests of the canneries and, as a consequence, of course, the growers.

SPEECH.PARA: The simple amendment included in the Canned Fruits Levy Amendment Bill corrects anomalies that could certainly arise in the Canned Fruits Levy Act 1979. The purpose of the amendment is to ensure that a single levy rate will apply to the cannery intake and canning of apricots. With the apricot season beginning in December the current definition of 'season' lacked any relationship to the reality of the canning season for such deciduous fruits. Clause 8 of the Canned Fruits Marketing Amendment Bill now envisages that inclusion of a Part IVA requiring the preparation of a corporate plan and annual operational plans. This requirement is for a period of three years. In other words, it has the quality of a sunset clause. I believe that we can now expect an even more commercially beneficial role for the Corporation.

Some time ago my colleague the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) and I had the good fortune to receive an invitation to visit the Ardmona cannery at Mooroopna in Victoria. Naturally we readily accepted the invitation on behalf of the Caucus primary industry committee and, I might say, on our own behalf as well because, being Victorians, we were very interested in Victorian primary industry. We were both particularly impressed by the very innovative, progressive and businesslike management controlling the company. For some time the canned fruit industry has been suffering from a change in such things as people's eating habits, together with competition in export markets, as mentioned by the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh). I was impressed by the sound market research and by the preparedness of the company to respond to the need to develop new products and to create new markets for innovatively packaged traditional products. I was particularly impressed by the range of products which use natural fruit without any additional sugar. To give it a plug, the product Rippa, a very fine soft drink made entirely of natural fruit, is certainly deserving of people's attention.

As was indicated, this industry has been hit very severely by a number of factors such as the changing tastes and eating habits of people, the labour intensive nature of the industry, the need to change products to overcome unit cost increases and, of course, the tremendous impact of the overseas market problems. It is particularly vulnerable to movement in costs and in market demands as well as in market access. It is also an industry that has to carry the effects of its seasonal factors. The need to finance stocks for up to 12 months makes the industry very vulnerable to upward trends in interest rates. Therefore, it is fortunate that, with the improvement in economic conditions brought about by the sound management policies of the Hawke Labor Government, the industry should benefit from lower interest rates.

The decline in traditional export markets and the long established subsidies provided by the European Economic Community have placed further pressure upon the industry. The vagaries of the climate only compound the potential problems of the industry. For instance, it was anticipated that the Australian canned fruits industry would be able to fill the gap caused by the failure of the United States crop in 1984. I would like to read a passage from page 4 of the 1983 annual report of the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation. The report states:

At the beginning of 1984 the industry was optimistic about being able to take advantage of a world shortage of canned peaches and fruit cocktail because of crop failures in the U.S.A. However it is regretted that the industry will not be able to take up the advantage of this situation because the crops of peaches in all peach growing areas of Australia were drastically affected by weather conditions and 'brown rot' disease. The expected intake of peaches for canned fruit is now approximately 30,000 tonnes against a budgeted requirement of at least 45,000 tonnes.

Factors such as that really make forward planning particularly difficult in such an industry. One of the provisions contained in the amending Bill should assist the individual marketers by providing them with marketing incentives. The ACFC will now be authorised to permit marketers to retain premiums realised on sales that are higher than the minimum prices set by the Corporation and the excess proceeds need not be remitted to the Corporation to be equalised with other proceeds for distribution to canners. It will be of considerable benefit to the marketers that the same provision will apply to non-pool sales as well as pool sales. In both cases this will provide an incentive for marketers.

The changes that are envisaged in this legislation are not disruptive to the effective operation of the industry and the Corporation. In fact, they should be quite the contrary. I congratulate the Minister for having consulted with the industry so thoroughly and so closely. Of course, this shows just what a very fine Minister we have in the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). In the main these changes reflect the wishes of the industry and should be beneficial to it. There has been an improvement in the orderly marketing of the industry since the Corporation was developed. This, of course, has resulted in a very strong sense of co-operation. The Government hopes that with the refinement of the legislation, this co-operation might be maintained and strengthened. I take pleasure in commending the legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing tonight in a cognate debate with the Dried Vine Fruits Equalization Amendment Bill 1984, the Canned Fruits Marketing Amendment Bill 1984, the Canned Fruits Levy Amendment Bill 1984 and the Canned Fruits Levy Collection Amendment Bill 1984 (No. 2).

SPEECH.PARA: The dried vine fruit industry legislation proposes to accelerate payments to growers and the canned fruits industry legislation is designed to extend the life of the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation. The honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh) has already given the statistical background to the dilemmas that face both these industries. In supporting the legislation before the House, the Opposition recognises that neither proposal will cost the Commonwealth money and, of course, neither is opposed by the Opposition.

It is appropriate that tonight we should deal with these Bills in a cognate debate because they cover industries which, while very different, have very similar problems. They cover industries that are located in similar geographical areas-from the Riverland in South Australia to the Sunraysia and the Golburn Valley in the eastern States. I make no apology for standing tonight in defence of these industries. Too often they are seen as peasant industries when in reality they occupy part of what is the fourth largest primary industry in Australia. It is only as a result of skilful scientific application of primary industry knowledge, such as, for example, selective plant breeding and, as a result, increased production over the last decade, that either of these industries has been able to survive. That is my first point.

The second point I want to make is that these industries are quality industries . They survive in Australia because Australia's quarantine regulations are so strict. We consequently produce quality fruit. They survive in Australia because the fruit is grown in veritable Gardens of Eden. They are grown steeped in sunshine. They are grown efficiently by any world standards. Thirdly, the dried vine and canned fruits industries are export orientated. They are not industries which seek support or protection in order to survive in the Australian domestic market. These industries grew to meet an export demand and they generate valuable export dollars.

Fourthly, these are industries which face subsidised competition and much of the overseas competition that these industries face is non-tariff barrier competition. The competition receives low interest loans or grants to enable it to occupy export markets that were historically occupied by the Australian crop. Fifthly, these industries face the real threat of imports because as subsidised production occurs overseas so it becomes more and more difficult for the Australian market to be insulated from the reality of subsidised markets overseas.

The honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren) had a great deal to say about why these industries have been in demise. But he failed to touch on the fundamental point that these are industries with long lead times. The dried vine fruit industry and, even more acutely, the canning fruit industry in Australia are facing permanent demise unless growers are encouraged to plant trees. Even with the best will in the world and the best horticultural information we have available to us, it is not possible to put a tree into production under four or five years. Unless we encourage people to stay in the industry we will lose a valuable export earner for Australia.

These are labour intensive industries, which, by primary production standards, require relatively low capital to get into. These industries are occupied by our characteristic Aussie battler. They were commenced originally by soldier settlers and in many instances have now been taken over by migrants who have come to us from European countries. It is in defence of these industries and these people, who are prepared to work and commit their families to heavy work schedules, that the Government needs to be acting now.

The problem with these Bills is not that there is anything wrong with them but that they do nothing to address the basic problem facing Australia's horticultural and viticultural industries. It is all very well for the honourable member for Ballarat to talk about falling interest rates but that is only the tip of the iceberg. The real problem facing these industries is that we have ceased to be competitive overseas because our wage costs and our on-costs are so exorbitantly high compared with those of our overseas competitors.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you bash the workers all the time?

—I am not intentionally bashing the workers; I am facing the uncomfortable dilemma that we are being priced out of overseas markets by a government that is at present before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission arguing in favour of an 8.3 per cent increase in wages over and above indexation. It is that sort of action from the Government which will ensure that the industries I represent tonight will face a further demise. It is not the simplicity of low interest rates, as outlined by the honourable member for Ballarat; it is the reality of living beyond our means.

SPEECH.PARA: These are labour intensive industries. There is work to be done. In Australia today there are unemployed people. These industries need a government which is prepared to be imaginative about the way it gets work done in labour intensive industries and about the way it goes about promoting fundamentally healthy foods designed for a healthy Australia. It is simply not good enough to bring these Bills into the House without further positive steps to support these labour intensive, long lead time industries. I take the liberty of quoting from a Press release by the then shadow Minister for Primary Industry on 12 May 1982. Mr Kerin, talking about the then Federal Government, said:
All the Federal Government could think of to help canning fruit growers was an IAC Inquiry . . .

Since this Government came to office the assistance that the canning fruit growers have received has been two Industries Assistance Commission inquiries into the dried vine fruit industry, one into the canning industry, and nothing else. Just a little bit of imagination in terms of what could be done for these industries, just a look again at what we could do, for example, in the area of food aid when we are talking about dried vine fruits, would mean that these growers would have an opportunity to believe that there could be a future for the industry. There could therefore be good reason for orchard and vineyard regeneration which, as I have said, will take up to five years.

TALK.START.PARA: —You fellows had seven years and you did nothing.

—I remind the interjector that he is currently in government. I conclude by saying that I have sat in this House and heard the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) suggest that because there may be no surpluses in the wine industry the viticulture industry will be out of trouble. The fact that there are no surpluses means nothing at all. Only last weekend I was in my electorate and witnessed frost damage to dried vine blocks-to sultana grape patches-and that very frost damage will ensure that there are no surpluses. That frost damage will do nothing to relieve the acute problems facing dried vine fruit growers.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased that these Bills are before the House, but they do nothing to address the fundamental problems that the growers I represent face every day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Dried Vine Fruits Equalization Amendment Bill and cognate Bills represent once again the contempt that the Government has for Australia's rural industries. Five Bills are being rushed through the Parliament tonight. Last week we saw 13 Bills rushed through here before about 1.20 a.m. We are seeing this mad rush by the Government to get to the polls mainly because of the fear it has of the activities of its friends in the New South Wales Government, or because of this Government's taxing policies, or because of the assets test that we know will have a major impact upon the people involved in these horticultural industries, or even perhaps because of the decline that we know will develop in relation to economic activity throughout Australia in 1985.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I wish to speak only to the Dried Vine Fruits Equalization Amendment Bill, which is supported by the Opposition. As we all know a levy is imposed on dried fruit that is sold on the Australian market. The levy proceeds from each season's crops are then redistributed to producers pro rata according to their total production in that season. The levy is payable by the packer of that fruit . In his second reading speech the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) said :

The Act presently provides that the levy becomes due for payment three months and 14 days after the month in which the leviable fruit ceased to be in the custody of the packers. This time lapse was provided at the request of the industry to provide time for the packer to receive the proceeds of a sale before being required to pay levy on that sale. In particular, it was designed to cover situations where a packer sent fruit to another firm for re-packing.

The Australian Dried Fruits Association, on behalf of the industry, has therefore requested this amendment to the due date so that provisions will be aimed at speeding up levy collections and disbursements while still allowing reasonable time for packers to receive sales proceeds before the levy is due. The Dried Fruits Association rightly claims that under the present circumstances there are many instances where packers receive the proceeds of domestic sales well in advance of the due date for the levy payment.

The first change that we see in this Bill is one that will provide that the levy is to become due for payment one month and 14 days after the month in which the fruit leaves the packer's custody. This, of course, is to replace the present provision for a delay of three months and 14 days as I have already mentioned. The second change will provide that the dried fruit:

Shall be taken to continue to be in the custody of the packer so long as it is in the custody of, or is in transit to, an agent appointed by the packer to sell the dried fruit, or a person to whom the dried fruit is to be sent by the packer for repacking on behalf of that packer.
As indicated the proposed amendments will expedite the payment of levies into the Consolidated Revenue Fund and the consequent redistribution of equalised moneys to the industry.

As can be seen, the changes that are being made are minor and they will be of very little help to an industry that is in crisis. Looking at the actions that have been taken over the past few months, as outlined by the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), one gains the impression that rather than assisting any producers in our grape industries the Government is seemingly doing them greater harm.

On 13 September I asked the Minister for Primary Industry a question in the Parliament. I asked him whether he agreed that the crisis in the grape industry would be further aggravated by the sales tax that was placed on wine in the last Budget and whether a drop in horticulturalists' income from $290 a week to $153 a week in a two-year period was considered as satisfactory. I also asked the Minister why he had instigated an inquiry into the grape industry before placing this further impost on it. I also referred to the rural adjustment scheme.

The Minister's reply indicates the sort of ad hoc measures that have been taken by the present Government in relation to our horticultural industries. He said that he fully stood behind the Government's decision to implement a wine tax. He justified this decision by saying that with or without the tax the industry was in a great mess, and that the inquiry that he had instigated had come about not as a consequence of the wine tax but because of the problems from which the industry was suffering. He also made the unbelievable statement that the wine tax that was introduced in the Budget was a tax not on growers but on consumers. I simply ask the Minister to take account of the reduction in wine intake that was caused as a result of the ill-advised fortified wine tax that was brought in last June, over 12 months ago, and which had to be removed. I believe that the Minister will also find that the implementation of this sales tax on wine will simply also ensure that the overall effect on the grape growing and wine industries is just as destructive.

Recent statistics in relation to the grape growing industry show that in the last year the wine grape harvest was estimated at 510,000 tonnes, as compared with 531,000 tonnes in the previous year. The 1983-84 estimate is slightly above the record of 502,000 tonnes of grapes produced in 1979-80. The table grape harvest is estimated at about 31,000 tonnes, after a then record 26,000 tonnes in the previous year. These figures indicated that the total grape harvest could well be about 870,000 to 880,000 tonnes. That will create enormous difficulties for the industry, be they in the dried fruit area or the wine making area.

As I have said, none of the measures taken by this Government has been designed in any way to alleviate the great social and economic problems in the industry. I think that we all recognise, particularly those of us who come from the horticultural areas and the regional fruit growing areas, that the effect is not just on the growers; it is on the rural towns, on the great regional centres, and on the total economic viability of whole areas. As the honourable member for Riverina (Mr Hicks) would know, it is the people in the Murray Valley, the Sunraysia areas, on both the Victorian and New South Wales side of the river who will be affected by the present crisis in the grape growing regions of Australia .

We all know the reasons for the difficulties in the industry. We know the problems that have been caused by the allowance by this Government of cheap imports to come on to the Australian market. We heard the honourable member for Wakefield refer to the problems related to internal costs in Australia and the comparison of wage costs in this country as compared with those of our major competing nations, Greece and Turkey. We know about the costs associated with protection of our machinery manufacturers and of our input costs, such as chemical costs, which affect the viability of our local growers in meeting and competing with those of other nations.

What concerns me more is that we have had so many inquiries that have been aimed at the bringing down of reports on and recommendations in respect of this industry, but very little action has been taken and there have been significant delays in any government assistance to it. I believe that the recent Industries Assistance Commission inquiry was a waste of time. It was a waste of resources by both the industry and the Government. The draft report was tabled in this Parliament some time late in February of last year. It has provided nothing to growers and it does not give any of the growers in our grape growing areas any confidence in their future or in the future viability of their industry. I admit that the problems in the industry are not the Government's fault, but it is certainly the Government's fault that we have seen little or no action in the months since the IAC draft report was tabled.

What did the Minister say on the tabling of that report which recommended against any provision of short term assistance to the dried vine fruit industry in the 1984 season? The Minister said that after the harvest was over the Government would have a clear indication of the immediate financial situation of growers and he mentioned the possibility at that time that carry on loans might be provided to producers under the rural adjustment scheme, once again, after the harvest had been completed. However, he added that that would very much depend on the evidence available at the time. I put it to him that we have had plenty of evidence that assistance is needed. We are now about to have another vintage, another harvest, in the grape growing areas, and nothing has been done of any consequence to assist those growers who are suffering such difficult economic and social circumstances.

The Australian Dried Fruits Association has indicated very clearly to the Government the sort of range of measures that could be undertaken to assist the industry through its difficult time. For instance, it has suggested that the Australian market should be retained for Australian growers against the increasing threat of cheap imports. The ADFA believes that better and more prompt support should be provided through the Dried Sultana Production Underwriting Act 1982 and it is particularly disturbing to me that dried sultanas today receive only a 90 per cent underwriting return, while underwriting commodities, such as the wheat industry which we debated in this Parliament last week, receive a 95 per cent underwriting level. The ADFA believes that there is a need for special consideration of welfare aspects for those growers who are in a serious financial situation. It believes there should be greater co-ordination of the adjustment scheme agencies and the Department of Social Security in order to ensure that adequate family support is provided to needy growers.

It is also essential, I believe, for the Government to abandon those imposts that it has again placed on the wine industry because of the detrimental effect on the incomes of grape growers and the severe limitations on intake to our wine makers. The adjustment scheme should also be amended to allow the debt reconstruction provision to be made more freely available to our dried vine fruit growers. The ADFA also believes the Government should issue a guarantee for the provision of finance on the basis of undelivered stocks of dried fruit that existed as at January 1984, that all imported dried vine fruits should meet the same quality standards as required by Australian packers and that only existing licensed packers be granted permits to import dried vine fruits into Australia.

I accept that long term planning on a regional basis is needed in our horticultural areas. The grape industry's morale needs a boost to break the crisis that presently exists. Governments must recognise that our horticultural industries have high capital involvement and long production times. If these are combined with the high risks of the climate and the unpredictable markets, we see the need for immediate and specific action. Unfortunately today growers are being forced out of the industry without any adequate incentive schemes to ease this exit from their industry.

Over recent years we have seen many growers buy into properties at times of high fruit prices but with limited financial advice and less marketing and production information. At the same time, of course, there is the special problem of small, eight-hectare, 20-acre properties which have attracted new growers and large numbers of new settlers into this country who unfortunately have had limited income and little financial capacity to cope with their investment. Nothing, therefore, has been done to assist those industries. As I said, we have had a fortified wine tax which was a failure and had to be withdrawn. We have the Industries Assistance Commission inquiry which has only brought about delays and a tremendous waste of resources. I believe that body has a total lack of understanding.

We now have the sales tax. We still have not seen the major impact that that is going to have on the total grape growing areas. The final straw is the election because now nothing will happen until well into March or April when, as I said earlier, we will have had another grape crop, another vintage and another impact of a harvest on the dried fruit industry.

We support this Bill but I point out that its impact will be minimal. It will do nothing to assist dried fruit grape growers who at present are involved in a massive struggle and unbelievable hardship. As the honourable member for Wakefield said, this measure does nothing to address these problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are four Bills in this cognate debate: The Dried Vine Fruits Equalization Amendment Bill 1984, the Canned Fruits Marketing Amendment Bill 1984, the Canned Fruits Levy Amendment Bill 1984 and the Canned Fruits Levy Collection Amendment Bill 1984 [No. 2]. The matters I wish to touch on are mainly in the canned fruit marketing area. Before I start I thank the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) for his courtesy in allowing me to speak . He is an expert on the canned fruit industry and very few people in Australia know more about it than he.
—You know a lot about it too, Noel.

—Yes, but I bow to the knowledge of the honourable member for Murray and also the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Fisher), of course, who is an expert in the dried vine fruits industry. Although I have a great amount of that industry in my electorate I bow to the knowledge of the honourable member for Mallee.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of the salient points on the canned fruit industry Bills have been covered by previous speakers. I rise to speak because of the importance of the canned fruit industry to the Riverina electorate and particularly to the area of the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area and to the town of Leeton. Many people in Leeton are employed in the Letona cannery. I notice that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), in his second reading speech, said that throughout Australia there are 950 orchards and that 2,300 people are in full time employment in that industry with a similar number in seasonal employment. A great number of those people are employed in the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area.

As I said, most matters have been covered but I would like to raise a few. The first is that part of the request following the Industries Assistance Commission report was for an underwriting scheme for growers. Growers were hopeful that this would come about but, of course, it did not eventuate. I make the point that if the Opposition were in government now we would certainly have looked very seriously at that matter and an underwriting scheme would have been implemented.

TALK.START.PARA: —There would have been an underwriting scheme for the canned fruit industry.

—That is right. As the honourable member for Murray says, we certainly would have implemented an underwriting scheme. I remember that when the present Opposition was in government a number of people pressed us to trade with the Russians in canned fruit. It was suggested that we sell them surplus fruit and that we enter into a trade agreement with them. The present Government, which was then in opposition, was mooting this scheme very strongly. Now, of course, when we ask the present Government what has happened to the trade with the Russians in canned fruit all we meet with is embarrassing silence. I am not quite sure what is going on in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation provides for two more members with specialist qualifications on the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation. Some people have spoken to me about this matter. I am not quite sure that it is a good thing, particularly if one of those members is the Chairman. In a number of other industries we see this happening. In some areas things do not turn out the way people expect because every industry has its own peculiarities. The canned fruit industry is no exception.

One of the few promises regarding the rural economy made prior to the last election that was kept was a promise given in Griffith. Many promises were given -but most of them were broken. As far as wine is concerned, a 10 per cent sales tax was introduced when there was a pledge not to introduce a tax. The subsidies for drought relief were dropped. Something was going to be done regarding the tariffs on orange juice, but nothing was done. The promise that was kept was that concerning a $4.2m loan to the Letona cannery. I must say that this has had an effect on Leeton. I thank the Government for providing that money to the Letona cannery. It has had an uplifting effect in the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area and in the town of Leeton. We strike a problem there in that the State Government has increased the water charges by 22 per cent. It seems to me that one government is putting money in and another government is taking money out. Overall I think it is not doing the MIA, the Riverina area, much good at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did they have a protest meeting about the water charges?
—There was a protest meeting at which 4,000 growers and people concerned in the area attended. They put it on the line to the Government that there was no way they could meet those charges and costs.
—That is about 4,000 voters in that area. You'll be right.

—That is right. It was not really surprising because the people in that area are very concerned. The whole welfare of the area is at stake. I have spoken with a number of leaders in the industry. They are generally satisfied with these Bills. They are sorry that the statutory marketing arrangements will apply for only three years instead of five years. However, I think they can live with that. We hope the arrangements will be extended in December 1987. One thing that they are worried about is the devaluation of the New Zealand currency and also the competition coming from that area.

SPEECH.PARA: While speaking of leaders of the industry, I wish to congratulate Mr Sam Catanzariti who is the President of the Australian Canning Fruit Growers Association. Mr Catanzariti has had a great deal to do in times of very difficult circumstances for the industry. He has been a tower of strength to the industry. He has taken part in a great number of discussions with governments of both political persuasions. He has guided the industry through a time of crisis. He has recently announced his retirement. I know that the Parliament and everyone involved with the industry will wish him well. He is still a very young man. I know that he has a number of options open to him and a number of challenges which I am sure he will face for the good of the community.

One of the great problems with this industry-it applies to many industries-is the effect of union activity on the product and getting the product to market. I think that everyone in the House will remember the devastating rail strike in New South Wales which had an adverse effect on many industries. While the strike was on the Deputy Chief Executive of the State Rail Authority of New South Wales wrote to the Letona cannery advising it what was going on with the strike and what the State Rail Authority proposed to do about it. I wish to read a letter which was written by the cannery to the State Rail Authority. I think the letter points out one of the major problems that we face in this country. I know that the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) mentioned the cost of wages and salaries, inflation and so on which affect the industry. If I read this letter honourable members will see something else that affects the industry which is of major importance. The letter reads:
Dear sir,
We acknowledge your letter with reference to the current rail strike. We advise that this Authority is being greatly inconvenienced in the following areas-
(1) Rail cars of products destined to valued customers are held up in the system and are still undelivered.
(2) Export shipments to Japan, United Kingdom and other areas are held up and will miss promotional periods in those countries.
Japanese buyers have constantly criticised Australian manufacturers because of the inconsistency of deliveries.
This society has spent the last 15 years building up the Letona business in Japan only to see it being damaged because of problems outside of our control.

(3) Non receipt of raw materials will affect production in both Letona and Mountain Maid plants. Assistance from the rail authority should be forthcoming to arrange alternate transport when strikes occur at short notice. This would assist in cementing customer relationships. It is impossible to arrange alternative transport at short notice in Leeton.
We do not have the same transport resources as the metropolitan area.
This society is in the process of costly retail promotion which will be wasted if we cannot move our products to the market place.
The continuation of the strike will have a disastrous effect on decentralised industry and will have a dramatic effect on the viability of this society.
The society has been assisted by the State Government and now we see this assistance being eroded by the current action.
Letona has always supported the State Rail Authority but the continued problem will make it necessary for the society to review its transport policy.

That explains to the House exactly the situation as far as union action and trying to get our exports overseas is concerned. I have mentioned Japan. To my knowledge there is no way that the people of Japan would strike if they thought it would have a detrimental effect on their fellow workers and on the economy of the nation. The actions of those unions is in contrast to the actions of unions at the Letona cannery who during the times of crisis practised wage and condition restraint for the good of their fellow workers, for the good of that cannery, for the good of the town of Leeton and, of course, for the good of the nation. These people are to be commended that they chose to take this action of moderation at a time of crisis and enabled the cannery to come through that time so that now it faces a much brighter future. I give full marks to those people.

Some worries still confront the industry. As I said before, New Zealand imports is one problem. I hope that these Bills will help to bring stability to the canning fruit industry. I know that every honourable member would wish the canning fruit growers, particularly in the MIA, Victoria and South Australia, a very good season despite some of the vagaries they have to face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I close the debate on these Bills with a few general comments. Honourable members on both sides of the House have generally been supportive. Most of the comments have related to aspects of the two industries under scrutiny and, of course, have gone beyond the Bills themselves because the dried vine fruit industry particularly is in a very serious situation at present. As far as the canned fruit industry is concerned, the Government made $4.1m available to the Letona company. The amendments to the canned fruits legislation will continue the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation but put a bit more expertise on the board. Of course, what it will really do is preserve the gentleman's agreement; in other words, it will keep the gentleman canners honest. What we are saying in respect of three years rather than five years for the continuation of the Corporation is that we have to look at some of the fundamentals and we think that in another three years would be a good time to review the situation again.

SPEECH.PARA: I apologise to honourable members that I had to depart from the chamber briefly to attend a Cabinet meeting, so I have not picked up all the reports. However, I will look at Hansard and get back to honourable members where there are questions requiring factual information rather than value judgments. I have noticed in some of the notes that my officials have given to me that a few suggestions in a few areas look a bit new, but by and large most of the suggestions from honourable members opposite reflect propositions being put forward by the industry or views being canvassed in those areas where the crops are produced.

Flowing through many of the comments from the industry, and I guess from some honourable members opposite, is the continuing problem of imports, particularly in respect of dried fruit. Like most horticultural industries the industry is very highly protectionist and there is a fundamental philosophic problem if we are to be traders on the world market. The dried vine fruits and canned fruits industries are both industries directed towards exports and we have to try to keep a relatively open position in respect of trade. However, where imports are coming into the country, either dumped or as a result of unfair trading advantage taken by other countries, of course we have to act. We are acting particularly in respect of imports of Greek dried fruits at present. The reason we think we will have some success there does not apply so much to the United States of America and Turkey. There are immense stocks of dried vine fruits in the world. The United States is the largest producer. The industry in that country is undergoing very rapid change. I recall a saying by Earl Butz, one of the United States Secretaries of Agriculture, that the best solution for low prices of agricultural products is low prices. Given the proportion that the United States produces we would hope to see some rapid adjustment in that country in relation to dried fruits which may in turn help the industry get some degree of recovery.

We are within days of receiving the final Industries Assistance Commission report on the dried vine fruits industry. Quite apart from the matters raised tonight by honourable members, we will be looking to see what carry-on assistance we can give to that industry. My view on some of the IAC reports, although I am not critical of their findings, is that when the recommendations, which are market-based and economic-based, are put against the real world and the need for governments to react to the problems of people and regions and industries, sometimes the reports do not prove to be of particular utility.

The reference by this Government to the IAC on the dried vine fruits industry was the first one in the overall review by the IAC. My colleague the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) agreed to the drafting of the reference so that it took into account alternative forms of production in those areas plus the regional impact, and also gave some attention to welfare needs, particularly in the Riverland and Sunraysia. I look forward to receiving the IAC report in the next few days and seeing what the Government will be able to do with it.

It is somewhat academic now, but the last Government did have a chance in the late 1970s to do something about the dried vine fruits industry. It proved very difficult to get agreement with the States. I am not being critical only of the Commonwealth Government. It is interesting to see that the industry itself is moving towards some sort of an agreement on the necessity for an entitlements scheme, and we will take that on board as well.

As I have said, Mr Deputy Speaker, I will be getting back to those members who have made significant contributions and who have asked for factual information. I also noticed a question relating to imports and quality standards. I must say again that if any honourable members here have any influence on State colleagues they should use it. It is becoming more and more important that we get uniform food standards in this country so that we can take some action against foods coming in which do not accord with our food standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do the States have to do so you can act in that way?
—Basically, they need to have uniform food standards.
—Should we implement the model food legislation?

—Yes. From my recollection, the Queensland Government is the only government that has really gone along to any large degree with this proposal. For example, some wine coming into this country-it is not a great deal, but it is enough to cause us worry, certainly now that there is a sales tax on Australian wine-has sugar in it and we have no way of stopping that. Such wine does not accord with our food standards or our labelling requirements, and we need to take some action.
—Preservatives in cheese would be another.

—As the honourable member for Murray has pointed out, some months ago with respect to the issue of natamycin in cheese there was some buck passing between the Australian and the Victorian governments. I do not think we can tolerate that sort of thing. Either there are additives in cheese or there are not. If we do not accept them in this country we should have uniform standards so we can take that on board. I commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Kerin) read a third time.
Consideration resumed from 13 September, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Kerin) read a third time.
Consideration resumed from 13 September, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Kerin) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: CANNED FRUITS LEVY COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1984 [No. 2]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 3 October, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Kerin) read a third time.
[COGNATE MOTION:
DECLARATION AND REGISTRATION OF MEMBERS' INTERESTS]

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the standing orders be amended by adopting the following new standing order:
Committee of Members' Interests 28A. (a) A Committee of Members' Interests shall be appointed at the commencement of each Parliament-
(i) to inquire into and report upon the arrangements made for the compilation, maintenance and accessibility of a Register of Members' Interests;
(ii) to consider any proposals made by Members and others as to the form and content of the Register;
(iii) to consider any specific complaints made in relation to the registering or declaring of interests;
(iv) to consider what changes to any Code of Conduct adopted by the House are necessary or desirable;
(v) to consider what classes of person (if any) other than Members ought to be required to register and declare their interests, and
(vi) to make recommendations upon these and any other matters which are relevant.

(b) The committee shall consist of 7 Members, 4 Members to be nominated by either the Prime Minister, the Leader of the House or the Government Whip and 3 Members to be nominated by either the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition or the Opposition Whip:

Provided that, where the Opposition is composed of 2 Parties, the committee shall consist of 4 Members to be nominated by either the Prime Minister, the Leader of the House or the Government Whip, 2 Members to be nominated by either the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition or the Opposition Whip, and 1 Member to be nominated by either the Leader of the Third Party, the Deputy Leader of the Third Party or the Third Party Whip.
(c) The committee shall elect as Chairman of the committee one of the Members nominated either by the Prime Minister, the Leader of the House or the Government Whip.

(d) The committee shall have power to send for persons, papers and records but shall not exercise that power, nor undertake an investigation of the private interests of any person, unless approved by not less than 4 members of the committee other than the Chairman.
(e) The committee shall have power to confer with a similar committee of the Senate.

(f) The committee shall, as soon as practicable after 31 December in each year, prepare and table in the House a report on its operations during that year and shall also have power to report from time to time.

The Government welcomes the report of the Standing Orders Committee in respect of the declaration and registration of private interests of members and supports the recommendations. On 5 October last year the House of Representatives agreed to a motion noting that Ministers had provided public record statements of their private interests, including those of their families of which they were aware, and expressing the opinion that all members should provide similar statements. The resolution called for the establishment of a public register of members' statements, members to provide such statements on an annual basis; amended statements to be provided of alterations if circumstances occur; individual members to declare any relevant interests if they participate in debate in the House or vote in a division; the Standing Orders Committee to report upon what changes to the Standing Orders may be required to give effect to the resolution; and the desirability of adopting other provisions contained in the report of the Committee of Inquiry into Public Duty and Private Interest, the Bowen report.

The Standing Orders Committee reported to the House of Representatives on 7 June 1984 on the changes to give effect to the matters agreed on by the resolution of the House. A later report is planned on additional matters relating to aspects of the Bowen report. The Committee considered three alternatives for the implementation of the resolution: First, incorporation in the Standing Orders; secondly, enactment of legislation; or thirdly, adoption of permanent resolutions of the House. The Committee has recommended against the first two alternatives on the basis that members' interests should be more directly identified with the conduct or eligibility of members rather than with matters of procedural order. The legislation would be too inflexible and would remove control from the Parliament to the courts. The Committee recommends the adoption by the House of specific resolutions to set up a committee of members to supervise the requirements for declaration and registration of members' interests.
