It would be a function of the proposed committee to draw up procedures for and the actual form of declarations to be made by members. The committee of members' interests is to have limited powers of investigation. The Standing Orders Committee has also recommended that the register of members' interests be tabled at the commencement of Parliament and in each subsequent calendar year and that members also be required to declare any relevant interests in proceedings.

The Committee has also recommended that the House give further consideration to the requirement for disclosure by members of the interests of their families. The Committee considers that the requirement is too widely drawn as it requires members to disclose details of the interests of family members who may no longer be dependent on them. The Committee is attracted to a restriction to dependent children, perhaps to those under the age of 18 years. The Government notes the recommendations that the House give further consideration to the requirements for disclosure by members of the known interests of their families and would agree with the Committee's view that children who are no longer dependent should not be included. The Government would suggest the adoption of the definition used by Ministers making declarations of interests, that is, spouse, including de facto spouse and dependent children. I would point out that Ministers made statements of pecuniary interests in 1983. The issue now is one for the House to debate.

I add that it is a matter of record that for some time there has been public agitation about the interests of members. It probably has some basis in the Constitution which provides that if members have a pecuniary interest it should be disclosed. Certainly the Constitution provides that, if they were to gain an advantage, they could be disqualified. In that sense it applies to all members.

Honourable members will recall that the matter attracted much publicity at the time of the resignation of the late Sir Phillip Lynch. A statement was made at the time by the then Prime Minister that he would establish a committee of inquiry. I do not want to delay the House by going back over what he said at the time but it is a matter of record that we have not achieved anything since that date. The Ministers in the present Government have had their statements tabled. Of course, under the previous Government statements were made to the Prime Minister.

The issue relates to pecuniary interests in matters that are before the House. Accordingly, it is appropriate that there be some procedure whereby the public is assured that matters discussed in this House in no way benefit any member but , if they do, that the member declare the pecuniary interest he would have as a result of the benefit and, I suggest, abstain from voting.

It is for those reasons that the Government is anxious to have this matter finalised. It was first raised in December 1977. Prior to that there was the report of the Riordon Committee on Pecuniary Interests of Members of Parliament and subsequent to that the Bowen report of the Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest, which indicated that there should be a code of conduct. There can be disagreement as to the actual detailed content of what is required from members but I do not think anybody would resile from the fact that public opinion expects all members to declare their interests. The precedents clearly show that other governments in the world, and in fact other governments in this Federation, have procedures which require members to disclose their interests.
Tuesday, 9 October 1984

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: -There are two motions before the House and I will address both rather than one specifically although obviously only one is being moved at a time. The Opposition feels quite strongly that it is an absolute farce for this Government to do this tonight when it declared earlier in the day that there is to be an election, with a new Parliament and that in the new Parliament alone will this new standing order apply.

SPEECH.PARA: The genesis of our concern is that it is ridiculous for this Parliament to be determining terms and conditions of disclosure for those members who are yet to be elected members. None of us are necessarily in a position to determine at this stage what the views and attitudes of the next Parliament might be. We therefore propose, and I will move directly, an amendment that suggests that this motion, and one to succeed it, be withdrawn and be resubmitted for consideration in the Thirty-fourth Parliament. I believe that is the proper course in circumstances where the motion designed to change the Standing Orders is to apply only from the Thirty-fourth Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —The right honourable member for New England mentioned at the outset that two motions are to be considered. It may assist the House if we have a cognate debate on the two motions. Is it the wish of the House to have a cognate debate on these two motions? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed. Separate questions will, of course, be put on the two motions. This procedure should assist the Leader of the National Party.

—My understanding of the comments of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) was that he had spoken to the second motion so I felt there was a common ground in our discussing each of them. From the point of view of the Opposition parties, we are content with and indeed support the application of standing orders Nos 196 and 326 which are already part of the Standing Orders. Each requires disclosure of interest before participating in a debate-there is a constitutional obligation to do so-and a denial of a member's right to sit were he or she to obtain special benefit from any legislation. So there is no dispute about those provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter is that we do not in any way resile from the general concept that, for example, a committee of members' interests might be constituted. We believe that it might well consider what changes, if any, are required or whether a code of conduct should be adopted by the House as necessary or desirable. We believe that it could make recommendations. We are not opposed to the constitution of this committee nor to the proposal that the committee select its chairman nominated by the Prime Minister, the Leader of the House, et cetera . We certainly would be happy for that committee to confer with a similar committee of the Senate and to table an annual report. Equally we would be content in terms of the second motion with the requirement that a member at the beginning of his or her speech in Parliament should identify whether he or she has a particular interest-that is not that much different from the provisions of standing orders 196 and 326-and similarly in a committee, and that as soon as practicable after a division is called a declaration be made in those circumstances by a member proposing to vote in that division.

As we all know, there was a Standing Orders Committee report. It has been tabled in this place, as you know, Mr Speaker, as Chairman of that Committee. I draw honourable members' attention to the fact that on page 13 there was a dissenting report to which a number of members of the coalition, including me, signed their names. Our view is significantly as expressed in that report. Our position is quite clear. We support disclosure and the necessity for members of the Parliament to be beyond reproach in any way they act in this Parliament. We believe that there are possible procedures and practices other than those that have been submitted by the Government and we intend to apply that altered form in any Parliament in which we are the Government. It therefore is necessary for us to look at what is now proposed to see the degree to which it is practicable and desirable. As I have said, however, it is my intention to move that neither of these two motions be considered by this Parliament but that they should be considered at the commencement of the next Parliament when it is proper and appropriate for that Parliament to determine those standing orders which are appropriate to it. We all know that a whole horde of sessional orders has been adopted for this Parliament and I have little doubt that the same will apply at the commencement of the next Parliament. It would be more appropriate, on a day when the election has been declared, for the Opposition's amendment to be submitted and for both of the motions to be dealt with at the commencement of the next Parliament.

The motions that are now before us have been amended by the Deputy Prime Minister, to take account of one area of our concern; that is, the obligation of members to disclose their spouses' and dependent children's interests. We are now told that they need disclose only those interests of which they are aware. I think it is of interest-I want to come back to it in a moment-that the ministerial declarations seem to contain such unanimous support for the disclosure. We all recall such headlines as 'The spouse that roared' and some comments about the wife of the Minister for Administrative Services. There was the headline 'Ministers shy to declare their interests' and a number of ministerial wives fairly strongly asserted their right to have an independent identity. Without specifically identifying them, I think it is worth drawing the attention of honourable members to section 26 (1) of the Sex Discrimination Act, which states:

It is unlawful for a person who performs any function or exercises any power under Commonwealth law or for the purposes of a Commonwealth program, or has any other responsibility for the administration of a Commonwealth law or the conduct of a Commonwealth program, to discriminate against another person, on the ground of the other person's sex, marital status or pregnancy, in the performance of that function, the exercise of that power or the performance of that responsibility.

I believe it is possible to develop an argument that this motion is contrary to that section of the Sex Discrimination Act in that it identifies marital status and the consequences of that marital status to the detriment of a member of this place. I believe it is quite possible, were any action to be taken in accordance with these proposals if they became part of the Standing Orders, that that law which was passed by this Parliament would in fact ensure that that declaration in respect of the spouse at least would have no status.

However, it is necessary to look at the meaningfulness of the declarations required. We all remember the forms with which the Ministers so bravely came in, telling us they were baring their souls, and we, being trustworthy souls, took them at their word. We remember full well how it came to be that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and each of his Ministers declared a list of pecuniary interests that were more notable for their omissions than for their revelations. On 22 September last the Ministers lodged their variations. That was only the first of the variations. On that day we had only nine but they revealed a series of either deliberate or perhaps understandable omissions from the Ministers' declarations. The more significant variation to the declarations came following that when a letter written by the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) to the Prime Minister was tabled in this Parliament. It referred to a report from Touche Ross and Company outlining his interests in and benefits derived from Coomel Pty Ltd in liquidation. Even beyond the Minister for Finance's revelations we had the instance only a few weeks ago of the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) apparently having brought into this country goods and having signed Customs forms with dubious valuation, with declarations which in our view have not been completely examined by Mr Black. These things have become a matter for debate in this House, and perhaps placed the Special Minister of State in contravention of the details that the Prime Minister said were part of this declaration of pecuniary interests tabled in the House.

So we have two Ministers at least who have significantly varied in the implications of their pecuniary interests matters that have arisen since the returns were presented to this Parliament. Nine Ministers have had to vary their specific returns and in addition to that there have been two cases where matters of benefit to Ministers in one form or another have been disclosed not by the pesentation of those returns but by things that have happened outside those members' declarations.

Mr Speaker, it is our concern that the form of this declaration will not prescribe honesty on those who seek to be dishonest. Our worry is not that we do not seek to maintain the confidence of the public in the Parliament and its members but rather that this declaration will in no way achieve that confidence. Indeed, we believe the whole nature of this public register is one that in no way will disclose assets which, in some instances where people seek to be dishonest, will be concealed from public view. We seriously question the wisdom of having any public register. If one looks at the sad decline in the general standard of this society in terms of criminal behaviour, there is little doubt that the disclosure of assets and the location of those assets for those who are perhaps more fortunate than most of us and have some significant assets will place the children at significant risk. Not only the members' assets but also their children's assets will be disclosed. So if it is revealed that dependent children have some significant assets, perhaps quite beyond their own independent determination, we will immediately have a kidnap register which sadly will make available a threat which I believe is not something that can be lightly cast aside. I seriously question the wisdom of that being included at all in any public register.

I believe that there is an entirely different position between members of this place and Ministers. In the coalition Government that preceded the Hawke Government there is no doubt that a disclosure that we made to the Prime Minister was significantly greater and more extensive and, I suggest, more honest in its presentation than anything that these Ministers have tabled in the public register. I believe that it is appropriate that Ministers disclose their assets. I do not believe that it should be a public register. I, and honourable members on this side of the House, are not against having some reconsideration of the nature of the register to ensure that there is somebody capable of receiving it perhaps other than the Prime Minister himself.

We are opposed to the concept of having members whose interests are distinctly different. This Government fails to realise the difference between the administration and the legislature. In our view, the legislature is not in the same position as the Ministers. Legislators are not in a position directly to benefit from the affairs of the government in the way that Ministers might well be. We see, therefore, a distinctly different responsibility, none of which comes out of this report. Finally, we read that there will be a necessity for an annual report. It is interesting that there has been no report back to this Parliament in the change in status of those who were Ministers. We had no report from the Prime Minister as to whether any of those settlements in the libel claims that we constantly hear him pursuing have been made out of court. Has he received large cash amounts as a result of those settlements? Are they matters which are beyond the interests of this Parliament? If he has received any, they should have been reported to this Parliament, but they have not been so reported . In accordance with those general remarks and because this is a cognate debate, I move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
'the motion be withdrawn and re-submitted for consideration in the 34th Parliament'.
I will be moving an identical motion with respect to the second motion when it is before this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Tuckey

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

INTERJECT.PARA: (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no personal difficulty with this legislation and the request for disclosure of one's assets and interests. I have been in the habit of telling this House and making public statements of where I stand on this matter. Whenever I have entered the debate on matters such as excise, I have always managed to make it clear that, in fact, I am the owner of some hotels. I sometimes wonder about that matter. Am I the representative of the thousand hoteliers within my electorate? Am I the representative of the people who will go to them for drinks? Or am I the representative of my own very small interest by comparison? The real interest to me in all of this is the fact that there are substantial omissions.

SPEECH.PARA: When we look at the motion and at the farce that was brought to the House on 22 September 1983 to which the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair ) has already referred, we find that this motion has exactly the same requirements as those the Minister submitted at that time. That suggests to me that the report and the inquiry have been ignored completely; the resolution is a copy of the ministerial statement. We already know what it did not say, particularly in regard to the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins). Having looked at that long list of about 11 different items in the motion, I find some omissions. I find that there is no obligation on a member to declare how much cash he has. I find that there is no obligation for him to declare his rich and powerful friends. Indeed, there is no obligation on him to acquaint the House of circumstances that might lead to outside pressures such as blackmail being put upon him in such a fashion that he might do things in this place that would not be in the public interest.

It is quite interesting to consider that when one considers the efforts that I made in this House to get the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to tell us about that cash on which, of course, he is quite safe. He did not bother to declare it in his statement. He did not bother to declare his cash resources because he is not obliged to do so any more than he will be obliged to do so under this new motion . In an article in the National Times of 4 April 1982 we find some very interesting statements that relate to these issues that are overlooked-the business of cash, rich and powerful friends, and the risk of blackmail. In that article a fellow by the name of Gibbs, a Labor member of the Queensland Parliament, is reported to have said:

In his telegram sent on March 9 to the secretary of the Caucus, Ros Kelly, Gibbs said that he was lodging 'the strongest of protests at the unwarranted interference by one of your Caucus members, namely R. J. Hawke, on the Queensland casino licence issue.
This man was complaining about one R. J. Hawke's support for the application of one Eddie Kornhauser. The article continued:
Gibbs said in Queensland Parliament that a 'stench' hung over Kornhauser's application.
A Labor Party person said that. The article continued:
On March 2, when the State Parliament resumed, Gibbs again attacked Kornhauser alleging that he had laundered illegally collected money.

We now get on to the cash issue. The interesting thing about the 2 March date is that it was just over a week after the Prime Minister lost some $5,000 of certain types of cash in the Boulevard Hotel.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has that got to do with this motion?
—It has plenty to do with the declaration of interests.
—Order! I suggest to the honourable member for O'Connor that he is straying rather wide from the terms of the motion and that he should return to the motion before the House.

—Mr Speaker, if this particular motion is carried and becomes part of this place, should you remain in your position in the Chair, you will be confronted with members coming into this House drawing attention to breaches of this motion. Presumably, that would be proper. Surely it is my opportunity to give you an example of what you will be confronted with-complaints, for example, by a Labor member of a State Parliament as to the activities of a member of this House, activities he has not declared in his statement.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor knows that what he is talking about is not covered by the terms of the motion before the House. I suggest he return to the motion before the House.
—The motion written by this Government has nothing to do with cash or with rich and powerful friends. The National Times article quotes one Hawke, in relation to Kornhauser, as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: 'Yes, he certainly is a good friend of mine, that's right. The question of friendship didn't really have a great deal to do with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for O'Connor should return to the motion before the House.

—Mr Speaker, this is a remarkable situation. I object to your ruling. It is amazing how sensitive people suddenly get about declaration of interest. Let me take you back to the Prime Minister's declaration of interest. He said he has a house in Sandringham for which, according to Blanche d'Alpuget in her book , he paid #17,250 when he was on #2,000 a year.

SPEECH.PARA: I expect that there is somebody around this place who can work out how much of that income would be left if he was paying that house off even at the 5 per cent interest rate of those days.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a cheap mug you are!

—I am not too worried about cheap mongrels. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs failed to declare his blooming interests with Protean ( Holdings) Ltd and the quids he got out of that. Let us not worry about the Minister.
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. The statements made by the honourable gentleman are not only untrue but also offensive. I ask that you ask him to withdraw them.
—The honourable member for O'Connor will withdraw the offensive remarks.
—Mr Speaker, I will withdraw but I point out to you that the--
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will withdraw and will proceed with his speech.

—That is exactly what I propose to do. But I hope that the Minister will now deny that he was ever in receipt of a payment as a solicitor. That is not offensive. Those are moneys associated with those matters.
—Ask the Liberal Minister about Protean.

—No, why should I ask him about that? The Prime Minister did not mention these disclosures. The disclosure of cash is not mentioned, the disclosure of powerful friends is not mentioned and the disclosure of the risk of blackmail is not mentioned. When one looks at the chronological order of this trip to Queensland one finds that it includes a stopover in northern New South Wales. We find all this cash money floating around. We wonder about the risk of blackmail as it might apply to a member of the House. Without these matters what use is this motion? What use is a motion that tells us only half the story? How often will these declarations be upgraded? I have had a look at the declaration of the Minister for Finance. Nobody has sent me an update of that declaration but it has been brought to my attention by an Aboriginal person that his wife now has employment with the Government. I believe that the wife of the Minister for Finance has a job as the assistant to the Chairman of the National Aboriginal Conference. Is it not proper that he should have advised us all of these changed circumstances? It is not an improper situation that his wife should get a job with the Government. There is nothing wrong with that. But are we to be told about that? Are there to be regular updates? Should the Government practise what it preaches?
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order.
—Is the Minister going to tell us that that is not so?
—Order! I call the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs on a point of order.
—My point of order is simply this: The statement made by the honourable gentleman is a complete fabrication. Any employee of the NAC is not in the employment of the Government.
—Oh, I see, and is-
—If you knew what you were were talking about and you were not such a cheap little smearer--
—Order! That is not a point of order; it is a statement of fact.

—The complaint that I received from this Aboriginal person was to the effect that the matter had to go through the Public Service Board irrespective of who paid the wages. His complaint was that that would cost an Aboriginal family a housing loan.
—That did not go through the Public Service Board. Why don't you stop smearing? Why don't you speak the truth?
—Order!
—Why don't you cut it out?
—You are a cheap mug and you know it.
—You are a traitor.
—You are a cheap mug and you know it.
—Order!
—Mr Speaker, that man is trying to interrupt my speech because it is hurting him. I add, Mr Speaker, that of course we have a situation where--
—You are the only convicted person in the House.
—The only reason you are not convicted is that you told lies.
—You should have been in gaol.
—Order! I call the Minister to order.

—Mr Speaker, if the Minister does not stop interjecting I will ask for extra time. Members opposite are in the habit of granting it in this place; I think they will grant it to me tonight. I turn to the motion regarding the proposed committee of members' interests and point out that the makeup of four Government members and three other members almost guarantees that there will never be a call for a Government member to provide his papers. Even though the chairman is taken from the four Government members the Government is much closer to the opportunity to persecute any members of the Opposition if it so chooses. Quite clearly that is not fair and it should be reconsidered.

SPEECH.PARA: We still have these problems of the omissions to which I have drawn honourable senators' attention. The sensitivity of the Government ranks is remarkable. I would have thought that the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) would by now be jumping to his feet and saying: 'You are quite right. It is essential that the Prime Minister's rich and powerful friends be included'. Only the other day I read in the newspaper-and I have not seen it denied-that the Prime Minister is supporting the claim of Ansett Airlines of Australia to compete overseas against Qantas Airways Ltd. Yet in the Blanche d'Alpuget confessional we read how the Prime Minister is a very close friend of the principal proprietor of Ansett Airlines, one Sir Peter Abeles. That book refers to how he used to get the keys to the Rolls Royce and drive off and how one of the passengers on one occasion was rung up and given a $25,000 loan.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member is diverting very far from the subject of the motion. The honourable member should return to the subject of the motion.

—Mr Speaker, you might suggest to us what we should talk about if we are not allowed to give examples of what has failed already. I refer, of course, to a resolution which is identical to what is proposed in this motion and which referred to statements of Ministers' pecuniary interests to 22 September 1983. If we turn to the first resolution and place numbers against the small letters we will find that they are even in the same order. The only difference, of course, is that we find that the significant ones are missing; the significant ones that would really count if one intends to declare one's interests and how they might affect how one would behave and act in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I see that my time is running out. I conclude by saying that questions have been placed on notice about some of the issues that I have raised, particularly matters relating to dealing in foreign currency. They have been ignored. The Minister-noisy Protean over there-voted to the effect that the Minister for Finance was innocent. If that can be achieved, what is the purpose of this rubbish? As I have said, I have no difficulty-I have not had any at any time-in giving people some idea of my personal wealth because I believe it is a recommendation to the people who elect me. I do not have a problem with it. I just want Government members to come clean now and start to get it right. If they want to have this sort of thing, they should do it right and start off with the question of cash.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! the honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will reject the amendment because all it does is ask that this matter be withdrawn and resubmitted in the next Parliament.
—Precisely.

—Yes. Let me have a look at it. I make the point again that this matter arose in the 1975 period with the Riordan Report of the Joint Committee on Pecuniary Interests of Members of Parliament. Of course, there was no opportunity to implement that report for reasons that are well known to honourable members opposite. In November 1977 Phillip Lynch had to resign. Following that resignation, then Prime Minister Fraser announced that he was establishing a committee of inquiry, known as the Bowen Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest. Honourable members should note the point that that occurred in 1977. It took a long while, but the Bowen Committee brought down a report in July 1979. Did the Fraser Government do anything about the recommendation of a code of conduct for members? No, it did not, in all of that period. The issue is not a question of whether honourable members have cash . The issue is: What are the honourable member's obligations in this House in relation to the people that he represents? When an honourable member asks questions about matters concerning projects in his electorate, it could be thought that he is trying to get something done that will add to his assets. It is a question of the member's conduct in this House and whether he has a pecuniary interest. They are the words that are used in the Constitution and in the Standing Orders. I am amazed to think that members of the Opposition are so afraid of disclosing to their electors what are their assets.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like honourable members opposite to listen to the point that was made by the Leader of the House (Mr Young). Let us make it clear that the resolution of the House was passed last October. It has taken from October until now for this matter to be put before the House. I think we have given more than ample time to the Committee which dealt with this matter and on which the Opposition was represented to come to a conclusion. Even when this report was produced to the House, the Opposition again dissented. For the life of me I do not know what members of the Opposition are so afraid of. Why are they not prepared to disclose their assets? The first precedent for this is the recommendation in 1979 of the Bowen Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest that there should be a code of conduct. Those opposite did nothing about it. They were afraid to disclose the position. This motion makes it very clear that it will operate from the Thirty-fourth Parliament. That really negates the amendment. Those opposite are frightened of that as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not.

—Members opposite are frightened, because that is the purpose of the amendment. Do they think we are the only ones in the world to have thought of this? Do they not realise that every member of parliament in the United Kingdom has to disclose his position? Do they not know that members in the United States have to disclose their position? Do they not know that in the States of this Federation their colleagues have to disclose their position? Why should those opposite be exempt? The Australian States do it. The Northern Territory does it. New South Wales does it. Victoria does it. South Australia does it. Those opposite are afraid to do it. What is wrong with them from the point of view of their electors? What are they so worried about? They have nothing to hide. They are on public notice as to their assets or liabilities and their electors are entitled to judge how they vote in this House because, by asking a question or moving an amendment, they may be trying to seek some personal advantage. That is the point.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no distinction between Ministers and members because everybody has the same responsibility. Since Lynch's resignation in 1977 we have been trying to get the members of this House to do what has already been done throughout the democratic world, including the majority of the Australian States. Yet those opposite are afraid to do it. I can tell the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) that there has been no alteration in the proposal. On 5 October the motion concerned members disclosing their interests and those of their families of which they were aware. The reason it had to be amended recently was that, due to an error in the Clerk's Office, those words were left out. That had nothing to do with the Government. The original motion was the same. I make that explanation in case it is thought there has been some government decision in this matter. The matter has been fully canvassed for a long period. It is a very simple proposition. It is a proposal that this House on the incoming of the Thirty-fourth Parliament-that is, after the next election -do something about telling the electors what are the assets and liabilities of members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the height of outrageous criminal hypocrisy that this Government in the dying hours of this Parliament is pontificating about declaration of members' interests, including matters as diverse as real estate, shareholdings and any assets valued at over $5,000, when only last year 10 of its Ministers proved to this Parliament and the nation that they could not properly fill in a declaration of their assets as required by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It is even worse when one realises that the Prime Minister himself has demonstrated beyond any doubt that he either cannot or will not properly declare even his own assets. The example I place before this Parliament tonight will prove this point for ever and a day. On Sunday, 21 February 1982, the honourable member for Wills, the present Prime Minister of Australia, stayed at the Boulevard Hotel, William Street, East Sydney. He occupied the Lady Nelson suite, suite 2012/13--

—On a point of order, Mr Speaker: I fail to see what the honourable member for Wills being at a hotel on a certain night has to do with this motion. It is out of order. My point of order is that this has nothing to do with the motion before the House and ought to be ruled out of order.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is some substance in what the honourable member for Melbourne raises. I am listening carefully and trust that the honourable member for Denison is going to relate his remarks to the motion before the House.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Humphreys) put:
That the question be now put.
The bells being rung-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Could I raise with honourable members a matter to which I have drawn their attention before. Remarks made during divisions which may be repeated may not be covered by privilege because they are not part of the proceedings of the House. I ask honourable members to take a great deal of care in the statements they make.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Sinclair's amendment) stand part of the question.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: DECLARATION AND REGISTRATION OF MEMBERS' INTERESTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move notice No. 2 relating to the registration and declaration of members' interests in the terms in which it appears on the Notice Paper, save provision (d) which relates to directorships in private companies. I suggest that that be amended to read ' interests in private companies to be determined by the Committee;'. I think that is the best way to put it.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there formal wording for this?

INTERJECT.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —There are representations from the Opposition side about the matter and I think that is the easiest thing to say.
—The Prime Minister said you're not allowed to make mistakes.
—I am not making a mistake; it is as a result of representations from the Opposition side.
—Order! Is the form of words available?
—I will write it out for you, Mr Speaker. The Clerk advises that I need leave to move the amendment.
—Leave is granted.
—Is it leave to move the amendment or leave to amend the motion as it appears on the Notice Paper?
—Leave to amend the motion.
—Leave has been granted to delete (d) and insert 'interests in private companies to be determined by the Committee;'.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following resolutions relating to the registration and declaration of Members' interests be adopted, such resolutions to have effect from the commencement of the 34th Parliament and to continue in force unless and until amended or repealed by the House of Representatives in this or a subsequent Parliament:

(1) Declaration of Members' interests That within 28 days of making and subscribing an oath or affirmation as a Member of the House of Representatives and within 28 days after the commencement of the first period of sittings in each subsequent calendar year while remaining a Member of the House of Representatives, each Member shall provide to the Registrar of Members' Interests, a statement of-
(1) the Member's registrable interests and
(2) the registrable interests of which the Member is aware (a) of the Member's spouse and (b) of any children who are wholly or mainly dependent on the Member for support,

in accordance with resolutions adopted by the House and in a form determined by the Committee of Members' Interests from time to time, and shall also notify any alteration of those interests to the Registrar within 28 days of that alteration occurring.

(2) Registrable interests That the statement of a Member's registrable interests to be provided by a Member shall include the registrable interests of which the Member is aware (1) of the Member's spouse and (2) of any children who are wholly or mainly dependent on the Member for support, and shall cover the following matters:
(a) shareholdings in public and private companies (including holding companies) indicating the name of the company or companies;
(b) family and business trusts and nominee companies-
(i) in which a beneficial interest is held, indicating the name of the trust, the nature of its operation and beneficial interest, and

(ii) in which the Member, the Member's spouse, or a child who is wholly or mainly dependent on the Member for support, is a trustee, indicating the name of the trust, the nature of its operation and the beneficiary of the trust;
(c) real estate, including the location (suburb or area only) and the purpose for which it is owned;
(d) interests in companies to be determined by the Committee;
(e) partnerships, indicating the nature of the interests, the activities of the partnership and the total amounts of its assets and liabilities;
(f) liabilities (excluding short-term credit arrangements) indicating the nature of the liability and the creditor concerned;
(g) the nature of any bonds, debentures and like investments;
(h) saving or investment accounts, indicating their nature and the name of the bank or other institutions concerned;
(i) the nature of any other assets (including collections, but excluding household and personal effects) each valued at over $5000;
(j) the nature of any other substantial sources of income;
(k) gifts valued at more than $250 received from official sources, or at more than $100 where received from other than official sources;
(l) any sponsored travel or hospitality received, and
(m) any other interests, such as membership of organisations, where a conflict of interest with a Member's public duties could foreseeably arise or be seen to arise.
(3) Register and Registrar of Members' Interests That-

(a) at the commencement of each Parliament, and at other times as necessary, Mr Speaker shall appoint an officer of the Department of the House of Representatives as the Registrar of Members' Interests and that officer shall also be Clerk to the Committee of Members' Interests;

(b) the Registrar of Members' Interests shall, in accordance with procedures determined by the Committee of Members' Interests, maintain a Register of Members' Interests in a form to be determined by that Committee from time to time;

(c) as soon as possible after the commencement of each Parliament and in each subsequent calendar year during the life of that Parliament, the Chairman of the Committee of Members' Interests shall table in the House a copy of the completed Register of Members' Interests and shall also table from time to time as required any notification by a Member of alteration of those interests, and
(d) the Register of Members' Interests shall be available for inspection by any person under conditions to be laid down by the Committee of Members' Interests from time to time.

(4) Declaration of interest in debate and other proceedings That, notwithstanding the lodgment by a Member of a statement of the Member's registrable interests and the registrable interests of which the Member is aware (1) of the Member's spouse and (2) of any children who are wholly or mainly dependent on the Member for support, and the incorporation of that statement in a Register of Members' Interests, a Member shall declare any relevant interest-
(a) at the beginning of his or her speech if the Member should participate in debate in the House, committee of the whole House, or a committee of the House ( or of the House and the Senate), and

(b) as soon as practicable after a division is called for in the House, committee of the whole House, or a committee of the House (or of the House and the Senate) if the Member proposes to vote in that division, and
the declaration shall be recorded and indexed in the Votes and Proceedings or Minutes of Proceedings (as applicable) and in any Hansard report of those proceedings or that division:
Provided that it shall not be necessary for a Member to declare an interest when directing a question seeking information in accordance with standing order 142 or 143.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the motion be withdrawn and resubmitted for consideration in the Thirty- fourth Parliament.
The Lady Nelson suite was to become the scene of one of the most extraordinary, mystifying, bizarre incidents in recent Australian criminal, legal and political history.
Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is a motion before the House. I suggest that the honourable member for Denison address himself to that.
—I move that the question be now put.
—Oh, come on! Gagging again. Honourable members opposite are scared of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), are they? They are covering up crime and malpractice-
—Order! I remind the honourable member for Griffith that that is not the appropriate motion. We have an amendment before the House.
—When he checked in at the Boulevard Hotel, the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) had with him a briefcase which had been presented to him by the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Humphreys) put:
That the honourable member be not further heard.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment. I want to observe that the way the Government is behaving tonight makes it appear that there is something about the Boulevard Hotel that members of the Government are trying to hide at all cost.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Humphreys) agreed to:
That the honourable member be not further heard.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Hodgman's amendment) stand part of the question.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROPOSED JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON VIDEO CLASSIFICATION

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE MESSAGE:
JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON VIDEO MATERIAL]
Debate resumed from 24 August, on motion by Mr Young:

(1) That a joint select committee be appointed to report on the operation of Regulation 4A of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations and the ACT Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 in relation to videotapes and videodiscs and in particular-

(a) the effectiveness of such legislation by comparison with previous legislation purporting to govern the importation, production, reproduction, sale and hire of violent, pornographic or otherwise obscene material;
(b) whether the present classification system, as applied by the Film Censorship Board, is adequate as a basis for import and point of sale controls;
(c) whether video retailers are observing the conditions of sale or hire attached to 'X' classified material, particularly in relation to children under 18 years;

(d) whether Regulation 4A of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations is adequate in identifying categories of prohibited material, and operating effectively in preventing the importation of videotapes/discs falling within the prohibited categories;
(e) whether children under the age of 18 years are gaining access to videotapes /discs containing violent, pornographic or otherwise obscene material;

(f) whether the ACT Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 should be amended to make it an offence for persons purchasing or hiring 'X' classified videotapes/discs to allow, suffer or negligently permit children to view such material;
(g) whether cinemas should be permitted to screen for public exhibition 'X' classified material, subject to prohibition from entry of persons under the age of 18 years;

(h) whether films which would merit an 'X' classification are being produced in Australia and if so whether Australian men and women are adequately protected by existing law from pressure to act in such films, and
(i) the likely effects upon people, especially children, of exposure to violent , pornographic or otherwise obscene material.

(2) That the committee consist of 7 members, 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Prime Minister, the Leader of the House or the Government Whip, 1 Member of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition or the Opposition Whip, 1 Member of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Leader of the National Party, the Deputy Leader of the National Party or the National Party Whip, 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate and 1 Senator to be nominated by any minority group or groups or independent Senator or independent Senators.
(3) That every nomination of a member of the committee be forthwith notified in writing to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives.
(4) That the committee proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(5) That the committee elect a Government Member as its chairman.

(6) That the chairman of the committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the committee to be the deputy chairman of the committee, and that the member so appointed act as chairman of the committee at any time when there is no chairman or the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee.
(7) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the chairman, or the deputy chairman when acting as chairman, have a casting vote.
(8) That the quorum of the committee be 3 members.
(9) That the committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources.

(10) That the committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament, and have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations it may deem fit.
(11) That the committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.
(12) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the standing orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders.
(13) That a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this resolution and requesting that it concur and take action accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, may I have the indulgence of the House to suggest that it may suit the convenience of the House to have a general debate covering this motion and order of the day No. 34, Government Business, as they are associated matters. I suggest, Mr Speaker, that you permit the subject matter of the two orders of the day to be discussed in this debate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these two matters? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

INTERJECT.PARA: Amendments (by Mr Lionel Bowen)-by leave-agreed to:
(1) Paragraph (1), omit 'report on', substitute 'inquire into and report upon'.
(2) Sub-paragraph (1) (f), omit ''X'' classified videotapes/discs', substitute 'videotapes/discs classified above ''R'''.
(3) Sub-paragraph (1) (g), omit '''X'' classified material', substitute ' material classified above ''R'''.
(4) Sub-paragraph (1) (h), omit 'an ''X'' classification', substitute 'a classification above ''R''.
(5) Omit paragraph (2), substitute the following paragraph:

'(2) That the committee consist of 9 members, 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Prime Minister, the Leader of the House or the Government Whip, 1 Member of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition or the Opposition Whip, 1 Member of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Leader of the National Party, the Deputy Leader of the National Party or the National Party Whip, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 1 Senator to be nominated by any minority group or groups or independent Senator or independent Senators.'.
(6) Omit paragraph (4).
(7) Omit paragraph (6), substitute the following paragraph:

'(6) That the committee elect a deputy chairman who shall perform the duties of the chairman of the committee at any time when the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee, and at any time when the chairman and deputy chairman are not present at a meeting of the committee, the members present shall elect another member to perform the duties of the chairman at that meeting.'.
(8) Omit paragraph (7).
(9) Omit paragraph (8), substitute the following paragraph:
'(8) That 3 members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee.'.
(10) Omit paragraph (9).
(11) Omit paragraph (10), substitute the following paragraphs:
'(10) That the committee have the power to send for persons, papers and records , and to move from place to place.
'(10A) That the committee report by 30 April 1985.'.
(12) Omit paragraph (11).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Omit sub-paragraph (1) (a), substitute the following sub-paragraph:
'(a) the effectiveness of such legislation to control adequately the importation, production, reproduction, sale and hire of violent, pornographic or otherwise obscene material;'
(2) Sub-paragraph (1) (c), omit ' ''X'' '.
(3) After sub-paragraph (1) (d) insert the following sub-paragraph:
'(dd) the extent to which videotapes/discs containing pornographic and violent material are available to the community;'.

I wish to say something about what we are seeking to do tonight because this debate is no more than a disagreeable and debasing farce. We are proposing to set up a Joint Select Committee on Video Classification which will stay in existence until the 25th of this month when Parliament comes to an end; and so does the Committee.

If honourable members want to know why we have actually reached this stage, they will need to go back and see what took place earlier this year when the Opposition moved to disallow the so-called model code, that perfectly absurd model code, which came out of the mind of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and was put before the Senate and this House as well. That was going to be the model code for classification of pornographic video material. That was going to be the purpose it would achieve. We objected to it. We pointed out that there were no point of sale controls. We pointed out that the code was deficient in many ways.

There was a debate here. Only one person on the Government side, the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy), spoke in that debate. Nobody else spoke on the Government side. A number of speakers spoke from our side but none from the Government side, although a number of people are listed to speak tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order on a matter of procedure. I do not wish to interfere with the speech by the honourable member for North Sydney. The honourable member has told us that he has circulated an amendment. I have seen the amendment before and I would like to see it again.
—It is on the Notice Paper at page 9333.
—Does that satisfy the point raised? I think the honourable member for North Sydney accepts that it is not an unreasonable intervention by the honourable member for Prospect.
—That is our motion. I am talking about the amendment by the honourable member for North Sydney.
—If the honourable member for Prospect resumes his seat we will make sure that the amendments are available to honourable members. I call the honourable member for North Sydney.

—On 4 June, when we debated the disallowance of the Classification of Publications Ordinance I said that we should have an inquiry and through an inquiry we should be able to get the views of people. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . where the views of the Catholic bishops, other church groups and mothers groups are taken into consideration, and during which expert evidence is received as to the effect of hard core pornography on the minds of children.
The Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy), when I put to him:
You hold a genuine community inquiry.
became abusive, the poor fellow, because he is bereft of common sense or of anything to put to the House. He said:
Not one Opposition member came up with any proposal that was worth listening to as to how the matter should be handled.

(Extension of time granted). I specifically put a proposal that there should be an inquiry. That was his reaction. We did not hear from anyone that night, as I say, apart from the Minister. Why did we not hear from other members who were going to be here this evening? Why did they not come into the House? After all they are decent, honourable people who no doubt have an interest in this subject . They did not come because while being decent and honourable they lack the courage or the interest or, in simpler, terms, they were told: 'You are not to go into the House; you are not to speak on this subject; you are not to embarrass the Government, you are not to add to the embarrassment that the Attorney-General has already brought on this Government's shoulders'. We will hear those honourable members tonight express views on what should be done, on what may be done and on what might come out of this inquiry, but we will not hear from any one of them a single reason as to why he or she was not in the House on the last occasion. They were outside the doors, unwilling and afraid to come inside.

If we go through the history of this proposal, not only is it perfectly plain that it came from the Opposition on 4 June, but also it is made even plainer by the fact that on 7 June the Speaker announced that he had received a message from the Senate for the establishment of a committee to inquire into the matters now before the House. That matter had come from the Opposition in the Senate and not from this Government. The Special Minister of State (Mr Young) gave an undertaking on 7 June that the matter would come on for debate early in the next Budget sittings. Here we are now with two weeks or so before this House is dissolved and, as I say, we are going to go through the solemn farce of establishing a committee that will inquire and report in accordance with its terms of reference to this House. We all know that nothing will happen. We all know that the only reason this proposal has been brought on for debate tonight is that nothing can happen. We know that the Government, having control of the business of this House, had it desired to do so could have dealt with all of these matters very much earlier, but that has not been done.

I make one or two general observations on the kinds of problems that the committee should be examining, if it were ever to examine anything, on its reconstitution after the election. It should be reconstituted after the election and it should not simply be treated here as it is now, as an expedient to be dealt with so that the Government can go to the people and say: 'Yes, we are concerned about this subject because we went ahead and established a committee to inquire into it and to report to this House'. I make the observation first of all that there can be no doubt that we are all shaped by the past and by experiences and that we cannot separate out the sexual behaviour or attitudes that we see or which are exhibited as part of our past. That particularly applies to children. Of course, in the case of children emulation and imitation is an inherent trait. When one thinks of the consequences to the minds of young children of being confronted, as I have said before, with, for example, scenes of bestiality-this Government still proposes that reasonable bestiality should be allowed to be viewed in certain circumstances-one can only conclude that the consequences for a sensitive child could be perfectly bad and perfectly foul.

Let me make another observation of a general kind; that is, that a central question here is the long term effect on our society of constant and indiscriminate exposure to hard core pornography. We are not simply dealing with the present; we are not simply seeking to deal with the effects of hard core pornography on children; we have to look at what might be called the long term consequences-whether there will be long term consequences-in terms of the degradation of our society and of the debasement of the place that sexual love has in families and between couples. It was very well put by an American by the name of Victor B. Cline in a treatise called 'Where do you draw the line?'. He said:

The real issues concern the consequences of many years of indulgence in obscene literature and arts, or, more exactly, the consequences of growing up in a community in which grossly obscene arts are highly prevalent, readily accessible , and sanctioned by the law.

The question is: Where do we draw the line? There can be no doubt that a line should be drawn somewhere. I think all of us are agreed upon that. None of us would think that complete freedom was permissible. We are not talking about curtailing freedom of expression. After all, that is what the purveyors speak of . We are talking about drawing a line in respect of matters which do not concern freedom of expression of ideas. After all, bestiality is not really an expression of an idea. Where should the line decently be drawn in our society?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment, Madam Deputy Speaker.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not my intention to speak at any length on this question, but honourable members could tempt me. I do not feel terribly strongly about the Opposition amendments. I suppose we will deal with them in the way we usually deal with amendments coming from the Opposition and we will not accept them. I shall just make a couple of points.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall be Chairman of the Joint Select Committee on Video Classification that is to be appointed. I certainly feel that it is worth while having a look at the issues that are being raised in the reference to the Select Committee. I do not want to reveal my prejudices too much at this stage, but it is obvious that everybody has prejudices in this sort of area. I was surprised to hear the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) suggesting in effect that if the Committee had been set up four weeks ago-

TALK.START.PARA: —Two months ago.
—Or even two months ago we would by now have solved all the problems that exist in that--
—At least you would have shown you were fair dinkum.

—On this issue the honourable member for Moreton is one of the greatest hypocrites one could ever find. He is an absolute and complete hypocrite, if one remembers his history. There have been many investigations into this problem-there have been United Kingdom commissions; there has been at least one long- running presidential commission in the United States of America on the same topic-and I do not think that the results are clear cut. A combination of different groups in the community is now taking a stronger line on what they consider to be pornographic material. One has what I would broadly call the Fred Nile faction joined by the radical women's groups who take a similar attitude to the censorious one.

SPEECH.PARA: It would be fair to say that my prejudices are against any form of censorship. Anyone who wants to stop me or other adults reading, seeing or hearing things would have to put up a good case that there is an actual danger to individuals in the community to establish a case in favour of bans. One hopes that most people in the community would take a similar basic attitude. Some people would be more easily persuaded that there is a danger to a significant section of the community if they are exposed to this type of material. Others would take a line that it is much less likely that exposure to this sort of material actually leads to grave consequences. I am not sure on that issue. I would like to refresh my memory on what findings have been reached by psychologists, psychiatrists and other people who claim some expertise in these matters when they have examined this subject in other countries. Since it has become an important issue in the community, I think it is important to establish such a committee.

As I said earlier I see no great problems with amendments moved by the honourable member for North Sydney. To a large extent I think they would be covered by the motion that was moved by the Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen) . The only point I cannot follow is why it should be sought to delete 'X' from paragraph (1) (c). The implication is that X-rated videos should not be available at all for sale or hire. Is that the implication there and is it suggested that we should not consider what their effect would be in relation to children under the age of 18? Is it implied that X-rated material should not be available at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is not the implication out of the terms of reference.
—I cannot follow why it is desired to omit 'X' from paragraph 1 (c). Is it desired to have it read 'sale or hire attached to classified material'?
—It simply widens it.

—It widens it. I feel, as I am sure the committee will feel, that even without that amendment we would obviously look at material in general and the potential effect of it on individuals in the community. I think Parliament should have a basic commitment and a non-censorious attitude. At the same time, if it can be shown clearly that there are clear cut risks associated, obviously the Committee should report and advise Parliament and the Government that maybe the legislation relevant to these items should be changed.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Humphreys) put:
That the question be now put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I have just one question. The Government has moved some amendments to the motion and I have moved some amendments to the motion. We have had a vote upon one set of amendments. You have not specified which amendments we are voting on. I am not being critical-
—Order! I understood that the amendments moved by the Deputy Prime Minister were incorporated into the motion.
—That answers my question. Thank you very much.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Lionel Bowen) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker--

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Lionel Bowen) agreed to:
That the question be now put.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
House adjourned at 1.37 a.m. (Tuesday)

The following papers were deemed to have been presented on 8 October 1984:

Lands Acquisition Act-Statement of lands acquired by agreement authorised under sub-section 7 (1).
Seat of Government (Administration) Act-Determinations, dated 2 October 1984, listing fees for purposes of-
Adoption of Children Ordinance.
Building and Services Ordinance.
Lakes Ordinance.
Machinery Ordinance.
Real Property Ordinance.
Registration of Births, Deaths and Marriages Ordinance.
Registration of Deeds Ordinance.
Sale of Motor Vehicles Ordinance.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Ainslie Fire Station, Australian Capital Territory

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Territories and Local Government, upon notice , on 5 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did his Department take delivery of a special fire truck which cost nearly $210,000 for use at the Ainslie Fire Station, Australian Capital Territory; if so, has it remained idle since it was delivered in July 1982.
(2) It is a fact that it remains idle because of (a) unsettled union claims about allowances to operate it and (b) some unresolved questions about its safety.
(3) What safety questions in relation to this vehicle require attention.
(4) Is the vehicle, as suggested in news reports, under-braked.
(5) Was the vehicle built in response to a tender specification prescribing its weight and braking capacity; if so, is the vehicle built to that specification.

(6) Has his attention been drawn to a report in the Canberra Times of 28 February 1984, that the Canberra Branch of the Federal Fire Fighters' Union has been willing to discuss the use of this vehicle, but that the union has not heard anything about getting the Skyjet operating for some months; if so, is the report correct.
(7) Has his Department been inactive about resolving this dispute; if so, what are the reasons.
(8) Has his attention been drawn to the acting A.C.T. Fire Commissioner's stated view that he was concerned about such an expensive piece of equipment lying idle.
(9) Is this matter of concern to him as Minister, and what action has he personally taken to resolve the outstanding questions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The Fire Brigade did, however, take delivery of a truck meeting this general description in January 1983 for use at the Fyshwick Fire Station.

(2) There is a union claim for an allowance which has not yet been finalised, but an agreement was reached some time ago which allowed the vehicle to be placed in service pending resolution of the claim.
It was necessary to withdraw it again to correct a number of structural problems which were discovered. These have now been rectified and the vehicle is now in service.

(3) (4) and (5) None. The braking capacity was specified and the vehicle was required to meet both the Australian Capital Territory and New South Wales Traffic Standards, including those in relation to tare weight. When delivered to Canberra in January 1983, the vehicle's brakes did not meet specification, but the manufacturer subsequently made the necessary adjustments. This was finalised in June 1983, after which time the vehicle was accepted by the brigade and could first have been considered available for use.
The gross vehicle weight originally specified was exceeded with the concurrence of the Fire Commissioner, and still satisfied Australian standards.
Although the vehicle then met specification, further brake up-grading and weight reduction were effected and more improvements are being considered.

(6) Yes, but in some respects the report was inaccurate or incomplete. My Department held several discussions with the union resulting in an offer of an interim settlement being made. The Salary and Wages Pause Act 1982 and the 1983 National Wage Case principles precluded any formal resolution of the union's claim until at least 1 February 1984. Agreement has been reached on suspending action during a joint examination of the union's claim.
(8) Yes.

(9) Yes. I have met with representatives from the Federal Firefighters' Union and have instructed my Department and the A.C.T. Fire Brigade to ensure that all related matters are resolved as quickly as possible.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Houses or Premises held by the Department of Administrative Services

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 21 August 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many houses held, for any purpose, by the Minister's Department or any agency or statutory authority responsible to the Minister in the Australian Capital Territory were vacant on 18 June 1984.

(2) Does the Minister's Department control any other premises in the Australian Capital Territory which are presently unused which could be occupied for residential purposes; if so (a) where are these premises, (b) what were their previous uses and (c) are there any plans for their future use.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Two such houses were vacant on 18 June 1984. They were the former South Vietnamese Embassy premises which have since been disposed of by public auction.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 24 August 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What amount has been paid out in supporting parents benefits since the introduction of the Family Law Act in 1975.
(2) What amount of this total or of other pension or benefit payments can be attributed to divorced people.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The following table shows expenditure on supporting parents' benefits for each year since 1975. Males are the only persons for whom supporting parents' benefit is paid on account of divorce. Also included are figures for Class A and B widows' pension. Female divorcees with children receive Class A widow's pension and those without children Class B widow's pension.

(2) Expenditure on divorced people is not identified separately from other expenditure. The following table shows the proportion of supporting parent beneficiaries and Class A and B widow pensioners identified as divorced as at 30 June of the years in question.
