ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Third Party Insurance Premiums

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Territories and Local Government, upon notice , on 4 September 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Was the NRMA submission on Australian Capital Territory third party insurance rates dated 19 March 1984, used as the basis for the new A.C.T. third party insurance premiums announced on 11 June 1984.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Territories and Local Government, upon notice , on 6 September 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On what date did he receive a letter, dated 22 June 1984, from the Motorcycle Riders' Association requesting a meeting as soon as possible.
(2) Did he reply to that letter; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The letter from the Motorcycle Riders' Association was received in my office on 25 June 1984.
(2) The letter raised several issues that required consideration. I met with representatives of the Association on 7 September 1984 to discuss these issues.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 6 September 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a memorandum, dated 1 June 1984, to all permanent heads, heads of statutory authorities and staff organisations from the Secretary of the Public Service Board, concerning encouragement of union membership.
(2) Was the memorandum brought to the attention of all staff in the Minister's Department and all statutory authorities reporting to the Minister; is so, how and on what dates.

(3) What additional action has been taken within the Minister's Department and statutory authorities reporting to the Minister to avoid delays in constructive action being taken to encourage union membership and on what dates; if no additional action has been taken, what are the reasons for such a decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) A memorandum from the Public Service Board entitled 'Encouragement of Union Membership' was received in the Department on 6 June, 1984. The full extent of the memorandum was published in the Department's Staff Bulletin (No. 1984/22) dated 21 June, 1984.

(3) Action is proceeding on a review of existing practices and procedures in the Department and the development and introduction of any additional practices and procedures necessary to ensure compliance with the Public Service Board's advice. Existing practices include advice to Unions, on request, of the names of potential members employed in the Department and inviting representatives of appropriate unions to address new recruits attending induction courses. In addition, the Department employs a large industrial workforce, including car and transport drivers, storemen, printing tradesmen and associated staff, which is almost fully unionised.

The responsibility for the Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Services Limited (CACS) also falls within my portfolio. The Company, which is wholly owned by the Commonwealth, has operation and management responsibility for food, beverage and accommodation services in Commonwealth premises. The Company encourages its employees to be members of a trade union or other employee association which has coverage of the operations. Because of the policy adopted by the Company, a large number of its employees are members of the relevant union or staff association.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 13 September 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to his Press release of 27 August 1984 concerning the construction of Commonwealth office buildings in 12 centres to reduce the rental cost for Commonwealth departments, is Shepparton, Victoria, one of the centres; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: No. The Commonwealth already owns a building at Shepparton. My Department, however, is examining the feasibility of constructing a new office building on Commonwealth-owned land at Shepparton.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Community Employment Program: Department of the Treasury

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 13 September 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: How many (a) males and (b) females have been engaged in (i) the Minister's Department and (ii) any statutory authorities reporting to the Minister, as temporary employees under the Community Employment Program, in each of the months June, July and August 1984.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: No males or females were employed by my Department or any statutory authority within my portfolio under the Community Employment Program in June, July or August 1984.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Community Employment Program: Department of Resources and Energy

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 13 September 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: How many (a) males and (b) females have been engaged in (i) the Minister's Department and (ii) any statutory authorities reporting to the Minister, as temporary employees under the Community Employment Program, in each of the months June, July and August 1984.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: In June, July and August there wer no (a) males or (b) females engaged as temporary employees under the Community Employment program in (i), my Department . In (ii), any statutory authorities reporting to me, the figures are as follows : June (a) 23 (b) 5; July (a) 27 (b) 4; and August (a) 25 (b) 4. All were engaged by the Australian Atomic Energy Commission.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Community Employment Program: Department of Science and Technology

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 13 September 1984.

QUESTION.PARA: How many (a) males and (b) females have been engaged in (i) the Minister's Department and (ii) any statutory authorities reporting to the Minister, as temporary employees under the Community Employment Program, in each of the months June, July and August 1984.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: COMMUNITY EMPLOYMENT PROGRAM SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY
Employment Statistics: 1 June 1984-31 August 1984
Department
Statutory Authorities

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 13 September 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Can he say whether the Government intends to extend repatriation benefits to Australians who were members of the Greek Army under British command between 1941 and 1945.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Under the Repatriation Act, former members of allied forces of the 1939-45 War are eligible for service pensions if they satisfy certain conditions, including a minimum Australian residence requirement. The Act excludes persons whose only service was in forces that were 'irregular'.

Insofar as the honourable member's question relates to former members of Greek forces from 1941 to 1945 who have subsequently become Australian citizens, the Repatriation Commission advises that Greek forces of the exiled King George which fought with the Allies in North Africa are eligible for service pensions subject to the conditions in the legislation and provided the Australian residence requirement is satisfied.
